name: Cờ ngũ hành
description:
In this chess game, Sun and Moon are leading a war against each other, with the help of the five elements planets (starring Mars for the fire, etc).

Using an unique mechanique of capture and respawn, based on the asian theories about cycles of elements (very famous in chinese medicine for example), this game born in Vietnam purpose a deep strategical experience similar to chess, with easy to learn rules.
mechanics: Grid Movement, Pattern Movement, Square Grid, Static Capture

name: Warlords of Ravenna
description:
A card game for 2 to 8 players with either individual or team play.

Players take turns placing cards that represent military strategies, renown Commanders and infamous Assassins. A player can place a card on themselves or on an opponent.

A round ends when a player chooses to attack instead of drawing a card. The attacking player, and the one being attacked, total up their cards. The player with the highest total wins that battle (a tie goes to the attacker) and points are awarded for the round.

The game ends when one player has scored enough points to be crowned 'Ruler of Ravenna.'
mechanics: Score-and-Reset Game

name: Fractured System
description:
A free to download and play game created by Chris Winterburn & 'The Unicorn Collective' Facebook Group Community.

Fractured System is an easy to play, action pawn and area control game set in a single solar system. 2 - 4 players can compete for control by moving their ships, attacking opponents, exploring, laying control tokens and researching ship upgrades.

A game takes between 30 and 60 minutes to play and players aged 7+ can enjoy it.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Points, Area Majority / Influence, Movement Points, Moving Multiple Units, Sudden Death Ending

name: The Megs
description:
The Megs is a cyberpunk two player competitive card game for players aged 14+ where cards positioning is central and, with highly-thematic effects, will generate brain-burning situations.

In The Megs, you will use colourful characters called Operators to wage corporate war against an enemy Megacorporation. Positioning your Operators and activating their skills, you will try to complete extremely risky missions like assassinating a high-ranking enemy Operative or smearing high-visibility opponents in the infamy of a sex scandal but, most of all, you will deploy your best and slyest hackers to steal precious data from your opponent!

Played in three rounds called Operations or “Ops” over the course of 30 to 45 minutes, the game is playable on a 13 per 18 inches (33/45 cm) table and meant to offer the depth and challenge of bigger games with the option of reducing it to a shirt pocket-friendly size.

The mechanics aim at generating puzzle-like situations, bluff, double-guessing, and mind-bending domino-effect while introducing edgy characters and tense situations that will immerse the players into our special breed of the Noir Sci-fi genre that is cyberpunk.

Including high-tech assassins, vicious cyber-tox, mad salary-men, ruthless gangs of enhanced Yakuzas, mysterious shamans of the virtual world, terrorists from high-tech death cults and lethally sexy Black Widows, The Megs is made into a dark and daring world thanks to the outstanding art of genius illustrator Ania Kryczkowska (Gloom of Kilforth, Paradise Lost).

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Science Fiction, Spies/Secret Agents
mechanics: Chaining, Hand Management, Modular Board, Pattern Building, Take That

name: ACP164: Albedo Combat Patrol – The Rule Book
description:
ACP164 Albedo Combat Patrol provides the rules for playing skirmishes with miniatures in the science fiction setting of Steve Gallacci’s Albedo comics.
ACP164 can be played with as few as 4 figures per side up to company sized engagements with 50+ figures and supporting vehicles and flyers.

The following components are required to play ACP164.

The Activation Deck is used to control the sequence in which units activate during a turn.
The Action Deck is used to resolve fire, melee, and morale. Typically, each player has their own Action Deck.
Various Markers denote wounds, stun, out of ammunition and morale.
Unit Data Cards inform players of the attributes of the figures within the units they control as well as the weapons with which those units are equipped.
Model figures, terrain, etc. are used as playing pieces in this tabletop game.
Six-sided order dice are used as part of the Double Random ActivationTM mechanism to control the sequence in which units activate.
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Spanish Pyramid: Sixes & Sevens
description:
Pirámide española (Spanish Pyramid) is a solitaire (patience, rèussite) card game challenges you to clear out a randomly created spread of cards by pairing them.

To play this game you will need a Spanish 48 card deck and a playing surface. Some skill in adding numbers is necessary but only up to 13. Instructions are also given for how to reduce a French/American deck of 52 cards down to the right size.

The game’s name derives from the pyramid shape of the starting spread. Six and 7 make 13.
mechanics: Solo / Solitaire Game

name: The Age of Eagles Scenario: The Battle of Elchingen
description:
Custom scenarios for Age of Eagles, although the orders of battle can be converted for other rule systems.

Smaller historical engagement.

ELCHINGEN (October 1805):
To complete his encirclement of Mack's army near Ulm, Napoleon orders Marshal Michel Ney to secure the Elchingen bridge over the Danube River.

Can the Austrians looming on the nearby heights stop Ney's corps from closing the ring on Field Marshal Mack?

Victory points: One point for every "worn" enemy brigade, and two points for each enemy "spent" or destroyed unit. Two points for uncontested control of Ober-Elchingen(the "abbey" is not considered part of the town.)
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Simulation

name: Mobility Era: Play Your Taxes!
description:
Mobility Era: Play Your Taxes! is a competitive and educational trivia board game about living and working in Europe.

The aim of the game is to accumulate Happy Points (HaPs). “Money can’t buy happiness”, but you can certainly invest in your health (HePs)! The game is based on the most recent statistics and is a fun type of trivia game about living conditions in 41 European countries, and it's suitable for adults and children alike.

—description from the designer
categories: Dice, Economic, Educational, Math, Travel, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Income, Roll / Spin and Move, Track Movement

name: Operation World War II: Skirmish Wargame Rules for 20-28mm Figures
description:
Inside this book you’ll find all the rules you need to simulate a battle set in the Second World War at a scale of single man and single vehicle. The book also contains specific tables for the weapons used by each army but, thanks to the Summary Tables that are also included, they are easy and fast to use.

The game also uses a unique and innovative system based on Order Cards to represent simultaneous actions and which will allow you to interrupt or anticipate the enemy’s moves. You can recreate battles with an historical background or play through the sort of missions that were common in the Second World War; occupying a town, breaking through enemy lines, taking a bridge, capturing a fuel dump – these will be your main objectives...

This game has been translated into four languages and developed after six years of playtests all over the world, and Operation World War Two now represents the new dimension of three-dimensional wargaming, where realism and simplicity have finally found the right balance. A unique experience based on a surprisingly immediate game system.

—description from the publisher
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Simulation

name: Slam Wars: Wrestling Legends of the Mid-Atlantic
description:
Slam Wars is a card battle game that celebrates the various wrestling territories that existed from the 1940's until the 1990's. It captures the unique flavor of the territory by using historical wrestlers, tag teams, managers, promoters, announcers and referees. Each Slam Wars set is a standalone game, but can be seamlessly integrated with any other Slam Wars set to form a larger playing pool.

Slam Wars: Wrestling Legends of the Mid-Atlantic comes in a 2-piece full-color dual deck poker box and includes a 20-page full-color instruction guide. There are a total of 90 playing cards:

44 solo wrestlers
16 tag teams
13 stat boosters
10 common match stipulations
6 special grudge match stipulations
1 championship


A round of play is called an "event" and consists of 7 matches (4 solo and 3 tag team). Seven match stipulation cards will be exposed, one for each match of the event. Each wrestler and tag team card is rated in 5 different categories (represented by symbols that match the stipulation cards). The objective is to strategically place the cards you were dealt in matches where they can perform the best (i.e. have high ratings). Like a good wrestling booker, you are trying to maximize your wrestler's strengths and minimize their weaknesses. After comparing the stats in that particular category, the card with the higher rating wins the match-up. Whichever player wins a majority of the 7 matches wins the event and is awarded the championship card. The holder of the championship card has an advantage heading into the next round of play. Much like poker, the rounds can continue until the participants decide to end it.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Open Drafting

name: Hyakuninisshu English Translated Karuta 1-100 Complete
description:
Hyakuninisshu English Translated Karuta is an English translated version of the Japanese Karuta using the translation of the original Japanese old poems from the anthology called "Hyakuninisshu". This edition is the complete version of all 100 cards.

The game is sometimes described as intellectual martial arts. It is about listening and being extremely focused and fast, just like the Samurai with their swords. Only here you fight with cards instead. The manga and anime and now a movie called "Chihayafuru" is about this game. For Chihayafuru fans, this is the karuta you've been waiting for!

The game is comprised of two decks of cards, the Reader deck and the Player deck. Cards in the Reader deck contain the whole poems while cards in the Player deck contain only the second part of these poems. To begin the game, a Reader is chosen (or you may opt to use the Reader app) and the players are divided into two teams sitting on opposite sides of the table or play area. The Reader shuffles the Reader deck and the Players mix, split evenly the Player deck between the teams and place them face-up in 3-4 rows in front of them. The Reader will read the complete poem on the reading cards and the player that finds the matching Playing card first takes that card and puts it aside. If the card taken was on your opponent's side, you must give one card from your side to your opponent. The first team that has no cards left on their side is the winner (you must get rid of all your cards first, to win).

The game is set in Japan during the Genpei war (1180-1185). In order to win the war, you need a strategy. Place the cards you are familiar with close to you (in the beginning it is normal that none of the cards are familiar). If you know what cards your opponent is familiar with, place those cards as far as possible from them inside the playing field. Since the reader or app will always read the complete quotation, you do not need prior knowledge of the poems. Strategically place the playing cards in a way that you can find and take them quickly such as laying them alphabetically or categorize them under the same first words.
categories: Ancient, Card Game, Memory, Wargame, Word Game
mechanics: Action Queue, Cooperative Game, Open Drafting, Pattern Recognition, Take That

name: Bag of Spiders
description:
It's a bag of spiders! it's also 8 fun and fantastic games to play with 1-9 of your friends and enemies!

Bag of Spiders features eight silly games that we have curated for your enjoyment, but you will find that there are many uses for your bag of spiders.

Bag of Spiders, a press your luck game for 2 - 5 players by Jeremy Davis
Last Spider Standing, a rolling war game for 2 - 4 players by Jeremy Davis
Squish, a social awkwardness game for 5 - 10 players by Carla Kopp and Jeremy Davis
Spider Leap, a dexterity game for 2 - 4 players by Jeremy Davis and Shawn Stankewich
Spider Sculptors, an artistic game for 4 - 8 players by Shawn Stankewich, Nick Kopp, and Jeremy Davis
Spider Poker, a bluffing game for 3 - 5 players by Zach Hoekstra
Spider-cala, an abstract game for 2 players by Zach Hoekstra
Mississippi Jackson And The Curse Of The Squeaky Inflatable Spiders, a very silly RPG for 2-6 players by Zach Hoekstra
mechanics: Deduction, Hidden Roles, Push Your Luck

name: Broken Crown
description:
Broken Crown is an epic Kingdom Building strategy game for 2-5 players set in the world of Orvæn; a land rich with history and culture that still aches from the scars of recent war. Players act as a noble of their unique homeland to rebuild their nation’s glory and restore the Crown.

Each play of Broken Crown is different from the next. The game uses elements of Euro-Style trading games along with direct player conflict to create a dynamic, ever-changing experience. Players win the game by achieving the most Glory points at the game’s end. Each game is played over a number of Years, each year being split in to 3 turns referred to as Seasons. As the seasons pass, event cards will be revealed that will affect all nations, and players will have to adapt in order to maintain their place in the Kingdom.
During the Market Phase players may recruit famed Champions, each with their own story and deep interwoven family history. They may purchase land deeds and ancient relics by bidding in the central Marketplace. These cards may be placed on their Realm Boards to build their own unique economies and armies.

In the Battle Phase, each player will secretly choose from their battle cards to maintain peace, attack another player’s realm or assist others in their efforts.

How well players fare in Orvæn depends not just on their economic or military skill, but their ability to negotiate and lead. Broken Crown allows for free trade and deal making between players for resources and assistance. Some players will choose to become warlords, seeking to dominate others in their pursuit of glory. Some will be peacekeepers of the land, earning their title as a respected leader of the people.

Build your Realm • Unite the Nations • Mend The Crown

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Market, Negotiation

name: Hokori
description:
Hokori (meaning pride or arrogance), is an easy to learn 2 player bidding and dueling game to the death. Players will first draw up a hand of 10 cards, choose which 5 to keep and which five to place up for bid. Both players will bid on the remaining 10 cards, trying to choose wisely to gain an advantage over their opponent. Once the bidding is over, the dueling phase begins. Player choose their stance from 4 options (attack, defense, meditate, or instinct) each with their own advantages and disadvantages. Play continues until both players have passed, are out of playable cards, or one player is dead.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Open Drafting, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Tug of War

name: Curious Humans: Morbid Humans Expansion Pack
description:
Curious about the morbid and macabre?

Explore these dark themes with the Morbid expansion for Curious Humans.

WARNING: The Morbid expansion contains confronting topics such as death, suicide, torture and other morbid themes. Please use caution when purchasing this product.

Contains 50 morbid statement cards.
categories: Card Game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Command Cards, Deduction, Open Drafting, Storytelling

name: Curious Humans: Deviant Humans Expansion Pack
description:
Expose your friends’ wicked thoughts about each other with the Deviant expansion for Curious Humans.

Warning: Deviant Humans contains sexual references about the other humans playing. Ensure all players are aware of these cards before beginning the game.

Contains 50 deviant statement cards
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Mature / Adult, Party Game
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Command Cards, Deduction, Open Drafting, Storytelling

name: Poisoned Chalice: Pass the Cup
description:
Poisoned Chalice is a fast-paced card game for 2 to 6 players. You will be playing cards to a common pile and adding up the score.

In this game you are competing nobles at a banquet table. As talk passes around the table you are adding wine (cards) to a shared chalice (common pile). When the chalice is full, the player holding it drinks (wins the trick). However, as well as wine you can choose to add poison. Not too much (adding up to exactly 31) has no effect, but too much (adding up to more than 31) has a negative effect. Special card effects adjust scoring mechanisms, and impose effects on other players.

A game is played till one player either scores positive 61 points or negative 61 points.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Math, Print & Play
mechanics: Trick-taking

name: Dark Force Incursion: Marsh Expansion
description:
These are the Marsh Expansion rules for Dark Force Incursion (DFI), a roll and write game that is for one person, taking 20 to 40 minutes to play. This expansion deals with the addition of the marsh hex tile to the game.

The marsh lands are hard to reclaim back for the players and probably not the type of map you would want to play your first Dark Force Incursion game on. The fact that the layout of the marshes is unpredictable can cause huge problems and take over large areas of the map, that therefore become impenetrable. A victory in a marsh region is well earned.

-description from designer
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Dark Force Incursion: Lakes Expansion
description:
These are the Lakes Expansion rules for Dark Force Incursion (DFI), a roll and write game that is for one person, taking 20 to 40 minutes to play. This expansion deals with the addition of the lake hex tile to the game.

-description from designer
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Dark Force Incursion: Muster and Ambush Expansion
description:
These are the Muster and Ambush Expansion rules for Dark Force Incursion (DFI), a roll and write game for one person, taking 20 to 40 minutes to play. This expansion deals with the addition of the muster and ambush hex tiles to the game. These rules are also designed to work alongside the Forest, Marsh and Lake Expansion rules.

Muster and ambush hexes bring a dynamic mechanism to the map, a dark and light option that enhances the narrative of the game. They can bring new hope to a push for a fort or add to the overwhelming armies of the Dark Force.

-description from designer
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Print & Play, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Roll / Spin and Move, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Spelunk or Dunk
description:
In Spelunk or Dunk players are racing against rising waters to get out of the cave with the most gems.

The water rises faster and faster each round and carrying those valuable gems is going to slow you down.

Players all start out by creating their working hand of cards to use throughout the game. Each round all players play 1 card and then figure out how far they get to move towards daylight.

Some cards are better if more people play the same card and others are better if you are the only one. Elements of the prisoners dilemma and push your luck make for a tense game with lots of player interaction and laughs.

—description from the publisher
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Negotiation, Party Game
mechanics: Deck Construction, Negotiation, Open Drafting, Pick-up and Deliver, Prisoner's Dilemma, Push Your Luck, Semi-Cooperative Game

name: Name That Review
description:
Name That Review is the fun party game where multiple personalities and judging others is encouraged!

In Name That Review, you take turns being the 'Buyer' and are looking up product reviews to help you decide if you should buy a product or not. All other players that round play as the 'Reviewers'. A Persona Card is drawn to determine which perspective the reviews are given from - this could be anything from a Helicopter Mom to a Hippie. A product card is drawn, not being shown to the buyer. A star coin is flipped to determine if it's a 1-star or 5-star review. The Reviewers then has 2 minutes to write a review. After the time is up, everyone reads their review, doing their best impersonation of the Persona Card. The Buyer tries to guess what the product is. If correct, the Buyer Scores a star point. The Buyer then chooses the "Most Helpful Review" and gives a star point to their favorite written review and chooses the "Best Impersonation" and gives a star point to the best impersonation of the Persona Card. The game ends after everyone's had a chance to be the Buyer once. The winner is the player with the most points at the end of the game.

What if there's a tie? In the case of the tie, the players in a tie have a SUDDEN DEATH round, where they battle directly against each other. The players in a tie each take a unique product card, careful not to show anyone else. They flip over a Persona Card for everyone to see. They then write and act the review out. All other players play as a Buyers, and will use their own star points to reward the overall performance of who they think did the best.
mechanics: Player Judge

name: Papyrus The Game
description:
Ancient Egypt, 2,512 BC, a group of Apprentice Priests discovers a scroll bearing some indications written by the Supreme Priest about the search for the ancient hieroglyphs of the Gods: whoever finds more of them shall take his place next to the Pharaoh. It is now time to undertake a journey to retrieve them. Will you be able to do it before anyone else?

RULE BOOK

Components
- 1 Ancient Egypt board game
- 150 coloured pyramids (30 each in Red, Blue, Yellow,
Green, Black)
- 186 Illustrated cards:
- 110 movement cards (24 for each symbol: Light, Dark,
Nature and Water + 14 "Eye of Horus")
- 36 Gods Cards
- 40 Event cards
- 1 bag for hieroglyphics
- 300 hieroglyphs
- 75 beetle tokens (15 for each player)
- 5 Player scrolls
- 5 hieroglyphics holders (1 for each player)
- 5 pawns (1 for each player)
- 5 scorekeepers (1 for each player)
- 1 rule book.

PREPARATION OF THE GAME
Place the board in the middle of the table.
Each player chooses a color. Each player is given 30 Pyramids, 1 pawn, 1 scorekeepers of the chosen colour, 1 player scroll, 15 scarab tokens and 1 hieroglyphic holder.
Each player places his marker token on the Start square of the marker, and places his pawn on the Pyramid of Hours square; it will be the starting square for all players.
Before you start the game, distribute it to each player:
- 4 movement cards
- 3 Gods cards
- 10 hieroglyphs
Now place the Movement card deck, the Gods card deck, the Event card deck and the hieroglyphics bag next to the board.
You are now ready to begin.

OBJECTIVE OF THE GAME
The aim of the game is to get the highest number of points. You earn points when you reach on the board the pyramid corresponding to the God card in your hand and you have previously formed the name of the corresponding God with hieroglyphics. (Example: the God Card HORUS is formed by the hieroglyphics corresponding to the letters H , O, R, U, and S. If you reach the "Pyramid of Horus" box on the board and you have the necessary hieroglyphics [see the conversion of letters into hieroglyphics on your player's scroll], you will have conquered the HORUS Card and you will be able to advance on the scoreboards with the value of the Card: in this case Horus is formed by 6 letters and therefore worth 6 points.


TURN OF GAME
The older player starts first. The game then proceeds clockwise. Each player in his turn can make 1 of these moves (only one):

- draw 2 movement cards;

- move on the map - The player can move on the board using the movement cards. Each movement card corresponds to the 4 colors on the map and the player must use the exact color and quantity indicated on the boxes to move on the board. (Example: the pyramid of Horus and Anubis are connected by 4 blue "water" squares + 2 yellow "light" squares; then the player must play 4 water movement cards + 2 light movement cards, for a total of 6 cards).
- If the player reaches the pyramid of the God card in his possession and has previously formed his name with hieroglyphics, he can put his coloured pyramid on top of the pyramid square. He then moves the scorekeepers along the number-marker corresponding to the value of the card, places a scarab token on his player's scroll. Finally, he discards the newly conquered God Card and can draw a new one. The hieroglyphs he used to form the name must be discarded, and the player may draw the hieroglyphs from the bag of the same number as the newly discarded ones.
- If the player reaches any pyramid on the map without having the right to conquer it, nothing happens and his turn ends.
- If the player reaches the Event square, draw 1 Event card.

- Draw 1 hieroglyph from the bag, but first he must pay by placing an uncovered hieroglyph in front of the bag. (or the player can choose 1 hieroglyph from those already uncovered, always paying with his own hieroglyph).

END OF THE GAME
When the Gods card deck is finished and one of the players wins his last God card, the final round begins for all players (except for the same player who has already finished the game).
After the final round, the game ends and the players move on to calculating their final score.

SCORING
Players should have already marked on the scoreboard the points earned by winning each God card. Each player must then add 5 points for each scarab token they have previously deposited on their personal scroll.
In addition, the player who has conquered more than 2 or more "sons of Horus" has bonus points:
2 sons of Horus: 5 bonus points
3 sons of Horus: 8 bonus points
All 4 sons of Horus: 10 bonus points
The player with the most points wins the game. If two or more players have the same number of points, the player who has won the most sons of Horus wins the game. In the unlikely event that they are still in a draw, the player who has won the "Amon-Ra" card wins.

1-PLAYER-VARIANT:
In the 1-player variant, the Gods Cards, the hieroglyphics, the scarab tokens, the player scroll and the movement cards are required.
The player at the beginning of the game has 3 Gods cards and must form his name with hieroglyphics in order to win the card. To buy a hieroglyph you must use an element card without distinction (in the normal version they are called movement cards).
Once the name is formed, the corresponding God card will be discarded and another card can be drawn. For each God card won you need to apply a scarab token to your Player scroll.
The game ends when the Gods card deck ends (you can decide at the beginning of the game if you prefer to play with fewer Gods cards).
Calculation of points and winnings: After you have formed the name of the last God of the deck, proceed with the calculation of the score (5 points for each scarab token + the specific points of each God card).
If the totalized score is higher than the number of the element cards paid, you win the game, otherwise you lose.
You can also play this variant with more players!
mechanics: Advantage Token, End Game Bonuses, Track Movement

name: Threat Level: Tube Strike
description:
This is a 2d6 narrative solo wargame based on the modern (2010 - Present) British Police forces battle against terror.

You play as the police force as they battle terrorists in different missions with more missions on the way, the game as an AI system to include members of the public, profiles and terrorists.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Anarcade Deck Building Game: Champion Gold
description:
The arcade was a dark and seedy arena where men could become kings for the price of a quarter. Now is your chance! Run the high score table and rule the arcade!

Anarcade is a deck building race to ace 3 arcade games before your opponents. Players play starter cards to buy better cards from the center stacks. Card actions allow players to buy better cards from the center, draw more cards for actions, earn Coins (used for buying or Scoring), or Score on the Games. The first player to fill up the High Score table wins that objective and the winner is the first player to win 3 objectives.

Choose a strategy, buy the right cards and own the arcade one game at a time!

-description from designer
mechanics: Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Monkey The Card Game: Spell-o-rama Expansion
description:
The crazy wizard Kurgill is back and he's got a whole new medley of spells in store for you. Outwit him if you can!

This expansion adds 22 new spell cards to the original game. Banana Ka-blama, Bear Trap, Vines, Hook, Mask, Spectacular Sheild of Mind-boggling Shininess, Python, Crystal Ball, Treasure Chest, Poison Dart Frog, Gems and Mushrooms!
categories: Animals, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Taumant's Lair
description:
Taumant's Lair is a dice game for a single player with a duration of approximately 20 minutes. To play you need six six-sided dice, each not exceeding 0.5 inches, about eight pawns, and a dozen counters or tokens. If you do not have any pawns nor counters.
The game is divided into three different parts, each corresponding to three pages, which you will use as game boards. Print each one on a different sheet of cardboard and follow their instructions.

Part I: Recruiting Adventurers
The first step to penetrate Taumant's lair is to form a party capable of surviving its many hazards. Luckily, you are near to the city-state of Kalazar, located between two kingdoms at war. It makes Kalazar the perfect place to look for adventurers. You must explore the city and try to recruit people prepared to risk their lives.

Part II: The Dungeon
It's the time! Your party is about to get into the cavern. Your goal is to get through its six levels with as few losses as possible. You will play six turns, each corresponding one level of the cave. Put the pawns representing your adventurers on the appropriate square of the column 'ready' and another one on the first level of the dungeon. If you beat the sixth level, you will face Taumant in Part III with your surviving adventurers!

Part III: Taumant!
You have arrived at Taumant's chamber. This will be a tough fight! As soon as he meets the adventurers, he prepares himself to reduce his enemies to ashes with his deadly fire breath. You have only three turns before he buries your party in a hell of flames. Every unwounded adventurer has a roll for every turn. Put this sheet 12 inches from you and roll a die towards the dragon; if it stops on him, you will cause damage points depending on its location. If you cause 50 or more damage points, you win! Otherwise, you can return to Part I and try again.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling

name: TRIAMAND
description:
TRIAMAND. Somewhere in a remote desert, an ancient tomb has been disturbed. An evil spirit has woken and is threatening to the whole world with an act of revenge.
You as a player need to save the world. The world counts on you! You must put bricks back on a tomb. Do it first, and you are the winner!!!
Game is played by 2 – 6 people, ages 7+. At the start, each player is given 5 playing cards, for which can be acquired bricks from the Brickbank. The bricks have different shapes and correspond to the color of the card. Amount paid for each brick can be the same as the price or higher. If brick is bought for its stated nominal value, a player can make an additional move. If paid by the nominal, it can be bought as many bricks as laying on the Brickbank (not from the treasury storage). After the player’s turn is over, every time empty brick spots on the Brickbank must be covered by new bricks.
First move on the game is given to the player with highest value card. If several players have similar highest cards, they are comparing their next highest cards until someone has an upper hand.
On players turn, can be made one of the following:
- Card drawn from the stock
- Brick bought from the Brickbank
- Brick removed /replaced. * if a row is completed, no brick can be removed or replaced.
Seems too easy? Not so fast, my friend. Competition is quite hard, and players need to come up with some strategy in order to succeed. Here are some hurdles:
- Although some bricks stretch up to the next rows, which is acceptable, player cannot build next row without completely bricklaying preceding one.
- You have laid almost all bricks and now have stuck for some particular piece: don’t have necessary currency to buy this exact brick? Think strategy again: maybe you don’t need to cover up row too fast before you acquire necessary resources from the Brickbank. You need to be good at reading patterns.
- First move always starts from the left bottom corner marked with red. Next moves can be done freely, but within the same row until it is filled and ready to move to the upper one.
Good luck!!!
Notice: Game is claimed strategic, and it truly is. In order to win, players must plan their movements in advance. The higher up the pyramid player climbs, the fewer choices one has and has to be very careful. Game is well suitable for school children to develop strategic thinking, to learn better geometrical shapes, and learn to count. Game is fun for adults also and is not burdening with the time required- just about 30 minutes to play one round. Quite addictive: lost players want a replay to get the satisfaction.

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Math, Party Game, Territory Building
mechanics: Grid Coverage, Grid Movement, Layering, Network and Route Building, Open Drafting, Tile Placement

name: Quarantine
description:
Quarantine is a cooperative board game where players are quarantined at home, fending off a virus, conserving their food and trying to find a cure.

Each player takes on the role of a family member, who all have different character traits for how much they can move and carry, which are all useful to be successful in the game. They must keep socially distanced from one another (two spaces) while moving around the house, avoiding the virus tokens which replicate as the game progresses, and collecting the item tokens needed to make a cure. Each player can carry 10 food tokens (25 for Granny) and these are exchanged for movement and can be restocked from the kitchen but the supply is limited so be careful, if the food supply runs out or someone catches the virus the game is over.

Each turn consists of movement and/or an action (restock food, disinfect spaces, mix cure items or knock down walls to escape the virus). Movement is dictated by the number of food a player wishes and each player has a number of spaces that their character is permitted to move per food.

After each turn players draw a card from the research deck, this identifies either a new item or new virus in the house or gives the player a powerup to use later (extra moves, search the deck, haz-mat suit for temporary virus immunity). Following a round (one go for each player) all the viruses on the board are moved one space closer to the nearest player. Most viruses appear outside the house and need to break in, giving players time to prepare, but occasionally new viruses appear inside the house and urgent disinfection is required.

The mechanic for placing viruses involves a D12, with two faces for internal placement and 10 for external. New items from the research deck are placed with a D20 (room selection) and a D6 (space selection). Dice are not involved in player movement or decision outcomes.

The game ends when either a player runs out of food, a player succumbs to the virus or the parts of the cure are mixed and the cure is completed.
mechanics: Cooperative Game

name: Asking For A Friend
description:
"Asking for a Friend: The party game that might get weird" is a party game where all players are both asking and answering a question each round. The official goal is to collect the most points over ten rounds of play. The real goal is to finally have an excuse to ask your friend's the questions you've never asked before.

At the start of a round, a question card is drawn that has a blank. (e.g. "How often do you _____?"). Each player writes a prompt on a piece of paper that fills in the blank to make a complete question (e.g. "wake up before your alarm", "cry", or "fart and blame it on someone else"). All the prompts get shuffled, and each player draws a prompt. Each player answers the prompt they drew (which is sometimes the one they wrote). After everyone has answered, a voting card is revealed and the players vote for the winning answer based on the criteria on the voting card. (One round the voting might be based on which answer is "Most likely to disappoint your parents" and the next round might be based on who gave the "Most wholesome answer"). The winning answer gets the voting card, which is worth a point. However, great answers are made in response to great questions. The author of the prompt that spurred the winning answer will receive a reward card. Then a new round begins.

If you don't want to answer a question, you can take a penalty card, but you might have to answer more questions later. Reward cards can do anything from telling someone else to get you a drink to letting you pick who answers which questions. Use your reward cards wisely, but don't forget to use them.

The game is concluded after 10 Question Cards/rounds have been completed (or really, however many you want to play!) The player with the most victory points is the winner.

The cards are minimalist and each deck has it's own color (white, black, and orange). There is nothing inherently dirty about this game, but you can make it very adult/mature if you'd like. You also could play with kids and grandparents at a family reunion and ask family friendly questions. The maturity level of the game depends on the prompts that are written.
mechanics: Paper-and-Pencil, Player Judge, Storytelling, Voting

name: Biplane Barmy: Refuelled Edition
description:
Biplane Barmy Refuelled is the long awaited second edition of Biplane Barmy, the game of World War I fighter combat.

It uses the same core "choose & move" system but is the first choose and move game based on a hexagonal map.

Players control one or more planes each and secretly choose maneuvers each turn, then move all planes simultaneously and resolve firing.

The game is fast and furious, typically playable in around 15 minutes, making it ideal to fill on round a roleplaying session or as a tournament game.

The game uses simple mechanics for fast play, but doesn't sacrifice detail with stats for a wide range of aircraft and rules to handle all manner of specifics, from bombing to garros wedges.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Print & Play, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Simulation

name: What If, But Also
description:
What If, But Also is a lighthearted party game in which 4 or more players compete to spin stories out of chaos and pull creative pitches out of wacky prompts — all to win the judge’s favor.

Each round, players come up with the best possible or worst possible scenario, based on the cards in play and in their hands. Scenarios are inspired by (however loosely players want), and must reference, a phrase created by 5 cards: 2 Link Cards and 3 Story Cards. These cards change between rounds.

Each turn, one player takes on the role of judge and all other players take on the role of storytellers. The judge determines whether they want to hear the best or worst possible scenario and indicate by flipping the "What If…" card to its positive or negative side. They draw the top two cards of the Link deck and play them face up. They then play a Story card from their own hand to begin the scenario. Storytellers play Story cards from their hands to supply options for 2 of the words in the phrase. These 2 words are different for each storyteller, meaning they’ll base their scenarios off slightly different phrases.

At the end of the turn, roles shift. The player to the left of the previous judge becomes the new judge. Each turn consists of three phases: judge’s setup, storyteller’s scenarios, and judge’s choice. Play continues until every player has had a chance to be judge twice — or keep going as long as you want! The game can be ended after any judge’s choice phase.

—description from the publisher
categories: Party Game, Print & Play, Word Game
mechanics: Communication Limits, Player Judge, Storytelling, Voting

name: Wieczna Waśń
description:
Wieczna Waśń ("Eternal Feud") is a strategic board game from 2 to 4 people / 8 + / 60-120 depending on the map of the land, in which 4 feuded races fight for dominance in a randomly created land.

No one remembers how the feud began, who came to the field or who first chewed on the stone ... the fact is that this feud seems to have always happened. People against the green horde of orcs from the north ... until one day the conflict joined the fallen, a great army of the dead rose up and went to war with the living ... in this eternal feud.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Team-Based Game, Tile Placement, Worker Placement with Dice Workers

name: The Once and Future Cuisine
description:
It’s the Time Tyrant’s wedding and they’ve called on you to whip up the feast! The Tyrant knows a chef is only
as good as their ingredients and has loaned you a time machine to let you leap through the ages and collect delicacies that will truly wow the guests.

Each round has three phases: 1) travel in time, 2) claim ingredients, 3) cleanup. Starting with the first player and proceeding clockwise, each player on their turn places a pawn on an era board, representing their claim on an ingredient from that era. Then, after everyone has placed their pawns, all chefs collect their ingredients, and the era boards are refilled.

Chefs are looking to show off their skills by featuring either a course of the same dish type (drink, appetizer, entree, or dessert) but of different eras known as a "Dish Set", or showcase the foods of one era known as an "Era Set".

The game ends immediately when either of the following happens during the “refill” step of the round’s Cleanup phase: either 3 or more era boards have all their cuisine spots filled with cards from eras other than their own (Paradoxes Aplenty), or it is not possible to fill all the cuisine spots on 1 or more era boards (Continuity Error). The chef with the tastiest tableau is the winner.

-description from publisher
mechanics: Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: REACTOR
description:
Join the global community and manage your resources as you build your nation’s Economy, Global Engagement, Military, Human Progress, and Satisfaction. Can you lead your country to an age of happiness and prosperity?

REACTOR is a light, quick playing civilization building strategy game commissioned by NSquare and designed for use in the classroom to create teachable moments highlighting the dangers of nuclear weapons.

Gameplay
Each turn consists of 3 phases in this order: Infrastructure, Action, and Aftermath

Infrastructure Phase
Starting with the first player, everyone chooses one category to raise up 2 levels.

Action Phase
Each player secretly chooses which action they will take by playing the corresponding card face down in front of themselves. There are 5 possible actions. Economic Progress: Add resources to any category. Global Responsibility: Create an alliance and/or generate resources. Human Achievement: Add resources to your lowest category. Satisfaction: Convert military resources to any other category and get bonus resources. Military: Invade or Nuke another nation. All actions are explained in greater detail below.

Once all players have locked in a choice, the cards are revealed, and the actions are resolved starting with the first player.

Aftermath Phase
Players with an active alliance automatically produce additional resources which can be placed anywhere. Allied players receive 1 resource per alliance at level 2, 2 resources per alliance at level 5, and 3 resources per alliance at level 10.

Then the first player marker is moved clockwise from the current first player and a new round begins.

End

At the end of the game, any nations with a total score of 30 or more points from all categories, except Military, (or with a Satisfaction level of 8+ and total score of 25 or more points) are considered winners unless all remaining nations have winning totals in which case the player with the lowest Satisfaction score loses. If players have a tie for lowest Satisfaction score then break that tie with their point total from the other three categories.

If all nations have been Nuked, then everyone loses.

If only 1 Nation remains, that nation is technically “the winner” but they are now the sole survivors of a nuclear wasteland.

Among younger demographics, the nuclear issue is abstract and distant—a problem of previous generations. There are more resonant issues like social injustice, global warming, or economy disparity that, while still daunting, are far more comprehensible and consequential.
Reactor, engages high school students in the classroom about the nuclear weapons threat by connecting this issue to more visible social matters through an interactive and accessible medium. By breaking down the complexity of this problem with play, students cultivate a sense of understanding that drives engagement, helping foster new generations that feel empowered and responsible to take action.

About NSquare:
In 2014, five of the largest peace and security funders in the United States joined forces to develop a new, collective approach to incentivizing and rewarding innovation in the nuclear threat field. What emerged was N Square, a path-breaking initiative built on the idea that new forms of cross-sector collaboration—combined with the sheer ingenuity of an engaged public­—will accelerate the achievement of internationally agreed goals to reduce nuclear dangers.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Negotiation, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Wild West Circus
description:
Wild West Circus - it is one of the kind role-playing immersive game using large sclae miniatures and tableau. An untold story where you will be immersed and forced to make tough decisions to survive and keep the circus intact ;)

Grimtown - it is a little town in Wild West where your circus comes. You think run circus is simple? Think again. Escaped animals, blackmailed by local sheriff, paying for “protection” is just a start. Native Americans are not happy with the way you go around towns – prepare to fight them off. Successful? Great, since now you have to solve love triangle. Finally you get a secret note that there might be buried treasure in town. Will you pursue the hint or is this just a prank to keep you from things that are really important? Maybe making moonshine will be more profitable in times of “dry” season? ? Brace yourself into an adventure of your lifetime!

To play this game you will need a smart phone – so you could hear all whispers and rumors. Without your “street” knowledge it will be nearly impossible to solve mysteries and get on the good side with town’s people.

You and your fellow "managers" will have to work hand in hand in order to achieve the best result possible. The better and more thoughtful your decision are the better score you will achieve. Compare these numbers in the app with other players and see who will be the best at running Circus In the old West.

—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, American West, Miniatures, Negotiation, Puzzle, Real-time, Word Game
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Grid Coverage, Role Playing

name: Tower Enforcer
description:
Take the role of a Dungeon Hunter with unique stats and abilities. Battle Towers of increasingly difficult monsters. Work your way up to the Tower Boss and claim the Legendary Items to help you defeat all 7 Towers to gain ultimate victory.

Use your selected Dungeon Hunter and Battle the Tower of your choosing with the Battle Deck. The battle deck consists of Attack Cards and Defense cards. These cards are added to your Dungeon Hunters Corresponding Base Stats. After drawing 5 battle cards the battle begins. Select one of the 7 Towers to Battle.

Play the battle card of your choice down within the energy requirements. A card can only be played if you have the energy equal to the card value. Energy is spent when you play an Attack card. Energy can be gained by playing defense card. If you receive damage when playing a defense card that damage is also dealt to your energy.

Your overall attack towards the monster is your base attack stat plus the attack card you have played. Same for your defense, it is the defense card and your Base Defense stat added together. If your overall attack is higher than the monsters overall attack damage is dealt to the monster. But if the monster has a higher attacking card the damage is dealt to your Dungeon Hunters Health Points. Once the monster's health is brought down to 0 the tower shifts down and you battle the next monster.

Every two monsters beaten the Tower rewards you with a random item that can help you defeat the Tower easier. But while the Tower can help you every 5 turns the Tower throws an Event at you. Events can be good helping you gain health, items or even boost your stats. But just as good as they can be they can also be bad. Removing items, losing health, or even doubling the Monsters stats.

Only after defeating all the monsters and the Tower Boss can you gain a Legendary item to help you Battle other towers. Defeating all 7 Tower will grant you victory!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Events

name: Wagram 1809: Formation Command #1
description:
Wagram 1809 is the first in a series of games designed to place an emphasis upon command at the individual formation level. Formations will be Corps in this game.

The Formation Command system requires both players to make a series of difficult battlefield decisions, usually with insufficient resources available.
This gets achieved through a unique Command system using Formation cards which will retain information about Cohesion (which affects Morale), Commands given and the readiness of Formations to fulfill actions required.
If the wrong Commands are issued at the start of the turn, the player will not be able to 'change course' during the turn, but will have to live with the consequences.

This will keep the map as clean and uncluttered as possible, because a lot of the action is going on ‘off board’. There will only be, at most, three counters per hex (excluding Leader)– maximum of 2 units plus a morale status marker.

The activation sequence of formations will be determined by a chit draw mechanic, although players are able to make choices about which exact formation to activate in most cases.

This, and the possibility for the passive player to conduct a range of five different reaction actions, lets both players be actively involved at all times.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Winner Winner Chicken Dinner: Tantrum Coop Promo Card
description:
Promo originally released for the Tantrum House Season 7 Kickstarter.

Add the Tantrum Coop to your action card deck.

When purchased, the player may hold onto the card to play on their turn at a later round (or they may choose to play it immediately). The chicken bags from all players are collected, mixed up, then redistributed back to all players. This does not impact cooked chickens.

-description from publisher
categories: Animals, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Humor
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Winner Winner Chicken Dinner: Toby the Dog Promo Card
description:
Add this promo card to your action card deck.

When purchased, the player may hold onto the card to play on their turn at a later round (or they may choose to play it immediately).

When played, all other players must return 3 chickens from their bag to the coop. If they don't have 3 chickens, they must return all that they do have in their bag. This does not impact cooked chickens.

-description from publisher
categories: Animals, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Humor
mechanics: Unspecified

name: 5150: Send Lawyers Guns and Money
description:
Send Lawyers, Guns and Money is playable with 5150: No Limits and the rest of our 5150 RPG titles. This book centers on New Hope City and the life of a Mercenary, or if you wish, a Jack of All Trades. Inside you’ll find:

Our Basic 5150 rules to play it as a stand-alone game.
35 Color Counters for your games.
Two Battle Boards to use your Counters on. Getting you right into the game!
A variety of Basic Encounters (Scenarios).
16 Encounters linked to form two different Stories.
An introduction to Cyndee.
A low bookkeeping Campaign to tie your Adventures together.
A variety of Races, Professions and Attributes to play.
An easy to learn, but challenging combat system with deadly results.
All this and more

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Role Playing

name: He Hemetera Thalassa, Mare Nostrum
description:
He Hemetera Thalassa, Mare Nostrum
A quick playing set of fleet action level Ancient naval rules covering the period 2000BC to 900AD, allowing large scale battles such as Salamis, Actium and the battles of the Peloponnesian and Punic Wars to be completed in a couple of hours or less.

They have been written with 1/2400 scale models based in groups or stands, with each stand representing 5 to 10 ships. A range of suitable 3D models are available for free download to accompany the rules.

Bookkeeping is minimal, using simple markers to indicate ship damage and crew casualties.

Data for over 30 different broad ship types and nine different fleet lists are included, from the Egyptians and Sea Peoples, through classical Greek and Roman to fleets and ships.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Simulation

name: Blood Red Skies: British Ace Pilot – Pierre Closterman
description:
This expansion includes ace pilot Pierre Clostermann.

He was a French flying Ace and joined the Free French Air Force in the United Kingdom in March 1942. After training at RAF Cranwell and 61 OTU, Clostermann, a sergeant pilot, was posted in January 1943 to No. 341 Squadron RAF (aka Groupe de Chasse n° 3/2 "Alsace"), flying the Supermarine Spitfire.

Throughout the war he became very well decorated and scored 33 recorded victories (19 solo, 14 shared, most of them against fighters) and five "probables", with eight more "damaged".
He also claimed 225 motor vehicles destroyed, 72 locomotives, five tanks, and two E-boats (fast torpedo boats).
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: Johnny Red's Falcon Squadron
description:
Johnny Red was Battle's longest-running series over 13 years, written by Tom Tully and drawn initially by Joe Colquhoun, later by John Cooper and finally by Carlos Pino, (and more recently by Garth Ennis) about a British fighter pilot Johnny "Red" Redburn flying for the Russians in a 'stolen' Hawker Hurricane fighter.

Falcon Squadron features a new card that will make playing against them a potentially difficult challenge!
The General Secretary often took a direct interest in aircraft production.
You play the 'Telegram from Stalin' card during deployment, allowing VVS planes in one designated squadron to disregard the Poor Quality trait in this battle.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: German Ace Pilot – Otto Kittel
description:
Otto Kittel flew first in Yugoslavia and then on the Eastern Front from June 1941 at the very outset of Operation Barbarossa.

He claimed his 100th aerial victory in September of 1943, his 150th in April of 1944 and his 200th in August the same year.

He was shot down and killed in action in February 1945 over the Courland Pocket, his final tally 267 victories over 583 combat missions.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: Soviet Ace Pilot – Lev 'Sokol' Shestakov
description:
Shestakov graduated from military college in 1936 and immediately applied for service in Spain, joining a Republican fighter squadron, where he claimed eight solo victories and 31 shared victories in 90 sorties in his I-16.

At the start of Operation Barbarossa, Shestakov found himself on the Odessa front, where his regiment mauled the German and Romanian opposition, scoring 96 victories between all the pilots.

Towards the end of the war, Shestakov converted over to the LaGG-3 which he flew until his death in 1944 - reportedly fighting his own private war with Stuka Ace Hans-Erich Rudel.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: US Ace Pilot – 'Tex' Hill
description:
"Tex" Hill was born in Gwangju, Korea whilst under Japanese rule but was raised in Texas. Graduating from Austin College in 1938, he entered service as a United States Naval Aviator, earning his wings as a TBD Devastator torpedo bomber pilot aboard the USS Saratoga. He also joined a Vought SB2U Vindicator Dive Bomber Squadron aboard USS Ranger. IN 1941 he was recruited to the 1st American Volunteer Group, training on the P-40 Warhawk in Burma.

Hill made his first kills on January 3rd 1942, shooting down two Japanese Nates over Thailand. 2 more followed on the 23rd and he became an ace the next day with two more kills. He thus became a squadron leader in March of that year, and by the time of the squadron's disbanding in the summer, he was a double ace, with 12 1/4 aerial victories on his record.

Hill was one of only 5 of the "Flying Tigers" to join the successor group, the 23rd Fighter Group, having a rank of major at this time, earning 5 more victories in the cockpit of a P-51. He returned home in 1944 and took command of the 412th Fighter Group, the first operational American jet fighter group (flying the P-59 Airacomet and P-80 Shooting Star). He went on to serve in the Korean War with the Texas Air National Guard. He retired as a brigadier general, has earned a plethora of merits and medals throughout his career.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: German Ace Pilot – Walter Nowotny
description:
Walter Nowotny (7 December 1920 – 8 November 1944) was an Austrian-born fighter ace of the Luftwaffe. Credited with 258 aerial victories over 442 combat missions. He achieved 255 of these victories over the Eastern Front whilst flying predominantly the Focke-Wulf Fw 190 but also the Messerschmitt BF109. He scored an "ace in a day" on several occasions - five enemy aircraft shot down in a single day. There were even two occurrences of "double-ace in a day" - 10 kills in a day. His final three kills were in the Messerschmitt Me 262.

Nowotny joined the Luftwaffe in 1939, completing his fighter pilot training in 1941. He was posted to Jagdgeschwader 54 "Grünherz" (JG 54) on the Eastern Front. Here, Nowotny was the first pilot to achieve 250 victories – 194 of them over 1943 earning several decorations. He was then prevented from flying for several months for propaganda reasons but was reinstated to front-line service in September 1944.

Nowotny tested and developed the 262 jet fighter as commander of a specialist unit named Kommando Nowotny. The unit had to grapple with the continuing development of the aircraft as well as creating new aerial tactics suitable for a jet aircraft. Nowotny's first kill in the 262 was a B-24 Liberator bomber on 7 October 1944.

On the 8th November, Nowotny engaged a large enemy bomber force singlehandedly, after a problem with his turbines prevented him from taking off with other aircraft. He reported over radio downing a B-24 Liberator and a P-51 Mustang before radioing with his final words - either "I'm on fire" or "it's on fire". It is not known whether he was shot down or suffered engine failure. In the wake of his death, the first operational jet fighter wing was named in his honour.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Simulation

name: Tlaczani
description:
The Ancient Royal Game of Ur with a new twist!

In ancient civilizations, people competed in different sports and games to prove their worthiness to their gods.

In Tlaczani you choose between the bravest Texotli (blue) or the fearsome Chiltik (Red) to start the run to see who's worthy of the favor of the god Macuilxochilt (5 flowers).

TLACZANI is the ancient ROyal Game of Ur with a twist!
Do you think you have the luck on your side?
Are you under Macuilxochilt favor?
Prove it!

Game contents: 3 board/cards, 26 run pieces (7 red, 7 blue, 6 green and 6 yellow) and 4 four sided dices.

-box bottom info

The word Tlaczani comes from the Nahualt language and it means "it that runs". In this game you will find some similarities with 2 ancient games; first the board is similar to the one used in the Royal Game of Ur, the oldest board game known with nearly 5,000 years old and Patolli (little red bean in Nahualt), a game played by the Teotihuacans, the Toltecs, the Mayans and the Aztecs. In this new twist of The Royal Game of Ur you will have an interesting mixture of the essential running mechanic of Ur and resource gain/exchange. Inside the box you will have all you need to play Tlaczani and other versions and interpretations of The Royal Game of Ur.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Trading

name: Blood Red Skies: Japanese Ace Pilot – Kaneyoshi Muto
description:
Kaneyoshi Muto earned his first air victory on 4 December 1937 during the Battle of Nanking when he shot down a Soviet-made Polikarpov I-16. He would go on to fight alongside Saburō Sakai on the island of Iwo Jima, surviving to be called by Sakai “the toughest fighter pilot in the Imperial Navy.”

In December 1944, Muto was posted to the Japanese Home Islands to join Captain Minoru Genda in his elite 343rd Kōkūtai. By June he was posted to the 343rd Air Group, 301st Squadron commanded by veteran ace Naoshi Kanno.

On 24 July 1945, over the Bungo Channel, Muto and other veteran pilots scrambled to attack a larger group of American fighters. Greatly outnumbered, Muto was shot down and never seen again.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: British Ace Pilot – 'Pick' Pickard
description:
Percy Charles ‘Pick’ Pickard flew a variety of aircraft during the war, from the Wellington bomber, through the Westland Lysander to the Mosquito, with which he appears in this Aces box.

He had a reputation for being calm under fire and always focusing on the mission objective.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: US Ace Pilot – 'Pappy' Boyington
description:
Major Gregory “Pappy” Boyington (Medal of Honor, Navy Cross) learnt his deadly trade during a year’s tour in China as a member of the 1st American Volunteer Group (The Flying Tigers).
Upon returning to the US, In 1943, he was charged to take a group of twenty-seven young men and form the new Marine Attack Squadron 214.

VMA214 (Black Sheep) would earn its reputation and the Presidential Unit Citation for extraordinary heroism in action under Pappy's command; fighting for 84 days achieving a record 203 Japanese planes destroyed or damaged, produced nine fighter aces with 97 confirmed air-to-air kills (22 by Boyington), several troop transports and supply ships sunk, destroyed many installations, in addition to numerous other victories.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: Soviet Ace Pilot – Alexandr Pokryshkin
description:
Pokryshkin was a three-time recipient of the Hero of the Soviet Union decoration during wartime - for his exceptional air combat record of 53 solo kills and 6 shared ones (though these tallies are disputed nowadays).

He was airborne on the first day of Operation Barbarossa, shooting down a Bf109 after being jumped on a recon mission, and would continue flying for the duration of the war, inventing new air combat tactics and stoking the USSR's propaganda mill.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Lasgidi Rats
description:
A great famine has descended upon the rat kingdom. Many rats are starving and many more have passed to the great beyond. But all hope is not lost. There is a prophecy of a guardian that will lead the survivals to a great city filled with food – the LASGIDI city.

The surviving rats must ﬁnd their way to homes of Lasgidians (humans of Lasgidi). As the Guardian, you must lead the last survivors through underground tunnels to the holes in the houses across the city. This is your mission, lead the ﬁrst batch of the rats safely to the yam store and gather your path points. Beware of the dangers you may encounter.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Tile Placement

name: Blood Red Skies: Soviet Ace Pilot – Vladimir Pokrovsky
description:
Vladimir Pokrovsky began flying I-16s in the Northern Fleet's 72nd Mixed Aviation Squadron, flying over the Murmansk Front during the early period of the war.

Like many pilots, he switched aircraft many times, from Hurricanes to Kittyhawks, Airacobras and Yak-1bs.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: US Ace Pilot – Philip Kirkwood
description:
Lieutenant, Junior Grade Philip Leroy Kirkwood was awarded the Navy Cross for extraordinary heroism in operations against the enemy.

Flying the F4U Corsair with the Grim Reapers (VF-10) from the USS Intrepid (CV-11) Kirkwood took part in strikes against the Ryukyu Islands, Kyūshū, Okinawa and Wake Island, downing 8 enemy aircraft bringing his tally to 12.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: German Ace Pilot – Hans Dortenmann
description:
Hans Dortenmann was a Luftwaffe ace who, after his completion of aerial training, starting serving on the Eastern Front where he scored his first victory.

Shortly after, he was transferred to the Western Front where he claimed many more victories against the Allied forces. He continued to serve until the end of the war.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: Focke Wulf Fw 190D 'Dora' Squadron
description:
The Fw 190 Dora was a single-seat, single-engined fighter aircraft. Alongside the Messerschmitt Bf 109, it became the backbone of the Luftwaffe.

It fulfilled a variety of roles including; day fighter, fighter-bomber, ground-attack aircraft and, to an extent, night fighter.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Blood Red Skies: Supermarine Spitfire Mk IX squadron
description:
Created out of the need to update the Spitfire VB which was being hilariously outperformed by the Focke-Wulf Fw 190.

The new Spitfire Mk IX was leaps and bounds above its predecessors in terms of aviation and combat abilities.

—description from the publisher
categories: Aviation / Flight, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Godzilla Rampage: Kaiju Unleashed – The Heroic Ultraman Supplement
description:
Expansion #2 for Godzilla Rampage: Kaiju Unleashed Board Game.

Includes 3 new game boards, 2 new Kaiju assist characters and 1 new Kaiju battle card. In addition to the new game boards, they will have exciting new added features.
Also included in this Expansion are Version 5 of the Rules and Assist Character Wound Counter Card that allows players to now play using the Kaiju Assist Characters.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Print & Play
mechanics: Dice Rolling

name: この料理を作ったのは誰だ!? (Who cooked this dish!?)
description:
この料理を作ったのは誰だ!? (Kono Ryōri wo tsukuttanoha dareda!?) (Who cooked this dish!?) is a Japanese deduction game.

"Who cooked this dish!?" is a detective card game where you show off the best dishes and compete for fame in the gourmet world. You are one of Japan's leading gastronomic critics. At this kaiseki gathered by gourmets who devote themselves to esophageal music, let's show off the seasonal gems created by your chef and make many tongues groan.

Your favorite food is a combination of randomly-distributed favorite food chips. Use the food and cooking cards in your hand to guess the favorite foods of other players. Once you get the Taste Onchi Chip, proceed with the game so that you cannot be identified.

「この料理を作ったのは誰だ!?」は至極の料理を披露し合い、グルメ界での名声を競う推理カードゲームです。あなたは日本屈指の美食評論家。食道楽に身を捧げたグルメ 仲間が集うこの会席で、お抱えの料理人が創作する四季折々の 逸品を披露し、多くの舌を「むむっ!!」と唸らせましょう。

ランダムに配られた好物料理チップの組み合わせが、あなたの好物料理。
手札の食材カードと料理カードを使い、他のプレイヤーの好物料理を当てましょう。
味オンチチップを手にしたら、正体を見破られないようにゲームを進めてください。
user summary
mechanics: Memory, Roles with Asymmetric Information, Variable Player Powers, Voting

name: っていうか、ババじゃん。 (BABA the Mahjongish)
description:
っていうか、ババじゃん。 (Tte iu ka, babajan.) (BABA the Mahjongish) is a card game from Japan.

They are all BABA!! It’s just like Mahjong!! An unique tabletop game that... Hilariously Gestaltzerfall! Will the KOBAN drop! Think the cards are the same? A little different? Confusion reigns in this Mahjong-like game! How many times will your eyes fail you!? Laugh as you trade bonus DORAYAKI chips and KOBAN coins AND jibes!
publisher's summary

Players try to build sets of cards with kanji that might say Baba or might say words like Baba. Subtle differences trick players into mistakes.
user summary
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Word Game
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection
publishers: Banana Moon Studio Sapporo (バナナムーン･ステュディオ)

name: どうぶつのおしりCARD (Dobutsu no Oshiri Cards)
description:
どうぶつのおしりCARD (Dobutsu no Oshiri Cards) (Animal Butt Card) is a card game from Japan. You can play classic games like Concentration or Old Maid or Buta no Shippo (Pig’s Tail). Or you can play the original games by the designer. The set allows you to play 7 different games in all.

The game has cute animal cards featuring the various bottoms and rear ends of different creatures. The cards are buttock shaped, with photos of animal bums. Without other markings, you can play a variety of games without having to read.
publisher's summary
mechanics: Hand Management, Memory, Pattern Recognition
publishers: Banana Moon Studio Sapporo (バナナムーン･ステュディオ)

name: Socially Unacceptable
description:
Perfect for game nights, parties, holidays, or any day! If you like other adult type of cards games, you are going to love Socially Unacceptable!
Create your own outrageously funny combination of gestures and impressions to answer life's (not so) important silly questions. Why just read an answer card or pick a picture to fill in the question blank? Take it to the next level!
Act out your answer or do an impression to embarrass your family and friends even more! Adults Only: This game contains adult content and was created for ages 17+. There are some things you can't unseen or unhear! This game has a lot of both!

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Party Game
mechanics: Acting, Player Judge

name: もやしイレブン (Moyashi Eleven)
description:
もやしイレブン (Moyashi Eleven) (Eleven Bean Sprouts) is a dice game from Japan.

Players are staff in food stores. A card deck has customers visiting who want to get bean sprouts. Players roll the dice and supply bean sprouts. Getting the customer orders right without going bust earn points for the players.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Black Wall Street: The Board Game
description:
Black Wall Street: The Board Game is the new fun way for you to increase your Financial Literacy and Black History Knowledge AT THE SAME TIME!

This game was inspired by the real businesses and events from Tulsa, Oklahoma aka Black Wall Street one of the most economically successful communities in American History.

How Do You Play?

Players roll dice to move pieces around the board. As you move you will land on Businesses and have the choice to "Use" the business as a customer or "Buy" the business and become an entrepreneur. Players can reinvest in businesses purchased to create LLCs and Corporations to make more money!

Buy or use Businesses its up to you but if you want to win you better invest!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Income, Ownership, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: アセンブリ・ファイト (Assembly Fight)
description:
アセンブリ・ファイト (Assembly Fight) is a Japanese speed card game.

Played over a total of 8 rounds, players speed program their own software, and then use code reviews to find the mistakes in the other players' code. No coding experience needed.

Players combine 7 instruction cards to complete the program to the number shown on the register board.

Because instructions are only arithmetic operations and substitutions, it can be enjoyed by anyone other than the programmer (not only the code but also the corresponding mathematical formula is written at the bottom of the card)

When you are done, yell out "Commit". The round ends once the commit is declared.

If you can't point out a code review with the remaining players, you get a score.
If there is a mistake in the program, the player who points out the mistake gets the score.

The player with the most points at the end of the 8th round is the winner!

全部で8ラウンドのスピード系プログラミングゲーム

プレイヤーは７枚の命令カードを組み合わせて、レジスタボードに示された数値になるようにプログラムを完成させます。
＊命令は四則演算と代入だけですのでプログラマ以外でも楽しめます（カードの下部にコードだけでなく該当する数式も記載）

完成したら大声で「コミット」と叫びましょう。
コミットが宣言されたら、ラウンドはいったん終了。

残されたプレイヤー達でコードレビューして間違いを指摘できなければ得点をゲット。
もしプログラムにミスがあれば、ミスを指摘したプレイヤーが得点をゲット。

８ラウンド終了時に最も多くポイントを持っていたプレイヤーが勝者です！
publisher's summary
mechanics: Speed Matching, Sudden Death Ending
publishers: Doratanki Co., Ltd. (株式会社ドラタンキ)

name: Escaping World War II
description:
In World War II it was the duty of all Allied prisoners of war (POWs) to try to escape their captors. If the escape was successful they could re-join the war, but even a failed attempt was not without merit, as it would keep many of the enemy busy tracking down escaped prisoners. Once having escaped the camp, the journey home would prove treacherous, and many POWs would lose their lives in the months that followed. Only sheer grit and determination would get them to safety. Hungry and weak from the backbreaking work suffered at the camps, they would need to draw on what little strength remained to pass through enemy terrain and reach neutral territory, to find a way back home.

Each game of Escaping WWII begins with a group of four servicemen who have managed to break free from one of six prisoner of war camps. In the weeks leading up to their escape, they have gathered a few basic supplies, and made a crude map in order to plan their escape. Tired and hungry, they begin the long journey to freedom. Their immediate goal is to reach Paris and hook up with the French Resistance.

With most of Europe under the Nazis control, getting to Paris will not be easy, and with the Nazi military on high alert, eyes are everywhere. Knowing who to trust will be difficult, and with the SS and the Gestapo relentlessly trying to track down escaped prisoners all over Europe, their agents will be everywhere. Local Resistance groups fighting back against the Nazi regime may provide vital assistance during the escape, but finding them will often prove dangerous.

If they get to Paris, the resistance will provide all the necessary documentation, and help them with a “Freedom Plan”. This is vital to their escape, and without it, they dare not enter the South of France (the blue spaces shown on the servicemen’s map).

Once a Freedom Plan has been secured, the servicemen must travel through France and cross into Spain to win the game.

—description from the designer

The game is available from the Game Crafter:

https://www.thegamecrafter.com/games/escaping-wwii
categories: Exploration, Fighting, Travel, World War II
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Move Through Deck, Solo / Solitaire Game, Storytelling, Track Movement

name: Legends Of Dragons: The Card Game
description:
Game mechanics like: role-playing, player elimination, variable setup, grid movement, and campaigning, are mixed into a formula of exciting adventure wrapped in a visually stunning package for 1 or more players with minor changes! A bold and fun experience that combines imagination, strategy, and conquering, in order to achieve the goal - utter dominance over the opponent(s) with your armada of Dragons. Players use decks of 50 cards to attack and defend with Dragons of many types and colors. For an added challenge, players may use up to six (6) dice to increase the difficulty!
