Players draw cards and place dragons of varying colors with different abilities as Attackers or Defenders, and use Action cards that effect the entire field of play, in order to defeat their opponent by reducing their life points to 0.

Players can capture each of the 27 locations to win a game and advance their Avatar Dragon one level. Certain levels unlock Stats that can be altered and each Location offers a benefit that can be used to the player's advantage. Utilizing any of the 6 dice allows access to Random Encounters, and a Stat Multiplier which multiplies all values on every card. Both of these features increase game time, but offer a more detailed experience.

Another option for two or more players is Fast Duels, in which players simply draw 1 dragon card at a time against their opponent(s). The player with the highest attack wins the round, unless an opponent has a dragon with equal or higher defense, then the first player loses. If incorporating Regions, the game is over when 1 player controls all 27 locations. Otherwise the player winning the most rounds is the overall winner.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Move Through Deck, Once-Per-Game Abilities, Player Elimination, Role Playing, Semi-Cooperative Game, Solo / Solitaire Game, Team-Based Game, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up

name: Strontium Dog: Search & Destroy!
description:
Successful Search/Destroy agents rely on speed, cunning and firepower in equal measure.

The ubiquitous skimmer provides high speed, all-terrain maneouvrability and is often the vehicle of choice for bounty hunters and outlaws alike.
Also known as hover sleds or hov-bikes, skimmers are able to operate in high radiation areas where natural mounts such as Morks struggle.

Johnny Alpha and his partner Wulf Sternhammer regularly tracked their quarry by skimmer and many an outlaw, criminal or alien fugitive from the law have been brought to justice as a result.

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: 2000 AD Comic, Rebellion Developments (Rebellion), Warlord Games

name: Strontium Dog: SD Agents
description:
An angry, uncouth Scotsman with a penchant for the bottle, Archibald 'Middenface' McNulty joins Johnny Alpha on many jobs and is only too happy to 'dish oot the laldy'. Whatever that means...

Like Middenface, Kid Knee likes a drink – he needs the solace of a bottle of Mac-Mac to calm his shot nerves.

Blubberlips was one of Johnny Alpha's group as they tracked down the notorious mutant war criminal, General William Blood Moon.

Afflicted with a vampire-like blood lust mutation Durham Red is both ally and lover to Johnny Alpha. Durham's thirst for blood is just one of the sources of Johnny's mistrust of her.

Maeve the Many-Armed, unsurprising, has many arms and aside from dressing like the legendary Queen of Connacht, she wields multiple weapons – you've got to hand it to her.

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: 2000 AD Comic, Rebellion Developments (Rebellion), Warlord Games

name: Strontium Dog: Bubo and the Bad Boys
description:
Riding their bipedal Mork steeds, Bubo and his howler henchmen raided for valuables and for meat - they cooked and devoured their prisoners! This reign of terror finally led to the mayor of the latest town to be hit by Bubo's gang to call on the Search/Destroy agency to send help.

That help materialised in the form of Johnny Alpha and his partner Wulf Sternhammer, who immediately set off on Bubo's trail...

Johnny and Wulf caught up with the Bad Boys as they attacked a train heading from Jobsville.

After a violent showdown Bubo tied the train’s throttle and it plunged off a bridge into the ravine below, trapping the unconscious Alpha. Wulf saved his partner, taking him to the nearest town for medical care before heading out to wreak bloody vengeance on Bubo and his Howler outlaws.

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: 2000 AD Comic, Rebellion Developments (Rebellion), Warlord Games

name: Strontium Dog: Scum of the Universe
description:
Where there are bounty hunters there must, by definition, be those who have a bounty placed on their heads. Often these are violent outlaws, criminals or psychopaths.

One of Johnny Alpha's previous partners, Sniffer Martinez, was gunned down by Kansyr on the planet Laz in Alpha's early days as an SD Agent. Using the Halugin weapon he stole on Laz, Kansyr went on to become crime lord of the planet Metastis.

Taking part in the ancient annual death-rite known as The Killing on planet Zdwhkkrswrld (more commonly known as Zed!), Johnny and Wulf cross paths with the android Steelkreeg. Holding the two SD agents off in a bell tower using his flamethrower he eventually meets his demise!

A two-faced mutant gang leader in the Spice System, Billy Joe forced Johnny into a duel with las-whips, the outcome a foregone conclusion as the gang leader was the system's champion for the last 16 years.

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: 2000 AD Comic, Rebellion Developments (Rebellion), Warlord Games

name: Strontium Dog: Mork Riders
description:
Bounty Hunters often need to track their quarry into the wildlands beyond towns and cities, and on many worlds the indigenous Morks are the mount of choice.

These bipedal mammals combine speed and durability with a seemingly high tolerance of radiation making them ideal steeds for bounty hunter and outlaw alike. Mork farms are not an unusual sight in the homesteads on the fringes of civilisation.

Johnny Alpha and his Viking partner Wulf Sternhammer make good use of Morks on many of their bounty-hunting jobs – from tackling the vicious alien outlaws Bubo and his gang of Howler Bad Boys to protecting alien farmsteaders from bullying neighbours intent on driving the Search/Destroy agents out.
Allying speed and resilience, Morks can reliably get them to where they need to be - much to the chagrin of their quarry!

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: 2000 AD Comic, Rebellion Developments (Rebellion), Warlord Games

name: Strontium Dog: Darkus' Howlers
description:
Not all bounty hunters are mutants. The dangerous, yet potentially lucrative, lifestyle also attracts unsavoury aliens such as the vicious Darkus and his fellow Howlers from the planet Kunghung. The Howlers are said to be happy to kill for fun even if they weren't getting paid!

Darkus and his Howler henchmen fell foul of Johnny Alpha, Wulf Sternhammer and Middenface McNulty as they vied for bounties during the end of the amnesty in the 49th Territory on the notorious planet Burrito. Things got out of hand when both groups fight for the chance to claim the massive 6,000,000 credit reward on galactic criminal Xen the Brainwraith...

Contents:
3 Miniatures
‣ 1 Darkus
‣ 2 Howlers
2 Character cards
2 Armoury Cards
1 Chicanery Card

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: 2000 AD Comic, Rebellion Developments (Rebellion), Warlord Games

name: Strontium Dog: Mutant Army Generals
description:
Due to Government minister Nelson Bunker Kreelman's anti-mutant laws, mutants are not allowed to hold down a job or even buy food for themselves. Confined to segregated ghettos and slums they live a miserable existence.

Small wonder many of them flock to the New Mutant Army and hit back at their norm tormentors with guerilla raids before finally launching an all-out assault on the Palace of Upminster, the seat of the norm government.

Each division of then Mutant Army is led by a fierce, charismatic figure such as this included in this set: Studs Boyce of the Midlands Divison, the Welsh Divisions Evans the Fist, Clacton Fuzz of the South-East Division and the Tyne-and-Weirdies led by The Torso from Newcastle. In overall command of the Mutant Army is the multi-limbed General Armz.

Contents:
5 Miniatures
‣ Studs Boyce
‣ General Armz
‣ Clacton Fuzz
‣ The Torso from Newcastle
‣ Evans the Fist
5 Character Cards
1 Armoury Card
4 Chicanery Cards

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: 2000 AD Comic, Rebellion Developments (Rebellion), Warlord Games

name: Strontium Dog: The Kreelers
description:
Riding a wave of anti-mutant sentiment, rich civic leader Nelson Bunker Krellman was elected to New British Parliament largely due to his anti-mutie rhetoric. On his election, he began enacting anti-mutant laws that forbade mutants from owning property, having jobs, or even congregating on the streets.

To enforce the harsh new laws Kreelman's quasi-official anti-mutant 'peacekeeping' patrols, the Kreelers, inflict brutality upon the mutants living in a New Britain devastated by nuclear war, sending many of the more able-bodied to work in experimental labour camps far from the populace.

Arch anti-mutant politician Nelson B. Kreelman is also the mutant hero, Johnny Alpha's father...

—description from the publisher
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game
publishers: 2000 AD Comic, Rebellion Developments (Rebellion), Warlord Games

name: Aversion
description:
The goal of the game is to find words that won't share any letter in the same position than the words previously found.

The winner is the player who made the most words, found the last one in the dictionnary or simply had the last word (others abandonned/couldn't play)

A scoring scheme can be used, for exemple 1 word/1 point, penalty for incorrect guesses. You can decide on a maximum alloted time for a move, play several rounds for a game to conclude, etc.


This is a pen and paper game. In the files section you'll find a small computer program with its source code that can serve as a referee.




—description from the designer
mechanics: Paper-and-Pencil, Real-Time

name: The Silver Bay Game
description:
This family board game is about Silver Bay on Lake George and might just become your new favorite family game.

Players surround themselves with pine tree covered mountains and take the windy road through Silver Bay – a beautiful retreat on the Lake. They explore the lake, walk the labyrinth, visit the ice cream shop, all while gathering resources and trying not to get stranded on an island.

Objective: Visit as many destinations on the Silver Bay campus as you can and acquire them with your gathered resources (pine cones). The game is over when all the Destination cards are claimed. The Silver Bay Game could be the next best thing to actually being at the lake.

The game mixes both chance and strategy.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Hexagon Fighting Championship
description:
With defensive maneuvers, movement, and an array of attacks, in the Hexagon Fighting Championship you can gradually grind your opponent down in a war of attrition, or win a sudden victory. Using of a hexagonal-grid game board, a 54-card deck, a 6-sided die, 2 tokens to represent fighters, and poker chips for damage, two adversaries seek positional advantage, attacking one another, and defending against, strikes, grappling, chokes, locks, and fouls.

Attack cards are played at various ranges, and to varied effect. Strikes (clubs) can hit from distance, and do damage. Grappling attacks (spades) apply from closer range, do damage, and put you in control of your opponent. Chokes (hearts) can be played within the grappling clinch, and end the fight immediately when successful. Locks (diamonds) do the same, but unlike chokes, score damage, too.

Defending attacks generally means playing a higher card of the same suit as the attack, or two lower cards in the same suit, unless you're in top position in a grappling clinch, in which case your grappling (spades) trump your opponent's chokes (hearts) and locks (diamonds). Fouls (jokers) trump everything.

Players pay for damage caused by attacks with their supply of poker chips; but, when those chips run out, or if your opponent scores a successful submission hold on you, you've lost the fight: the winner takes the chips.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Hexagon Grid, King of the Hill, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation, Static Capture, Take That, Trick-taking, Zone of Control

name: Galleys, Guns and Glory!
description:
Galleys Guns and Glory! is designed to play table top naval battles with fleets of cannon packing oared vessels, in a time frame from roughly 1500- 1650. The rules are designed to work at “convention level”, which means you can learn the rules in less than 5 minutes, get into action- making a couple of n00b moves,(or spectacular maneuvers) and come away with a story or two to tell at the bar.

Management of each ship and its crew are visual and easy to account for as the crew and damage to the ship are represented on the models- leaving little to no paperwork!

Although trying to capture the essence of the period and referencing strongly the doctrines and tactics of the time, I claim no absolute historical accuracy, other than like the galleys of yore my ships are made of wood and are adorned with such opulent awnings, lanterns, flags and bulwark side trim that would make the Sultan’s harem jealous.

Galleys Guns and Glory! is designed for oared naval actions ranging in scale from small corsair raids of a few ships to “epic” grand battle re-fights such as Lepanto- with over 100 ships! With an emphasis on maneuvering, the brutality of gun fire, sky darkening fusillades of small arms and intense melee boarding actions that would ebb and flow across ships, GGG! has something for everyone!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: "500" Cribbage
description:
Fully referred to as the "500 Cribbage Thomas System", this game sets out to develop and modernize the classic game of Cribbage with several refinements.

Players peg points on an updated version of the original Cribbage board, with separate tracks for points scored in the Play, Hand, and Crib. Additionally, the straight-flush is recognized as an independent scoring combination, and the play of the cards until "Go" is extended to a limit of 34 instead of 31. Equal deals are played (5 each) and at the end players total their scores: points from the Play are worth 6, from the Hand 4, and from the Crib 3. If the loser failed to reach a grand total of 500, their deficit is added to the winner's final score (relevant in series play).

The most significant change is the board. The "500" Cribbage board includes, for each player: two tracks to 30 labeled "Play" and "Crib", one double-track to 60 labeled "Hand", a bank of additional pegs and 30/60/120 holes to mark if any of those tracks are exceeded, and a 5-hole track for each player to mark the number of deals. The game thus cannot be played on a classic Cribbage board, but classic Cribbage can be played on the "500" board by using the eight tracks for up to four players.

Included within the rules are variants for solitaire play, four players in partnerships, and a spinoff betting game called "Cribbage Poker".
mechanics: Hand Management

name: Qua
description:
Qua is a three-dimensional (3D) abstract strategy game for three players. It is an extension of the two-dimensional, two player game called Gale, marketed as Bridg-It. Qua is played on a 3D game board grid composed of NxNxN cells in the shape of a cube, where N is typically odd and equal to the number of cells along each edge of the game board.

The objective of Qua is to be the first player to complete a connected chain (path) of cells containing their game play pieces between their two opposite faces of the game board cube.

The 3D game board does not start out empty. Some of the cells in the game board are permanently filled-in with one of three game play pieces, called qua. See Figure 1 from the Images gallery above: https://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/5539928/qua. The three qua game play pieces--one for each player--are distinguished from each other by shape and color.

Rules
Players choose their qua at the beginning of the game and decide who will go first, second and third in sequential turn order. Each turn, players place one of their qua in an empty cell in the game board cube.

Players may only place qua in an empty cell if it is adjacent to two cells that already contain their qua, or one such cell and one of their two game board cube faces.

If a player cannot make a move, they skip their turn.

If the current player is in a Kingmaker situation where one of the other players will win on their next turn and the one who wins will be determined by the current player's move, then the Qua Kingmaker game play rule states that the current player blocks the immediate next player's win first. However, if no one identifies the Kingmaker situation, and the current player makes a different move, then that move is valid.

The game ends when the first player connects their two faces of the Qua Cube game board.

Game Play Variants
Qua Misere
The first player that connects their two faces of the game board loses. This can be a two-player game.

Dice Qua
Players roll a 6-sided die to determine which game play piece to play on their turn (two sides of the die for each game play piece). This can also be played as a two-person game. A player may win as a result of an opponent’s move.
mechanics: Connections, Paper-and-Pencil

name: Seas the Day
description:
Seas the Day is fun memory match and basic strategy game that helps you exercise your grey cells. Each player matches multiple variables to complete their matching sets, while learning about the sea creature on the card.

Each card has unique poem that encapsulates an interesting fact about the sea creature.

The game also includes a strategy mode where players can choose to match one or more objects in a game to score points. While players may be tempted to target patterns that score the highest points, they will soon learn that waiting for their cards of choice may not be the best approach, as other players race to finish the game before they do.

—description from the designer
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Math, Trivia
mechanics: Matching, Memory

name: Bärenmarke Alpenspiel
description:
The players have to move either a tractor or a horse carriage from from start to finish. They may use three different kinds of streets: country road, mountain road and "Bundesstraße", each with its own obstacles and benefits. Movement is determined by a die with the numbers 1, 2 and 3.

The first player to reach finish wins the game.

The game was published in the 1970s as a giveaway. Tractors and carriages were enclosed in packs of four cans Bärenmarke coffee creamer.

—user summary
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Monopoly: Charleroi
description:
The classic Monopoly with a Charleroi (Belgium) twist.

In addition to green houses and red hotels, you can buy wine cellars, stolen cars workshops, or even brothels.
The Monopoly of Charleroi has... four jails !
When you pass GO you receive the usual €200, plus €200 in bribe.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Espalier
description:
Espalier is a simultaneous play, family-friendly experience that turns the tile-placement genre upside-down. The game artfully grafts a gardening theme to the tile-laying mechanic with its simple concept and intense strategy. Feel the tension as your branches line up (or not!) and you compete to make the most fruitful tree in the garden.

Three easy steps to play:

Pick up and place tiles
Buy and grow fruit
Compete to achieve Garden Goals


Endless possibilities:

Every tree is unique in every game
Variable setup dramatically changes strategy in each playthrough


Quick game time:

Consistently rapid games regardless of player count


Options for everyone:

Challenging solo player mode
Simple beginner variants for new players


—description from the publisher
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Math, Puzzle, Real-time
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Pattern Building, Simultaneous Action Selection, Tile Placement, Variable Set-up

name: Diamonds for Water
description:
Water is scarce and becoming scarcer every day! You and your team of experts has been called upon to solve one crisis after another across the globe. The countdown is on in Diamonds for Water, a new cooperative deck building game from Big Girl Games.

In each game, a team is made up of water experts who must work together to achieve a final solution to a region-specific water problem. Players begin with a deck of basic cards which are supplemented by purchasing cards from the Market. On each turn, the players must engage with a Conflict, and resolve whatever problems the water issue brings up. Then they gather the resources from the cards in their hand and take any of several actions: help their teammates, purchase new cards for their deck, invest diamonds in the Bank, or trade and spend currency to solve the ongoing Goal or Objective.

Players choose from characters with special Actions. They may be able to help their fellow players stay healthy, draw extra cards, or receive extra Food or Energy. Each character also has a Skill they can choose to use three times in a game, such as halting the countdown marker or digging through the Market draw deck to find elusive Water cards. While Food and Energy are plentiful, trading for Diamonds requires them to be available in the Bank, and getting them there can require some sacrifice for the team. However, team members can also Plant and Harvest left over Food as a way to raise the currency they need for more expensive items, such as Water cards.

In the world of the game, Water is actually more valuable than Diamonds. And it becomes more scarce as you play - a Countdown Marker shows how water is running out while your team tries to solve each problem. Let the Countdown Marker reach 0 without resolving each Goal and Objective, and your team loses. Fix the problems using Energy, Diamonds, and Water, and you win!

-description from designer
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building

name: Test of Honour: The Samurai MIniatures Game – Sohei Temple Guard
description:
Led by Superior Saburo, the fierce Sohei warrior monks defend their sacred temple-fortresses to the last.

Mounted Sohei Superior Saburo
Sohei Sergeant
Sohei Creed Bearer
Sohei Temple Guard with nodachi heavy sword
Sohei Temple Guard with tetsubo heavy club
Sohei Temple Guard with paired swords
9 Recruitment Cards
1 Trait Card
6 Skill Cards
2 Quest Cards
MDF bases

The warriors represented in this box can be used with other Sohei forces, Ikko Ikki rebels, as well as allied samurai clans. These zealous believers do not fear death and fight even harder if their brethren are slain.

Superior Saburo leads the defence of the temple-fortress, galloping at his enemies to deliver a devasting one-off attack with the Dive Strike card.

The Sohei sergeant can send his troops surging forward in a sudden wave (or unleash a sudden blast of gunfire if you use him as a gunnery sergeaant) - a definite contrast to the steady ashigaru of the clans.

Meanwhile the Creed Bearer carries a banner daubed with inspiring prayers and religious slogans, making it more likely for nearby believers to trigger their Strike bonuses.

The devout Temple Guards themselves are the toughest fighters, hand-picked from among the warrior monks and able to shrug off minor injuries and carry on the battle unaffected. You can make them even harder to defeat with the Final Guardians trait!

Skill cards include Holy Relic, Hallowed Walls and Power from Grief.

Box contains 18 gaming cards for Test of Honour and 6 metal miniatures plus bases.

—description from the publisher
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Medieval, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Chit-Pull System, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Just Rhyme
description:
"Looking for a fun party game of words, charades and rhymes? With over 1200 words including creating your own words? Get ready in this game of up to 8 players and see how fast you can rhyme every word."

(Publisher blurb)
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Green vs Tan: Where Dingos Dare
description:
Green Vs. Tan: Where Dingo's Dare!

An exciting new, easy to learn skirmish game that the whole family can enjoy!

Utilizing a fluid, fun dynamic of mechanics that are very straightforward and simple, this game can be read and played like a pro today!

The game also includes print and play minis and objectives for your convenience!

All models are Characters, with names and unique stats and traits, and all are willing to do their part, either for the Green Guard, or the Tanzer Elite!

Everything you need is here!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement

name: First Mention
description:
In First Mention, players compete with their Bible knowledge. There are two game modes: Normal and Territorial.

In the normal mode, players advance on a track by drawing cards with characters or events from the Bible. By answering in which chapter of the Bible a character or event was first mentioned, and by explaining what they stand for, players advance on the game track. If a player gives a wrong answer, other can challenge them to make them return to from where they started. The first player to reach Paradise (i.e., the end of the track) wins the game.

In the Territorial mode, players attempt to occupy the locations on the board, each of which is connected to a section of the Bible. Answering correctly lets you place a banner on a location, but you can score points only if you are not driven out by another player. The player with the highest score wins.
mechanics: Race

name: Hybrids
description:
A unique strategy board game featuring disgustingly adorable, genetically pliable Blibs. Players build their characters using genes and relics, participating in a king of the hill style battle. First player to 500 points, wins!

Hybrids may be a king of the hill style game, but the catch is there's more to winning than simply staying in the center. Gain points from staying on the map, pushing others off the map, or even using supportive genes to help your fellow players. Each player has 4 gene slots they can customize and switch with other genes they get over the course of the game. Relics bring additional customization, adding effects to genes, mutating them, or enabling powerful consumable effects.

The game will come with the core rules as well as 3 alternate game modes, including a team mode. The ability for players to pursue various builds every time allows for different experiences each play session and the freedom to experiment between games.

Hybrids brings high replayability, multiple layers of strategy, and is simple to learn but hard to master.

-description from publisher
mechanics: Action Retrieval, Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, King of the Hill, Movement Points, Role Playing, Slide/Push, Square Grid, Team-Based Game, Turn Order: Progressive, Variable Player Powers, Victory Points as a Resource

name: Interstate
description:
Interstate is a trivia game about the 36 states of Nigeria. There are two decks, a green deck with the name of one state each, and a red deck with questions. The green cards are dealt out to the players. Each player picks one of those cards and places it openly in front of them.
A red card is then flipped up and each player must in turn answer that question in relation to the state on their card. If they manage to do so, they can discard the green card; if not, they have to take it back into their hand. Answers can be challenged; but if you wrongly accuse someone of giving a wrong answer you have to take their green card.
The first player to get rid of all their green cards is the winner.
mechanics: Unspecified

name: In Cold and Dicey Waters
description:
The cold war between the Northern Coalition and the Southern Alliance is about to escalate!

In this competitive game for two to four players, you take control of a dice-powered attack submarine about to make contact with the enemy. The numbers and technological capabilties on both sides even out, so it is up to your wits and tactics to ensure that your side emerges from this first engagement with an advantage.

This is a free print & play game made for the "4th Roll & Write Contest" organized here in the BGG forums.

In Cold and Dicey Waters offers a competitive 1v1 or 2v2 experience based on action-programming, incomplete information and a moderate amount of dice rolling.

This game was specifically designed to feature good playability over video-chat software and only requires some dice, a pencil and one printed player sheet each. No cutting, no folding, no scissors, just symmetrical, tactical gameplay.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Dice Rolling, Different Dice Movement, Hexagon Grid, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game

name: Go For Broke!: A World War II Miniatures Skirmish Game
description:
Go For Broke! is an easy to learn, fun to master skirmish miniatures game! These rules provide everything you need to start using your collection of 25mm to 28mm World War II miniatures in pitched battles and daring scenarios. With these rules it is easy to create a “beer & pretzels” style game night or an in-depth mission with a realistic objective! So grab your dice, your little metal figures, maybe a tank or two, and prepare to Go For Broke!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Monopoly: Folkestone
description:
From the publisher:

"Tour Folkestone for the hottest properties: sites, travel spaces and local services are all up for grabs. Invest in houses and hotels, then watch the rent come pouring in! Make deals with other players and look out for bargains at auction - there are many ways to get what you want. Stay sharp, because there's only room at the top for one. For everyone else, there's bankruptcy. Trade your way to success - you can own it all! MONOPOLY has made its way to the diverse city of Folkestone.

Key Features

The world’s favourite family board game brings you another exciting edition of MONOPOLY – Folkestone!
Choose your favourite token, tour your favourite sites and accumulate fortunes, but watch out for taxes, jail and bankruptcy
Advance to Folkestone's historical sites – will you owe rent or reap the rewards?
Invest in houses and hotels and trade your way to success
The Fast-Dealing Property Trading Game is fun for the whole family"
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Market, Ownership, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Dawn of Madness: Of Art and Oblivion
description: Of Art and Oblivion is a Wanderer expansion featuring Cary James the Actor. This expansion adds a whole new chapter to a Dawn of Madness campaign, complete with its own twisted story.
categories: Adventure, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Role Playing, Storytelling, Variable Player Powers

name: Corona Yuga
description:
The pandemic situation has imposed a lockdown on all of humankind. Veer Kashyap (Age 9Yrs 9Months), a class 5 student at Army Public School, New Delhi, had gone to visit his grandparents in Bengaluru during the academic break and got stuck due to lockdown. To overcome the boredom, he decided to design a board game on his own when our Prime Minister announced 21 days of lockdown. He understood the COVID-19 scenario through media and came up with a board game, which he named CORONA YUGA, meaning Corona Era. He designed the layout, drew it on a cardboard and completed using material available at home, and started playing with family.

Board games are a fun and effective way of introducing new concepts to children of all ages and Corona Yuga aims to create awareness in a most interesting manner and spend time together at home during lockdown period. The board game designed like the infamous corona virus, promotes Yoga & Social Distancing and also appreciates COVID Warriors for their services to mankind. This fun game played by ages 5+ will entertain everyone in future years, about the present scenario faced by each one of us.
mechanics: Dice Rolling

name: Animal Football
description:
The most exciting football tournament is about to begin! Join us in the challenge: choose five players from a row of dozens of characters with unique qualities and attractive designs to enhance your playing style. Get ready to face your friends in this fantastic game that combines tactics and actions.

Move your players on the rectangle field, make the most of each player's characteristics like speed, pass, shot, dribbling, contrast and interception. Create fast or intricate actions to bring your team to score more goals than the opponent in the regular 45 minutes, or prepare to face the penalties, where in the event of a tie, you will have to challenge your opponent in a match of intuition and luck until you win the game.

The game is based on a few of intuitive mechanics. With the qualities of the characters well highlighted on the card, which indicates the dice to be thrown to perform the action that has been set up: in this way, your fun is guaranteed from the first minutes of the game. Meanwhile, the large space left to the player's creativity allows to develop an infinite number of tactics - with a great depth of game, able to satisfy even the most experienced players. What are you waiting for?

-description from designer
mechanics: Unspecified

name: How Game Are You? Original Edition
description:
This 'ORIGINAL EDITION' is named so because its the first of the Question card format games, following the previous 'COUPLES INTIMACY EDITION' board game.

In this ORIGINAL EDITION, questions are ranked A, B or C depending on whether you want a quick lite game (A's) or deeper questions (C's) or play A,B,C in order.

Player one asks the selected question of the other player(s), and they answer with the total Truth, or a total Lie. Player one has to guess is it Truth or a Lie and gains a point if they identified it correctly. This can also be played as a drinking game where the wrong guess means you take a drink. Suitable for 2-8 players 16+y/o for normal games and older if its a drinking game.

The game can also be played co-cooperatively, where all questions are Truth and take turns to ask the other(s). Lose a point for no answer given or you want to skip. Alternatively focus more on the answers and interesting conversations normally ensue for clarification or shared experiences together.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deduction

name: Brothers at War: 6mm ACW Wargame Rules
description:
Brothers at War is wargame system to land battles in the American Civil War (ACW) on 6mm to 20mm scale.
The basic fighting unit is a company or a battery of artilley. These are grouped into divisions.
Turns are performed by alternate activation of divisions, with the quality of the commanders determining some issues.

Basic unit types are: infantry, cavalry, artillery and special units (General, Officer, Banner, Skirmisher).
Points system for units and army lists for points based games.
The army lists can be used to convert historical orders of battle, into lists for games.

The objective is to provide an easy, agile and adaptable rules system for the simulation of combat in the American Civil War.
The definitions of range of weapons were based on historical sources and serious publications, in particular the book “Small Arms at Gettysburg”, by Joseph G. Bilby.
Likewise, the rules for combat formations and for the historical characteristics of each army were also the target of research in specialized bibliography on the subject.

—description from the publisher
categories: American Civil War, Book, Miniatures, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Dawn of Madness: The Ticking Heart
description:
Edward is a clockmaker who, like Claude, also happens to be a family man. Unlike Claude, though, he knows that it is already too late for his family. Or... is it? What if there was a way to undo what had been done? What if he could bring her back?

The first major expansion to the game unlocked by the stretch goals during Kickstarter campaign. Edward Hirshfield, the clockmaker, will be the wanderer, who will have the leading part and his story is going to be a doozy.
categories: Adventure, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Horror, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Role Playing, Storytelling, Variable Player Powers

name: Gloop (Second Edition)
description: Take on the role of a teen trying to protect an alien life form that crashed down from other aliens that came after it. The game is a cooperative action point based game.
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Events, Modular Board, Solo / Solitaire Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Monster Park
description:
Monster Park is a co-operative miniatures game designed in 2016 by board game Artist James Churchill. Players use movement cards and individual character abilities to evade or attack. Monster cards determine the movement of each cryptid(s). Gates can be opened and closed within the compound using access codes assigned to each player. Victory can be achieved by luring and trapping all monsters into containment areas, or by all players escaping the compound.

-description from designer
mechanics: Area Movement, Cooperative Game, Hand Management

name: War Hounds
description:
A new century has dawned for all pups and dogs on the great island continent of Doggerland. But the hope of a shining new future has quickly darkened. The nations of Doggerland fortify their borders, mobilize troops and artillery daily. Though many fear war, many more welcome it as the opportunity for glory and patriotic display. Little do they understand what destruction is to come…

Each player in War Hounds is the leader of a nation of dogs. There are 12 factions (6 double sided playerboards.) Each faction with its own set of abilities, functions, costs etc. Players will play over the course of 4 years, the war ending at the close of the 4th year. Players will play in rondel turn order, each round the turn order possibly changing. Players will take one action on their turn by selecting an action in the top of their playerboard. As with everything in this era of Doggerland history, things are hierarchical, meaning a chain of command or top-down, and so in selecting actions, generally a player may not select an action above those they have already selected. Players will draft troops, build artillery, invest in new technologies, influence new policies, shift and transform their economies, and of course engage in embroiled bouts of combat. Players will conquer territories, gain medals and lose casualties. Ultimately, the winner is the nation with the most victory paws at the end of the game.

The winner is the nation with the most total victory paws at the end of the game (all paws are awarded at game end--none during). Players gain victory paws from the following sources: medals, casualties (negative paws), controlled territories, technologies, policies, loan debt (negative paws) and wealth (1 victory paw per $25).

-description from designer
categories: Animals, Economic, Wargame, World War I
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling, Income, Loans, Rondel, Tech Trees / Tech Tracks, Trading

name: Old Shanghai Game: a card game of the Barbary Coast
description:
Welcome to the Barbary Coast, a Wild West mess of saloons, dance-halls and gambling dens in Old San Francisco. In this elimination card game players try to avoid being Shanghai'd - using "Upstairs Ladies", "Old Shellbacks" taking advantage of "Drunken Sailors" or just by plying opponents with "drinks".
Other players gang up against a Shanghai'd player with Rowing Gangs or Shanghai Boss cards and there's a price to pay if the Shanghai fails.
This game has local interest, but isn't only a San Francisco game. The game features good player interaction, it plays fast, eliminated players aren't out for long, less than 5 minutes for the average game.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Sudden Death Ending

name: Checkards
description:
Addition to the classical game of chess. A new strategy element consisting of 48 cards which are used for movement of the pieces. There are 15 pawn cards, 7 knight cards, 7 bishop cards, 5, rook cards, 5 queen cards, 3 light pieces cards, 3 heavy pieces cards, and 3 strategy cards. The game is played on a regular chess board with standard rules (including castling, en passant etc), but before you can play a move, first you must play a card that matches the piece you are moving (example: to play a pawn you must play a pawn card). At the beginning of the game, each player receives 20 cards from the deck. After both players have used all of their cards, the deck is reshuffled and each player receives 20 cards again. Beside regular cards (each for one type of piece) there are also three kinds of special cards - light, heavy and strategy. "Light" can move either a knight or a bishop, "heavy" either a rook or a queen, and "strategy" can move any piece on the board. If, at some point of the game, a player has no card by which he can move the remaining pieces on the board, he must move his king. To move a king a player can play any card from the deck, but he place it face down on the discard pile. If a player doesn't have a card to move any of the remaining pieces, and his king is unable to move (due to check threat), that player immediately loses the game.

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Card Game, Expansion for Base-game
mechanics: Command Cards

name: Diskwars: Dragonkin
description:
A Fantasy themed miniatures wargame without the miniatures. Will you play as the ubiquitous Elves, the barbaric Uthuk Yllan, the stalwart Dwarves, the vile Undead, the medieval Knights, the desert dwelling Acolytes, the mighty Dragon kin, or the vicious Orcs? Players choose a faction from the eight available in the base game and an army point value for the battle. Each must then build an army using the double-sided cardboard disks and battle it out. At least half of the army points must be from one faction and the remaining points are made up of like aligned or neutral disks and spells.

Each double-sided disk represents either a faction homeland (your starting area), a terrain (ruins, forest, swamp etc... with effects on combat and line of sight), a spell(levels 1-3), a missile or one unit with its alignment (Good, Neutral, or Evil) with values for its Attack, Defense, Toughness, Movement and the army point cost of the disk. The disks have varying sizes (Giants and Dragons tend to be larger) and most units have a wide variety special abilities such as flying, the spell-casting ability or the missile ability to launch boulders, bolts, arrows or fireballs for example. Players take it in turn activating 3 units(disks) and resolving battles, casting spells, and firing missiles.

Activated Unit disks are moved around the table by flipping them end over end a number of times up to their movement value. If the disk lands on top of an opposing army disk a battle ensues with the top disk (the attacker) doing its attack damage value to the lower disk (the defender) who applies its defense value to the attacker if the damage is equal or greater to either unit's toughness it is either wounded or killed. Combats can involve numerous disks upon top of each other and are resolved top down. Missiles can be fired by missile capable units at disks within range by dropping them upon the target from a foot above the table. Those which land upon the target do damage otherwise they miss or can hit other disks they land on. This can result in 'friendly fire' damage on your own troops and adds an element of luck/dexterity to the game.

The game rules come with multiple scenarios that accommodate 2 to 8 players. The victory goal of each scenario can vary from king of the hill, to enemy elimination, to just about any combat scenario victory condition one could imagine.
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Variable Player Powers

name: Bonaparte: 6mm-20mm Napoleonic Wargame Rules
description:
Bonaparte is wargame system to land battles in the Napoleonic Wars on 6mm to 20mm scale.

The basic fighting unit is a company or a battery of artillery.
These are grouped into battalions.

Turns are performed by alternate activation of battalions, with the quality of the commanders determining some issues.
Basic unit types are; infantry, cavalry, artillery and special units (General, Officer, Banner, Skirmisher).

Points system for units and army lists for points based games.
The army lists can be used to convert historical orders of battle, into lists for games.

The objective is to provide an easy, agile and adaptable rules system for the simulation of combat in the Napoleonic Wars.

The definitions of range of weapons were based on historical sources and serious publications, in particular the book “Weapons & Equipment of the Napoleonic Wars”, by Philip J. Haythornthwaite.

Likewise, the rules for combat formations and for the historical characteristics of each army were also the target of research in specialized bibliography on the subject.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Diskwars: Moon Over Thelgrim – Zocrab's Marauders
description:
There is a bad moon rising, full of blood and ill omens. The Great War has come to Thelgrim, and death follows in its wake.

Moon Over Thelgrim is the first expansion set for Diskwars. With Moon Over Thelgrim, you may expand your Diskwars game with more 100 new Disks, including new creatures, spells, lands and even a new faction. Moon Over Thelgrim comes in eight different army packs: The Draco Wing (Dragonkin), Frothan's Ghouls (Undead), The Groman Guard (Knights), The Sons of Triamlavar (Elves), Zocrab's Marauders (Orcs), The Hammers of Urth (Dwarves), The Knives of Q'aro Fenn (Uthuk), and Waiqar's Sundermen (Acolytes). Each pack has four set flats of that faction and four random flats.

What's New in Moon Over Thelgrim:

Terrain - The expansion includes new rules for terrain, as well as six new Terrain Disks.
Champions - These unique new hero Disks add power to your "pure" armies.
New Disk Abilities - Dozens of the new Creature Disks feature new abilities to add variety and strategy to your game.
New Scenarios - No Diskwars expansion would be complete without new scenarios, and Moon Over Thelgrim gives you several from which to choose.
A New Faction - The mysterious wilds of the Thelgrim Peninsula are home to strange new faction that does not appreciate outsiders invading its homeland.
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Variable Player Powers

name: Diskwars: The Wastelands Reinforcement Pack
description:
The wise ones say that the Char'gr Wastelands are full of demons. They say evil twisted creatures lurk beneath the earth, lying in wait for unwary travelers.

The Wastelands is the second expansion for Diskwars. With The Wastelands, you may expand your Diskwars game with more than 120 new Disks, including new creatures, spells, terrains, and a new faction. Each Reinforcement Pack will include four random flats of Disks. Sold as booster with no specific faction.
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Variable Player Powers

name: Diskwars: Legions – Massacre at Godstone Keep
description:
Each Legions set is a complete game, ready to be played by both beginning and experienced DiskWars players. Legions contains everything you need for a two-player game of DiskWars.

There are 4 Legions 2-player Boxes: Dark Wings Over Nochaim (Dragon vs. Mahkim), Last Stand at Dunwarr (Dwarves vs. Orc), Massacre at Godstone Keep (Knight vs. Uthuk), and Nightmare in Nharwood (Elf vs. Undead).


Complete two-player game for Diskwars. Contains:

Pre-constructed Knight army
Pre-constructed Uthuk Y'llan army
Complete game rules
Introductory quick-start sheet
Full-color map of Mennara
Several brand-new Disks unavailable elsewhere
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Variable Player Powers

name: Diskwars: Legions – Last Stand at Dunwarr
description:
Each Legions set is a complete game, ready to be played by both beginning and experienced DiskWars players. Legions contains everything you need for a two-player game of DiskWars.

There are 4 Legions 2-player Boxes: Dark Wings Over Nochaim (Dragon vs. Mahkim), Last Stand at Dunwarr (Dwarves vs. Orc), Massacre at Godstone Keep (Knight vs. Uthuk), and Nightmare in Nharwood (Elf vs. Undead).


Complete two-player game for Diskwars. Contains:

Pre-constructed Dwarf army
Pre-constructed Orc army
Complete game rules
Introductory quick-start sheet
Full-color map of Mennara
Several brand-new Disks unavailable elsewhere
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Variable Player Powers

name: Diskwars: Legions – Dark Wings over Nochaim
description:
Each Legions set is a complete game, ready to be played by both beginning and experienced DiskWars players. Legions contains everything you need for a two-player game of DiskWars.

There are 4 Legions 2-player Boxes: Dark Wings Over Nochaim (Dragon vs. Mahkim), Last Stand at Dunwarr (Dwarves vs. Orc), Massacre at Godstone Keep (Knight vs. Uthuk), and Nightmare in Nharwood (Elf vs. Undead).


Complete two-player game for Diskwars. Contains:

Pre-constructed Dragon army
Pre-constructed Mahkim army
Complete game rules
Introductory quick-start sheet
Full-color map of Mennara
Several brand-new Disks unavailable elsewhere
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Variable Player Powers

name: Diskwars: Waiqar's Path – The Fire Within
description:
An alliance of Elves and Acolytes has set out through the Wastelands in desperate attempt to reach the citadel of Llovar. They are exhausted, hungry and hounded by enemies on all sides. Things are about to get much worse.

8 Waiqar's Path Army Sets: The Shadow Serpent (Dragonkin), The Bone Coast (Undead), The Broken Crown (Knights), The Fire Within (Elves), The Eternal Horde (Orcs), The Dunwarr Gates (Dwarves), The Ru Lords (Uthuk) and The Welqu Storm (Acolytes).
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Variable Player Powers

name: Diskwars: Broken Shadows – The Hand of Llovar
description:
The Shadow Serpent has awakened, and now is the time of X'ru. But this is no time for superstition, for this is the time of victory and these are the last days.

8 Broken Shadows Army Sets: Prophecy (Dragonkin), Tombs of Ice (Undead), Sword of Daqan (Knights), Latari Wind (Elves), Banner of the Raven (Orcs), Forgotten Forge (Dwarves), Hand of Llovar (Uthuk), Return of One (Acolytes) @ 2 Fixed Flats, 6 Random.
categories: Collectible Components, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Variable Player Powers

name: A Gunslinger's Paradise
description:
A Gunslinger’s Paradise is a tabletop wargame that gives players a plethora of options and mechanics to help them recreate their favorite cinematic or historical gun fights, last stands, bank heists and more.

The game was designed with the intent to give its players maximum customization with list building and equipment so they would be able to bring their favorite characters of the wild west to life and have them perform in the game as they did on the big screen or in a history book.

Here are just a few of the things you will find on the 164 full color pages of “A Gunslinger’s Paradise”:

10 Faction Lists with unique special rules and character classes
28 Customized Scenarios that have been tailored to fit with the faction you are playing as
50+ Weapons and pieces of Equipment
60+ Character Skills and Abilities
25+ Weapon Abilities
15 Pages of Campaign Rules and Content.


… and a whole lot more!

Let A Gunslinger’s Paradise be your guide through the untamed lands of the wild west.

We know a city slicker like yourself isn’t going to get very far without it!

Designed for 28mm, but working 15-35mm

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation

name: Loophole
description:
Loophole is a battle royale on a 5 x 5 grid. Players control a game piece with 9 lives and an immortal ghost piece.

Dice are rolled to determine movement. Squares containing loopholes allow players to transport themselves around the grid. Players navigate opponent's game pieces, ghosts, and a mirror at the center of the board. If a player's life counter die reaches 0 - their game piece is removed from the board, however, their ghost piece remains in play. This offers players who can no longer win an opportunity to cause mischief and avenge their loss. The last player with their game piece on the grid wins.

A unique, optional element is the soundtrack. There are periodic cues in the audio that signal a player should lose a turn. When the soundtrack is over - the game is over. In this variation the player with the most remaining lives wins.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move, Square Grid

name: Warhammer Warriors: Ephrael Stern
description:
A Warhammer version of Lost Worlds based on Games Workshop's 40,000 setting. Each player uses a battle book and chooses a page number for a maneuver for their turn. These are revealed simultaneously and cross-referenced. A chart then shows you which page to turn to see the results of the maneuvers. Players usually end up wounded or in a better position to strike a killing blow.

Warhammer Warriors is slightly more stream-lined than Lost Worlds and plays faster. Warhammer Warriors does not have "behind you" maneuvers and there is a lot more shooting/ranged combat. All characters have a Deathblow maneuver which speed up games if you're in a good position.

Ephrael Stern is number #3 in the series.
mechanics: Rock-Paper-Scissors, Simultaneous Action Selection, Variable Player Powers

name: Frontline
description:
Frontline is a two player card game representing a battle between two armies using highly detailed illustrated cards. The aim of the game is to defeat the opposing players commander by first breaking through their ranks of soldiers, whilst defending your own commander at the same time.
Cards are randomly placed at the start of the game, meaning strategies and tactics will have to be adapted and improvised as each battle unfolds, making every game unique, interesting and engaging.

Easy to understand but difficult to master, with elements of luck thrown in to the mix. Frontline makes each battle diverse and unpredictable.

Use specific cards skills and abilities to gain an upper hand against your opponent, there is no one strategy to win the war!

Stunning illustrations on each card emphasise the raw, gritty feel of being on the battlefield, and make every victory feel truly earned.

The highs and lows of battle. The ability to have your back against a wall as your opponent smashes through your defences, only to have one of his commanders guards flee, potentially changing the course of the battle makes each game truly tense and memorable.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Monopoly: Dinant
description:
The city of Dinant has had its Monopoly since 2010 at the initiative of the Junior Chamber of Commerce.

The game takes up the various tourist attractions of the city.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Ducasse de Mons
description:
It was Jacques Colart who launched the Monopoly de la Ducasse de Mons initiative in 2011.
It was developed in collaboration with players from the Ducasse.
The streets of the plateau retrace the route of the procession.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Lose a Turn, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Dico Games, Parker Brothers, Winning Moves France

name: Recipe Roundup
description:
Recipe Roundup is a card game whose purpose is to learn about the ingredients that make up delicious, healthy meals. Chefs collect the necessary ingredients to complete the perfect recipes. Ingredients are limited so the competition can be dicey. Chefs can strategically stock ingredients in their pantry, while others are left for their friends to “borrow”. If another Chef poaches your key ingredient, you’ll have to scramble or you’ll be in hot water. Chefs can expand their palette with new recipes, but beware of holding too many ingredients or you’ll be left holding the bag (of wasted food).

Players score points for completed Recipes and lose points for anything unused. Each Ingredient and Recipe is assigned a point value (top right corner of the card) based on the rarity of the required Ingredients, as well as the demand for those Ingredients in the Recipes. Collected Ingredients that aren’t made into a Recipe are wasted in the players’ Kitchens. Points for wasted Ingredients are subtracted: wasting food is bad! The player with the most points at the end of the round (or several rounds) wins.

-description from publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Open Drafting

name: Cohorts: Battles of Imperial Rome
description:
Cohorts is a wargame system to land battles in Imperial Rome on 6mm to 20mm scale.
The basic fighting unit is a Century (Rome) and a Unit (Gauls, Germans, and Britons).
These are grouped into Cohorts and Bands.

Turns are performed by alternate activation.

Basic unit types are: infantry, cavalry, artillery (Scorpion), and special units (Nobles, Skirmishers, Chariots, Fanatics).

The objective is to provide an easy, agile, and adaptable rules system for the simulation of combat in the historical period between 200 BC and 200 AD, especially the period of Roman conquests over central Europe and Brittany. The main temporal focus is the Gallic Wars.

The definitions of a range of weapons were based on historical sources and serious publications. Likewise, the rules for combat formations and the historical characteristics of each army were also the target of research in specialized bibliography on the subject.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Warhammer 40,000 (Seventh Edition): Codex Adeptus Astartes – Deathwatch
description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Guess the Fence
description:
Protect your farm from all kinds of harm! You’ve decided to add fences to your large farm. Anything to keep the nosy neighbours away, right? But shhh, you have to build them secretly! Whoever guesses the fences made by the other farmer, wins. Think smart, guess patiently and fence away!

In Guess the Fence, you must protect your farm from all kinds of harm. The goal is to guess all the fences made by your opponent. Each player starts with: a farm board, an erasable marking sheet, 3 long fences, 3 diagonal fences and 8 small fences, one red and green marker. The partition board is placed between the players. Each farm board has a grid of 25 numbers.On their board, each player makes 4 shapes using their fences - a square, a rectangle, a big triangle and a small triangle. The fences are placed along the dotted lines only. The circle of the fence is the vertex of the shape and must be placed on a number. The end of a fence must meet another vertex. The shapes must not have shared vertices or sides. Once both players have made their fences, the game begins.On your turn, you can either guess a vertex or guess a shape. When you guess a vertex-
Look at your marking sheet and call out a number where you think your opponent may have a vertex
Your opponent looks at their farm board and tells you if it is right or wrong.
If correct, they say ‘hit’ and you shade that vertex number in green.
if wrong, they say ‘miss’ and you shade that vertex number in red.
When you guess a shape (calling out the vertex of that shape)-
Look at your marking sheet and call out a shape where you think your opponent has made one
You must say the name of the shape and all its vertices. for e.g. “do you have a triangle at 3,4 and 9?”
Your opponent, then, looks at their farm board and tells you if it is right or wrong.
If correct, they say ‘hit’ and you get 3 points, and shade the shape!
If wrong, they say ‘miss’ and you lose 1 point!
When a player guesses all the shapes of the other, the game ends. The person with the highest points, wins!

Guess The Fence is a guess-and-write game that will help burgeon your visual reasoning and creativity. It’s perfect for families to have a great time but also introduce kids to an innovative learning experience. Enjoy with them as they apply their knowledge of geometry to make shapes with fences and develop essential skills that go beyond academics. See their creativity and imagination soar right before your eyes! This is a simple but highly addictive educational game.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Deduction, Line Drawing, Paper-and-Pencil, Secret Unit Deployment

name: What a Tanker 40,000 (fan expansion for What a Tanker)
description:
What a Tanker! 40,000 is a modification of the TooFatLardies tank combat game What a Tanker!
It changes the setting from World War II to Games Workshop’s Warhammer 40,000 universe.
It features:

100+ new Tank Statistics
9 new Career Ladders
New special rules to represent 41st millennium technology



—description from the publisher

This game is a not-for-profit fan-made work based on existing IPs and unofficial modifications of What a Tanker! a copy of which is needed to play
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fan Expansion, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Fields of Blood
description:
Fields of Blood is a wargame system to land battles in the historical period from the Hundred Years’ Wars (1337 to 1453) until the Wars of the Roses (between 1455 and 1485) - but it can be easily adapted to any medieval period - on 6mm to 20mm scale.

The objective is to provide an easy, agile, and adaptable rules system for the simulation of combat in that historical period. The definitions of a range of weapons were based on historical sources and serious publications. Likewise, the rules for combat formations and the historical characteristics of each army were also the target of research in specialized bibliography on the subject.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Simulation

name: Rifts in Reality: The Bloodline
description:
Rifts in Reality is a cooperative choose-your-own-adventure skirmish board game, with a highly thematic and rich narrative, with many roads to victory.

“When rifts starts to emerge in open air and nightmares breaks into the fabric of reality, you must choose to either follow your foretold path and safe route, or go against your destiny and gamble with your life.“

Rifts in Reality is a game about interwoven timelines, strategic puzzles and narrative exploration. Your biggest challenge is your own nightmare, as the difference between reality and dreams become illusive. What about you or world is real?

Each story is a book and each page is a hex based game board, that your will explore and move your highly detailed miniatures across; finding clues, weapons and other remedies to fight your nightmare. As locations are solved, you will progress through the book, trying to keep you sanity, explore the map, move your figure and encounter new areas on each page. The story will guide you through the adventure, if you can survive it or do you give in to your nightmares?

Five books, five stories, five characters and five unique nightmares, set in different timelines, all woven together as one season: The Bloodline.

In the year 878, we will save the viking Toke, fighting to regain his honour and pay his depth to the mythical Neck. In the year 1720, we will help Mary Luccraft from Devonshire find her lost son, stolen by foul pixies. In the year 1919, we will visit H. P. Lovecraft in his youth and battle his night terrors, monsters beyond our realm, testing Howards sanity. In the year 1950, we will help Lydia Breaux through apartheid, voodoo and conspiracies, closing rifts before government agents can exploit them. In the year 2468, Jonathan will be up against the ultimately battle, humanities biggest nightmare, our own extinction.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Dice, Exploration, Fantasy, Horror, Puzzle, Science Fiction, Space Exploration
mechanics: Die Icon Resolution, Movement Points, Multiple Maps, Narrative Choice / Paragraph, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Warhammer 40,000: Imperial Armour – Volume One: Second Edition – Imperial Guard
description: The book is re-print of an old edition Imperial Armour Volume One - Imperial Guard and Imperial Navy with the rules which cover new rulebook edition. This volume focuses on the Imperial Guard and Imperial Tanks. This book is part of the Imperial Armour series of books.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Baseball Wars: Hangin' Curves and Heaters edition
description:
1 on 1 card game great for ALL ages
No boards, graphs, pen/pencil or dice needed
(Just cards, instructions included)
Multiple ways to play (different outs or inning numbers) Great for travel, easy game play, easy to put away
Can be played on an airplane tray or the backseat of your car
NEW INVENTION - Made in the USA
sturdy product - professional print

1 player pitches, the other bats, after 3 outs, switch.
Made to play 3 outs & 3 innings

Its a game of baseball, after the two teams (players) have decided to play 3 innings or 4 innings with each inning being 6 out if you want :) (extra game style)(with multiple decks) 9 or 10 innings you play until the end of the game
mechanics: Action/Event, Turn Order: Pass Order, Turn Order: Progressive

name: Monopoly: RCSC
description:
A Monopoly about the Sporting de Charleroi, created in 1904.
Features 22 of the club legendary players.


Fondé en 1904, le Sporting de Charleroi s’est forgé un nom au sein de l’élite du football belge. Au fil des décennies, le Matricule 22 a vécu de nombreuses épopées fastes mais aussi traversé des périodes plus délicates: Vice-champions nationaux en 1969, finalistes de la Coupe de Belgique en 1978 et 1993, les Zèbres ont par ailleurs connu les joies des rencontres européennes en 1994 et 2015. L’année 2012 a marqué un tournant dans l’histoire récente du club. Un changement de direction allait insuffler une nouvelle dynamique portée par un novateur plan stratégique 3-6-9 avec, in fine, des ambitions sportives revues à la hausse concrétisées par une qualification pour les play-offs 1 ( top 6) mais aussi pour les tours préliminaires de l’Europa League. Le Sporting est redevenu respecté et crédible sur la scène nationale, capable de se mêler chaque année à la lutte pour les premières places du championnat. Ce jeu est dédié à Jean-Noël Antoine, lui qui avait gardé son âme de gamin et qui était si fier de son club!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Track Movement, Trading

name: Monopoly: Wavre
description:
The city of Wavre has had its Monopoly since 2010.

The game takes up the streets, heritage, culture and folklore of the city.

Only 1000 copies were published.


Située au cœur du Brabant Wallon, à quelques minutes de la capitale, Wavre se découvre au creux de deux collines, nichée dans la vallée de la Dyle. Fière de son « Maca », une statue d’un jeune garçon qui escalade le muret de l’hôtel de ville, elle l’est aussi de son sens de l’hospitalité et de son centre pittoresque avec ses charmantes rues et ruelles piétonnes qui invitent à la flânerie. Chef-lieu de la province du Brabant wallon, Wavre est aussi reconnue pour son patrimoine, sa culture et son folklore avec sa délicieuse tarte au Stofé, ses géants, le carillon de l’église Saint-Jean-Baptiste ou encore le jeu de Jean et Alice pour n’en citer que quelques-uns.

Enrichie par de nombreux commerces de proximité et animée au quotidien par ses citoyens, Wavre regorge de vie et revendique cet esprit frondeur qui lui va si bien.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Set Collection, Trading

name: Xola
description:
In Xola, you take control of the mighty Aztec Empire in the height of its power. Players have access to a wide variety of cards in order to impose their presence on the different cities surrounding the grand Aztec capital of Tenochtitlan. The player that has the strongest presence in the region wins the game.

Xola is a 2-4 player competitive game of domination. Matches take 20 to 30 minutes. Using a shared 100 card deck, players take turns and place cards on Aztec cities, increasing their power and dominance on the map. The game is played in rounds. After a round ends, new cities become available for the players to claim. The game ends when all cities on the map have been claimed. Whoever earns the most points wins.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Modular Board, Open Drafting

name: Bias Effect: A game of cognitive combat
description:
The Premise
You are a world-renowned computer programmer and part of the team responsible for giving us the first android. You have reached the final stage of programming before sending your creation into the world. There’s only one thing left to do — give it some political beliefs! Unfortunately, your colleagues don’t agree with your views. Program the "correct" beliefs into your android before it becomes autonomous.

The Game
Bid for control of political beliefs to ensure that when the android reaches AUTONOMY, its composition of beliefs match your POLITICAL IDENTITY! Employ ALGORITHM CARDS to slow down and frustrate your opponents or to propel yourself to victory! The game consists of 224 cards, 1 Autonomy Counter, and 100 tokens (in-game currency; you'll need to supply the tokens--we suggest poker chips or something similar).

The Bias Effect
But be warned! Just like in real life, the more beliefs of one kind the android has, the harder it is to program beliefs of the opposite type. Victory will only come to those who learn to use or overcome this frustrating dimension of thought!

The Game's Appeal
Politics have become so polarizing and divisive in recent years, people need to de-stress by laughing about the absurdity of it all! We think this game can do just that.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Print & Play
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Bias, Take That

name: Warhammer 40,000 (Seventh Edition): Codex – Imperial Agents
description: The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Monopoly: Thuin
description:
Official Monopoly game for the City of Thuin in Belgium.

The game is based on the riches of the thudinien heritage will be accompanied by a booklet explaining all the places and symbols that are in the game.


Thuin, cité médiévale juchée sur un éperon rocheux.
En plein cœur du centre ancien, les petites rues pavées, les postys et les ruelles sinueuses nous plongent dans les couloirs du temps…
Par le sud, les jardins suspendus se déclinent vers la vallée de la Biesmelle.
Au nord, la Sambre surprend par ses méandres verdoyants, ses écluses manuelles, ses péniches marchandes, son quartier des bateliers.
Vous reconnaîtrez toujours Thuin par son Beffroi car où que vous vous trouviez dans la ville, il est là, il domine, tel un phare…
A cela s’ajoutent également l’Abbaye d’Aulne, Ragnies un des « Plus Beaux Villages de Wallonie », la Distillerie à la Ferme de la Cour, le Château du Fosteau, le Moulin de Donstiennes, le Hameau d’Ossogne, la Maison de l’Imprimerie, le musée du Tramway vicinal, le RAVeL, la ducasse aux cerises et encore bien d’autres…
Sans oublier une tradition vieille de plus de 360 ans : la St-Roch. C
haque 3e dimanche de mai, Thuin vit au son des fifres et tambours par son folklore typique de l’entre-Sambre-et-Meuse, plus de 2500 marcheurs se rassemblent et défilent en cortège à travers la ville.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Income, Lose a Turn, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading
publishers: Dico Games, Hasbro, Winning Moves France

name: Warhammer 40,000 (Third Edition): Codex Battlezone – Cityfight
description:
The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.


User summary:
Codex Battlezone: Cityfight is an expansion codex book for Warhammer 40,000 3rd Edition. This codex covers battles in urban terrain with special rules, army list updates, equipment for fighting in cities, terrain modeling, campaign design and scenarios.

From the back cover:
Throughout the universe, warring races descend on each other's cities bringing destruction with them. In the shattered ruins, old generals are forced to learn new tricks while their soldiers hope merely to survive. Inside you will find:

Cityfight core rules explaining how to fight battles in urban terrain.

Codex modifications needed to amend army organization for Cityfight.

New equipment for attackers and defenders.

The Battle for Vogen. Background details for a famous cityfight in the Cadian Gate.

Cityscaping. Instructions on how to make your own buildings and assemble a Cityfight battlezone.

Gaming ideas. Advice on how to play campaign to decide the fate of a city.

ISBN: 1-84154-093-5
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Warhammer 40,000 (Third Edition): Codex – Witch Hunters
description:
The Warhammer 40,000 Codex books contain the complete rules for playing various armies in Warhammer 40,000. They also contain in-depth painting guides, army lists, and much more.


User summary:

Codex: Witch Hunters is an expansion codex book for Warhammer 40,000 3rd Eition. It is one of three books either published or proposed about the Ordo Hereticus (Codex: Daemonhunters, Codex: Witch Hunters, Codex: Alienhunters).

From the back cover:

The Witch Hunters of the Ordo Hereticus are perhaps the most sinister of all Inquisitors as the threats they must face lurk not in the depths of space or the Warp, but amongst the everyday citizenry of the Imperium; the witch, the mutant, the heretic and the fallen cleric. Such abominations are an affront to the Emperor and together with their Chamber Militant, the Sisters of Battle, they purge evil from the worlds of Man with the cleansing fire of purity.

ISBN: 1-84154-485-X
