name: Russian roulette: Risk.Be_Smart.Survive!
description:
In this fast-paced board (and safe) version of Russian Roulette, you try to be the last one standing.

You may play risky pulling the trigger or smart by bribing your opponents to take your place. Use energy cards to facilitate your position or make it difficult for your opponents.

In each phase of a round, a player is eliminated and the others gain victory points, until only one remains. Collect the most victory points in a specified number of rounds to be the winner!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Deduction, Player Elimination, Push Your Luck, Simulation
publishers: (Looking for a publisher), Three Themes Games

name: Greedy Monkey
description:
A game of 10 rounds, a player has to roll the DiiCii to get a number and a color
After the first roll, everyone gets to ask the player rolling the DiiCii, “Are you greedy?”
The objective is to consecutively get numbers on the DiiCii of the same colour. This results in adding on to their scores.
However, if the player gets a different coloured number on the DiiCii the resulting score will come down to zero.
At the end of 10 rounds, whosoever gets the maximum score wins
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Push Your Luck

name: Tug of Paw
description:
A one card game to play anywhere! Put three fingers on your side of the card, count down from three and start tugging! (Make an animal sound on "GO!")
If your opponent lets go of the card, you win the round. Take one finger off the card, then play again. The first player to win three rounds wins!


Keep Tug of Paw in your wallet for scrappy action, anytime!
Play on any surface you can get your pesky paws on!
Take the lead, and you'll have a less 'paw'erful grip!


—description from the designer
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Cartolan: Trade Winds
description:
As the old powers surrounding your Home City look hungrily at controlling the mysterious Silk Road, innovations in harnessing wind and water offer your Culture a chance to connect this wider world of trade partners first. Start a new age of exploration for fair trade, to leave a different legacy than rapacious colonisation.

Race your Adventurers out with silk and lacquer wings, effortlessly riding trade winds or striving against them and packing overland. Earn rewards by expanding your city's shared atlas, whether joining old maps or drawing anew.

Establish trade routes by recruiting Innkeepers along your way, giving future Adventurers rest so they can quickly revisit exotic ports and trade for the silks that give your Home City's edge.

Perhaps you'll even discover the Mythical City and a second home far away. But always remember, there are rival cultures even within your city, and they may not be above a little piracy!

Only the culture that gathers silks fastest can weave a different future.

—description from the designer
categories: Adventure, Medieval, Nautical, Pirates, Renaissance, Travel
mechanics: Catch the Leader, Chaining, Grid Movement, Highest-Lowest Scoring, Map Addition, Movement Template, Network and Route Building, Ownership, Race, Rock-Paper-Scissors, Square Grid, Tile Placement, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up

name: Правдец (Trued up)
description:
Ready to have some fun? Trued up is a game that rocks any party. The box contains two decks of cards and a lot of funny situations and fun. Each turn, you choose an "True" or "Dare" card and complete the task. Whoever has the most completed tasks by the end of the game wins. This simple game will rocks even a bored company!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Acting

name: Stop That Toy!
description: Track down a Danny the Dragon toy for your daughter's Christmas present in this holiday themed at-home escape room.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deduction, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Resilience: Survive and Thrive
description:
Resilience Survive and Thrive is a tabletop card game that aims to teach its players lessons on balanced development and natural resiliency under the climate change lens.

Each round is divided into several phases: Draw, Activity, Impact, Community and Crisis.

In the Draw phase, each player draws 2 cards from the Development deck. If the number of cards from the players' hands exceeds 7, they must discard the extra cards.

In the Activity phase, each player can do up to 3 activities. An Activity can be a combination of any of the following:

Restoring an Environment - turning over an environment card back to its position on the playmat.
Playing an Investment - placing an Investment card from your hand into your community.
Playing a House - placing any card facedown and sideways from your hand into your community. Houses are Gray Investments and give 1 Development Point (DP).



In the Apply Impact phase, players will specific impacts of the Investment cards they have placed onto the playmat. Different Investments have different impacts:

Sustainable Investments increase DPs depending on how sustainable its associated Environment is.
Commercial Investment can destroy the environment, removing 1 Environment card from the playmat, but also gives the player 4 DP.
Conservation Investment restore 1 particular Environment card but does not give any DP.


In the Community phase, players can play 1 Action card. If the player does not play an Action card, they can take 1 card from the Development deck instead or simply pass. Action cards are used to gain an upper hand against the player's opponents. Place the Action card into the discard pile once played. In this phase, players can also cast votes to close down one Investment at play. Voted Investments go into the discard pile.

Lastly, in the Crisis phase, the top card is revealed and its effect applied.

If the revealed Crisis is an Extreme Weather Event, players must determine its effect by counting the associated Environment, then apply the destruction to each community.
If the revealed Crisis is an End Game Crisis, destroy all cards of the specific Environment type and place the End Game card on its slot in the playmat. The game continues as long as the 3 End Game slots are not yet occupied.


After the crisis, return to the Draw phase to start a new round.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Cooperative Game, Semi-Cooperative Game, Sudden Death Ending

name: Cockleshell Heroes: Operation Frankton, December 11, 1942
description:
Cockleshell Heroes is a solitaire play game portraying Operation Frankton. Operation Frankton was a commando raid on ships based in the German occupied French port of Bordeaux during the Second World War. The raid was carried out by a small unit of the Royal Marines know as the “Royal Marines Boom Patrol Detachment”, who were part of a combined operations transported by the submarine, HMS Tuna. Variant rules for two players are included.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: NUM
description:
NUM is a card game where each player will start with 5 cards, each turn is divided into 4 phases: play, replace, summon and discard. When playing cards from your hand to the board, you will take the cards that have a lower number than your card, seeking to complete the requirements of each warrior for his invocation.

Each warrior requires a number of spirits and portals depending on the number of victory points awarded, if any player runs out of cards at the end of their turn, the rest of the players must discard their hands and 5 new cards will be dealt to each player.

The first player to get 5 victory points for quick game or 8 points for normal game wins.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Гномы воришки (Gnomes thieves)
description:
Do you put away your toys at night? If you leave them on the floor, night thieves will come for them. Little gnomes think that children don't need toys and take them for themselves! Let's take our toys from the thieves!

Every turn, you roll dice that defines gnome to find. Then everyone race to spot correct gnome on the board and trying to grab the correct toy as quickly as possible.

The winner is the one who takes five toys.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Speed Matching

name: Dinostone
description:
From a set of 32 cards, 20 different cards are selected for each game, and two players battle using those cards.

The 20 cards at the start of the game and the order of the cards are random, but after that, there is no drawing, etc., and the use of the cards can limit the opponent's actions on his/her next turn.
There is no element of luck other than the order of the cards at the beginning of the game, and the game is a severe game in which victory or defeat is determined solely by playing.

There is a concept of cost, but there is no need to save mana to pay the cost, and accidents do not occur.
(You will know what I mean when you try it!)

It is possible to mix and match cards from the planned second and subsequent expansions.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Move Through Deck, Rondel

name: Шот шпионский (Spy shot)
description:
Spy Shot is a drinking game with thematic tasks. Players become spies, intelligence and action heroes. You can be in the shoes of James Bond, spending time with friends.

On your turn, you either complete a task or drink. For tasks you get bonuses, but you decide whether to spend them or not.

Sometimes you can draw animals cards from the deck. If they appears you should start making special move. The game will end when somebody draws "Mission Accomplished" card from the deck. The winner is the one who has the most completed tasks.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Acting

name: Terachess II
description:
An evolution of Terachess I, Terachess II is a large Chess variant with 26 different kinds of pieces played on a 16 x 16 board.

Full list of piece types with their values:

N/A - King - (King's move + Initial King's jump that replaces castling)
10.2 - Amazon - (Knight's move + Queen's move)
8.4 - Eagle - (Unique move pattern, similar to Rhinoceros)
8.3 - Queen - (Queen's move)
8.2 - Sorceress - (Combines Cannon and Crocodile)
6.9 - Marshall - (Combines Rook and Knight)
6.1 - Rhinoceros - (Unique move pattern, similar to Eagle)
6.0 - Admiral - (Combines Rook and King)
6.0 - Lion - (Combines Elephant, Machine and Knight)
5.8 - Duchess - (Jumps up to 3 squares in any direction)
5.4 - Buffalo - (Combines Knight, Camel and Giraffe)
5.3 - Cardinal - (Combines Knight and Bishop)
5.0 - Rook - (Rook's move)
5.0 - Cannon - (Cannon's move from Xiangqi)
4.4 - Missionary - (Combines Bishop and King)
4.1 - Centaur - (Combines Knight and King)
3.4 - Bishop - (Bishop's move)
3.3 - Crocodile - (Diagonal counterpart of the Cannon)
2.4 - Troll - (Combines classic Pawn and 3-step jump)
2.3 - Prince - (Combines King's move and 2-step no-capture move)
2.2 - Machine - (Jumps up to 2 squares orthogonally)
2.0 - Knight - (Knight's move)
2.0 - Elephant - (Jumps up to 2 squares diagonally)
1.8 - Camel - (Jumps like an extended knight)
1.7 - Giraffe - (Jumps to the opposite square of a 3x4 rectangle)
0.5 - Pawn - (Pawn that can also move 2 squares forward from any place)

The main change to the regular Chess rules pertains to obligatory promotion upon reaching the last rank of the board.
Only the following pieces are promoted:

Knight > Buffalo
Camel > Buffalo
Giraffe > Buffalo
Elephant > Lion
Machine > Lion
Centaur > Lion
Prince > Amazon
Pawn > Queen
Troll > Queen (Must move 1-step to promote)
mechanics: Grid Movement, Pattern Movement, Square Grid, Static Capture

name: Godtear: Fenra, Wolf of the End Times & Chainless Curs
description:
Feasting on godtears has blessed Fenra with unnatural size, and rumours abound that her ascent to godhood could bring about the end times in a rain of flaming crystals.

No wolf is complete without her pack - Fenra’s piercing howls summon a snarling pack of Chainless Curs, the cunning gnolls who hunt down and surround any who escape her razor-sharp wrath.

Inside this box is everything you need to add the Maelstrom champion Fenra, Wolf of The End Times & Chainless Curs, to your Godtear warband. Use this expansion with any Godtear starter set.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Sci-Fi Skirmish Scenarios
description:
Welcome to The Sprawl…

Sci-fi skirmishes are an increasingly popular genre of war game but they are more dependent than most on good scenarios to keep them varied and exciting. John Lambshead has taken the work out of scenario building. He presents a selection of thirty-six missions of varying complexity, each with clear objectives and victory conditions, a map showing set-up zones and some with special rules. Although they are set in his imagined dystopian city of Civitas Cavernum (aka The Sprawl), with its factions of Scavs, Proctors, Cultists and Corporates, the scenarios are designed to be adaptable to almost any setting and set of rules (including those published in the author’s One-hour Skirmish Wargames). In addition, there are no less than three mini-campaigns that link the scenarios together in various combinations.

But that is not all. John Lambshead gives advice on designing your own scenarios and campaigns and there is even a set of tables allowing you to quickly create them through random dice rolls, ensuring almost infinite variety to your games. Finally, there is a useful reference section listing websites of rules publishers and manufacturers of suitable miniatures and model terrain. Welcome to The Sprawl (but keep your gun close and your mask on).
mechanics: Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game

name: Cruel Tunes
description:
Cruel Tunes is the perfect culmination of music, laughter, and roasting your stupid friends. Perfect for parties, pregames, or the get together after your grandma's funeral. No matter what this game is a lot of fun and you're sure to have a laugh or two while playing some tunes that define a generation. Feel free to create your own playlists or utilize the ones we have created on Spotify or Apple Music.

Put on a song, lay down the funniest reason you'd be listening to that song, let a judge decide the winner. First to 8 cards wins.

No music knowledge is required. Simply play a song and roast the judge based on the reason they would be listening to the song.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Music, Party Game
mechanics: Player Judge

name: Power Rangers: Heroes of the Grid – Scenario Book 2
description: The follow-up to the Fan Appreciation Kit, Scenario Book 2 includes the next 12 narrative Scenarios, previously individually released online as Scenarios 13-24.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Variable Player Powers

name: Gemwielders: Dagger
description:
A brand new Gembearer (starting deck) for Gemwielders Deckbuilding Game. It comes with two handy cards to track life and power.

The Dagger is made for the cunning tactician, alternating feint attacks and premeditated strikes, meant to cause maximum harm. And what better feeling than to lay a trap and watch your opponent walk into it unsuspectingly?
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting

name: Cochechs
description:
Based on old "Paper-and-pencil" game, Cochechs is a racing board game where nothing is left to chance. With no dice, player move their cars using vector moves.

The game includes 8 boards printed on both sides. Player will be able to build a different circuit for every race. There are a huge number of combinations available.

The game also includes cards that give to the pilots extra speed, extra break or they can disturb the rivals.
mechanics: Catch the Leader, Paper-and-Pencil, Race

name: 9Stax Card Game
description:
Each player has 9 stacks of 4 cards. The goal of the game is to play every card in your 9 stacks. The play style uses some common techniques, such as matching the color or text of the previously played card, but has a number of interesting twists. A unique element of the game is that every number card played causes all players to switch to that numbered stack. You are constantly moving and reevaluating your strategy as the cards in your hand change. Also, some cards allow a player to swap a stack with another player, discard and entire stack at one time, choose an opponent's stack to look at, and cause an opponent to create a new stack.

Each player has an Immunity tile which can be played once per game to block a card played against them. There is an intriguing mix of strategy, random chance, and mischief that gets more fun the more times you play the game.

The game is designed for 2-4 players age 8+ and has been play tested with players as old as 80 years. The game consists of 200 game cards, 36 numbered tokens, 4 Immunity tiles and a direction of play disc. Play time tends to be 30-40 min. per game.
mechanics: Move Through Deck, Once-Per-Game Abilities, Turn Order: Progressive

name: Dicing with Tea
description:
This is a cut-out-and-play game with a food/baking theme.

Players take turns to roll dice to build up ingredient tokens, then get a chance to make recipes from a random selection of cards.

First to complete each category of recipes wins!

This game is a variation of Dicing with Dinner.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Race, Random Production

name: Pantanal
description:
"The Pantanal is the largest floodplain biome on the planet, located in three countries in South America: Paraguay, Bolivia and, for the most part, Brazil.

Every year, starting in November, rainfall largely increases and raises the level of the rivers, flooding the plains. In flooded areas, a large amount of fish is retained in lagoons and bays, attracting many birds in search of food. In May, the rains stop and the waters begin to slowly recede. This annual cycle of floods renews fauna and flora, maintaining the ecological balance of the biome.

In Pantanal, players add a Landscape Tile to the group of tiles in the center of the table, forming a landscape of fields, lakes and rivers throughout the game.

The tile placement is very important, as each player has a Character Card to score at the end of the game according to the distribution of that character in the tiles landscape. Each player keeps his identity a secret, being able, at any time during the game, to make guesses about other players' characters. Correct guesses score Victory Points at the end of the game.

When placing a tile, the player can also receive Guaviras tokens, which can be used to buy tiles or Biome Cards, with objectives that score extra points at the end of the game. The player with the most points is the winner.

-description from publisher
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Hidden Roles, Tile Placement

name: Xor0: A Card Game
description:
A Xor0 deck consists of 63 cards. Each card has a unique combination of six dots. Each dot is identified by both a color and a number. A player wins by quickly finding "Xor0" groups of cards. Techniques for finding Xor0 groups include visual pattern matching, dot counting, binary numbers math, or any combination thereof.

A Xor0 group is a group of cards where each dot color appears an even number of times. The name of the game derives from the fact that after summing up the numbers on each card and applying the mathematical XOR operation to them has the result zero.

The game is played in rounds. A round starts by taking seven cards from a shuffled deck and placing them face up on the table. There is always at least one Xor0 group present in the seven cards. The player who first spots a Xor0 group announces it by saying "Xor0!" and pointing out the group. All player collaboratively validate that the group is indeed a Xor0 group. If confirmed, the player who found the group takes the cards in the group. Otherwise, the player must pause until another player finds a valid group. After a player found and took the cards, the seven cards on the table are replenished from the deck and all players look for the next Xor0 group. The round ends as soon as the last card is drawn from the deck. The player who collected the most cards during a round wins. Ties are broken by number of dots collected.

The difficulty of the game can be adjusted by playing with a partial deck that omits one (or two or three) of the six dot colors.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Pattern Recognition, Score-and-Reset Game, Set Collection

name: A Steadfast and Violent Affair: The Battle of Lundy's Lane, July 25, 1814
description:
A Steadfast and Violent Affair: The Battle of Lundy's Lane is an introductory level wargame. It is part of the Battles for Canada Series of games that portray famous battles fought for control of that country during the War of 1812.

Each hex is approximately 50 yards across, a regular or militia infantry unit is 250-350 men, First Nation and Dragoon units are 80 to 100 men, and artillery units represent 2 or 3 guns. A turn represents one hour of time.

Players use a standard deck of playing cards (a custom series card set is available from the publisher) to activate their units. A six-sided die is used to resolve combats (assault and fire) as well as other game events.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Wishland: Dreams from America
description:
Wishland: Dreams from America is the first expansion pack for Wishland.

It will include:
- Components for a fifth player
- A new card type
- New achievement tiles
- Updates to the base game
- New entrepreneurs

"Wishland: Dreams from America" 's release brings a new type of cards that combines the effects of rides, actors, restaurants and hotels from the base game.

-description from designer
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Income, Set Collection, Worker Placement

name: Chi è di scena!: Il gioco all'improvviso
description: All ready: lights, curtain and... the game begins! With Chi è di scena! you will immerse yourself in the unpredictable world of improvisation! Two teams of actors will compete in beats, facing improbable situations and taking on the role of the most diverse characters in order to win and get to the end of the show to take the thunderous applause of the public! Get out of the box, the only limit is your imagination!
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Election: A Game of Secret States
description:
2 to 4 players vie to become President of the United States by earning the most electoral votes in the election. Players will choose a party at the start of the game: Defense, Economy, Government, or Society. Each party has unique special abilities. As a candidate, you will strive to earn states, especially high-value ones, and keep those states safely in your possession.

Players take turns drawing Campaign Cards to earn resources: either Cash or Support. At the same time, they will build piles of four Campaign Cards to earn State Cards. Also in the draw pile are Event Cards and Staff Boost Cards. Event Cards will have either positive or negative effects. Staff Boost cards provide a powerful bonus that lasts until removed by an opponent.

As players earn State Cards they will have to decide which ones to reveal by “securing” and which ones to keep secret. Players will form their strategy based on their state values, party abilities, and Staff Boost cards in play. They can spend resources to secure states, steal states from other players, and remove Staff Boost Cards. Some strategies might include, but are not limited to: bluffing, hoarding states, going after opponents, or timely use of party abilities.

Any player who has secured 10 states has the power to end the game, but must consider secured and secret (unsecured) states in their calculations. Once the election is held, all electoral votes (secured and unsecured) are tallied. Highest total wins.

—description from designer
mechanics: Hidden Victory Points, Multi-Use Cards, Once-Per-Game Abilities, Variable Player Powers

name: Who Stinks?
description:
One of you stinks and you must find out who it is. Everybody plays with five cards, and you draw cards after each turn. Plus cards increase the stink level and minus cards decrease the stink level. Special cards enable more advanced gameplay strategies and include Multiplier cards, Zero cards, and Any Number -5 to +5 cards. Your goal is to stay in the safe zone – 30 or less – and force other players to push the stink level above 30 into the danger zone. The game gets more and more intense as the stink level approaches the danger zone. Use challenge cards to immediately skip turn to your opponents and force them to take actions which greatly increase their chances of triggering the danger zone. The Stinkbomb card moves the stink level instantly to 30 and the challenged player must play with five new cards from the draw pile while trying to stay in the safe zone. The Stinkbug card forces players to play a random card from their hand and hope to land in the safe zone. This gets more and more challenging as the game progresses. The Stinkbomb Shield and Stinkbug Repellent cards push the challenge back to the player who started the challenge which leads to unexpected twists and turns with unpredictable outcomes.
If your card pushes the stink level into the danger zone you must flip over one of the five stink pile cards which are placed face-down in a fan-like pattern under the draw pile to see if you are the Stinker, or prove everyone wrong:

If you get the You Stink card, bummer, you are the Stinker and you lost the game!
If you get the Not Me card, great, you’re saved! Quickly drop your cards and yell “Not Me!!!”. Congrats, you won the game! All other players must hurry to quickly drop their cards as well. The last player to drop their cards is the Stinker!
If you get the Stinkbug or Stinkbomb card, you can still win! Play them against any player to start the danger zone battle. The player’s goal in the danger zone battle is to bring the stink level back into the safe zone – 30 or less – or challenge another player!


You also win if you collect all the plus or minus cards, all cards of the same kind, or plus and minus cards that all add up to zero. Just drop your cards at any time and yell “Not Me!!! The last player to drop their cards is the Stinker!
mechanics: Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Take That

name: Planet 28 (Second Edition)
description:
An updated edition of the narrative Sci fi skirmish hit, containing all the rules needed to create your own warband of unique charactrers and play out fierce and lethal battles on the tabletop. Also included are complete vehicle creation rules, Solo and co-op play, campaign play and progression and a whole host of extra optional rules desined to make planet 28 into the ultimate toolbox of tabletop violence.

From power armourerd warriors wielding hightech plasma rifles, to blood stained barbarians fighting tooth and nail, to armoured behemoths decked out with city crushing cannons, Planet 28 allows you to create profiles for any combination of miniatures.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling

name: Calamandara
description:
Calamandara is a competitive and strategic board game, playable by 2 to 4 people. Here the playeres, called Travelers, must compete against each other to reach the center point of the board. Each traveler starts the game at the beginning of their respective board and to move his pawn around the the grid board he needs to use Dogmatic Symbols, which are tokens that have specific attributes.

Each Dogmatic Symbol has a different function that will help travelers navigate the board. As an example, some symbols help the traveler move faster while others can disrupt their opponents' journey to the center of the board.

While the use of Dogmatic Symbols happens and the players' pawns advance across the board, the travelers also use the Memory Cards, which serve to intensify their moves or cause sudden changes in their opponents' strategy. Those special cards are limited and travelers need to choose the right time to use them wisely.

Each Traveler will perform 4 types of actions or phases on their turn:

1st Phase: The traveler will Acquire Dogmatic Symbols using Symbol Cards.

2nd Phase: The traveler will be able to Insert the Dogmatic Symbols on the board to start setting up his movement strategy.

3rd Phase: The traveler will be able to Move his Traveler Token (pawn) on the board, according to the positioning of the Dogmatic Symbols on his board.

4th Phase: The traveler will be able to Reserve, Discard and Acquire Memory Cards.

The Memory Cards can be used at any time in the game, providing a unique dynamism in all matches.

To achieve victory, it is necessary to create a good strategy and make the right decisions, thinking about the present and the future. The multiple possibilities of using Dogmatic Symbols and Memory Cards will make players explore reasoning and risk management in their decisions.

And the objective is simple: Whoever reaches the center of the board first wins!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Area Movement, Events, Finale Ending, Grid Movement, Hand Management, Race

name: Mi Amigurumi
description:
A GAME AND A TOY TOGETHER FOR RESTLESS AND CREATIVE CHILDREN

This is an original proposal, ideal for playing at home: play with your Amigurumi doll, bring it to life, make it a part of your adventures through activities and cards with proposals for movements and spaces.

Mi Amigurumi brings two ways to play inside the houses: MOVE and SEARCH.

The first proposal is a game of motor skills, attention and dexterity, where the participants have to use their bodies to move the doll to different parts of the house. Ideal for restless and creative children.

The second combines memory and attention, with an original "treasure hunt" style proposal, where players must look for their hidden friend. Here memory and attention play a fundamental role.

WHAT IS A FRIEND?

This set comes with a knitted doll. His kind are called AMIGURUMI, what a strange name! It sounds that weird because they come from Japan.

They have been made there for many years with a particular technique and some people believe that they are special because by giving them away with good wishes, they become a faithful companion of whoever receives them. Give away a game and a toy together.

MORE THAN A GAME

The AMIGURUMI game is a game that helps us contribute to the cognitive and emotional development of children in a fun way. It seeks to articulate the natural tendency to learn by playing with the possibility of enhancing their abilities.

In the instructions you will also find a small guide and advice for adults; to help (us) to get more involved in the fantasy world, which is created by playing.
mechanics: Acting

name: Boba Goba
description:
Through their love of tabletop games and boba tea, the founders of Landes Toys and Games LLC bring you BOBA GOBA!

The Goal of the game is simple, earn as much points as you can by collecting Boba cards but be careful because behind every turn of a card may be a hazard.

Game play is as simple as it gets, all the cards are distributed amongst the players and placed face down. Players then take turns flipping over cards that will either earn them points, affect other players or set aside to help themselves.
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Federation Commander: Gunboats Attack
description:
“Captain, there’s a flotilla of six gunboats headed for us.”

“Shields up! Arm all weapons! Red alert!”

The small, scrappy gunboats make their way to Federation Commander. Weak individually, in a flotilla of six, they are a match for a cruiser and can damage a dreadnought enough that it won’t just buff out. In some ways, they are eggs armed with sledgehammers.

This title includes a 16-page rulebook, including rules, ship descriptions, and eight scenarios. There are 15 new gunboats and a new monster. Banshees are found in hordes, looking for sites, preferably bases or anything slow-moving and poorly armed, to build breeding nests. There is a scenario for a solo player featuring these creatures. Be sure and defend your base, or you will have even more banshees to fight against! Of course, there are the images you need to create your own counters.

This product provides additional ships for use in Federation Commander. You will need one of the entry-point products (Klingon Border, Romulan Border, Academy) to use these ships. Either the Reference Rulebook or modules introducing more empires are useful for the ships from those empires.

- description from the publisher's blurb
categories: Book, Expansion for Base-game, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Park Racer
description:
Park Racer is a ramming & skidding strategy auto racing game for 1 to 6 players where speeding moonshine cars thunder around the idyllic forest parkland.

Using an unique car movement mechanic where for each matching icon dice the car is driven into a colour space on the track matching the chosen die's colour. Dice are retained by rolling varying amounts of black and white dice according to the car's current gear in the search for matching icons, all single dice are discarded. Carve out the best route to increase gears and gain distance against your rivals.

Includes Auto Cars to race against for both solo and multiplayer races.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Die Icon Resolution, Different Dice Movement, Grid Movement, Matching

name: Kim-Joy's Magic Bakery: Robot Fancies Promo Card
description:
Originally available as part of the Man vs. Meeple Season 4 Kickstarter.

1 new level 3 customer card requiring 1 sponge, 1 icing, and 1 jam card to fulfill.

Shuffle the card into the rest of the level 3 customer cards and proceed as usual.
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Six Sisters
description:
Simultaneous. Competitive. Short, but rewarding sessions. Asymmetric, but not heavily. Interesting combos. These are the primary tenets of Six Sisters.

Each player will manipulate between 2 and 6 Spell cards during the game. The cards are loaded each turn by up to 3 rolled Ingredients. As such, the decisions are not overwhelming. Often, the obvious choice is a good one. However, under that simple loop is a more complex system of counters and combos.

Six Sisters was explicitly designed with new or casual players in mind while offering significant depth to more experienced players.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: KANPUR: El Desierto Florido
description:
KANPUR: El Desierto Florido ("KANPUR: The Flowered Desert") brings up to four players to the vast and wide Atacama Desert, to witness how many species of flowers, within the wonderful landscapes of the driest non-arctic desert on Earth, bloom before and when spring arrives.

Players represent the north winds; they take turns drawing seed tiles, revealing cards that determine where water and sunlight will fall, and then strategically placing and/or moving their tiles depending on the flowers' requirements to bloom. Every flower, even similar species, requires its own conditions to show its colors.

Blooming is the main way to score, as well as Trophy cards that work as boosts for players to gain even more VP. Players use their wooden flower markers to track their score, and once a player fulfills a Trophy mission, that player keeps the card and the VP involved!

Rounds in the game represent one year seasons, changing weather. In addition, the board has different heights in the middle, making gardening a bit harder than expected, but no worries: Nature is amazing, as this phenomenon is seen every year in the "Norte Grande de Chile" (Great North of Chile).

The game has 4 game modes: Free for All, 2 vs 2, Solo, and Cooperative with 3 difficulty levels: Easy, Standard and Hard. Cooperative and Solo modes are challenges to overcome with strategy and skill.

Play as you like and take a view on these beautiful flowers!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Drawing, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Highest-Lowest Scoring, Semi-Cooperative Game, Set Collection, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: EKAT
description:
EKAT is a French board game in self-publishing.

Totally made in France and ecologically responsible.

Dive into a world of strategy and intense battles with this battle royale card game on the island of Ekat where you will have to face the other players to end a conflict that has been going on for years.

Play your cards with cunning and tactics to overcome your opponents and win.

Two nations have been at war for years. Deaths are piling up on both sides... The leaders of the two countries decide to send their best champion for a duel to the death on the island of Ekat.

You play as one of these two champions.

Collect ammunition, weapons, and food to survive this fight and end this endless war.

—description from the designer (translated)

EKAT est un jeu de société français en autoédition.

Fabriqué totalement en France et éco responsable.

Plongez dans un monde de stratégie et de combats intenses avec ce jeu de cartes battle royale sur l'île d'Ekat où vous devrez affronter l'autre joueur pour mettre fin à un conflit qui dure depuis des années.

Jouez vos cartes avec astuce et faites preuve de tactique pour triompher de votre adversaire et remporter la victoire.

Deux nations se déchirent et sont en guerre depuis des années. Les morts s'accumulent de part et d'autre des deux camps... Les dirigeants des deux pays décident d'envoyer chacun leur meilleur champion pour un duel à mort sur l'île d'Ekat.

Vous incarnez un de ces deux champions.

Récoltez des munitions, des armes, des vivres pour survivre à ce combat et mettre fin à cette guerre interminable.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action Drafting, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Dice Rolling

name: After Life Party: The Game
description:
ALP is a game that is creepy enough to be seriously fun where you get to hunt ghosts with friends. And the ghosts get to hunt you back.

Tired of babyish ghost games for scaredy cats, but not about to bust out the ouija, because you know better? Ready for a real ghost themed board game to shiver your timbers while you battle your friends? This one's real... Real fun. Up to 6 players can play as skeptics OR believers. Compete to collect evidence cards and survive ghosts effects from each haunted location you dare to investigate. But beware, when you play with ghosts, they play back. Will you be the Psychic, the TV host, The Camera Guy, The Agent, The Priest or the Skeptic? And will you beat the bumps in the night? Roll the dice, spin the ghost effects planchette. Be the first to prove or debunk, while sabotaging your meddling colleagues. Don't get labeled a quack and hold on to your evidence! The hunt is on.

—description the designer
categories: Card Game, Dice, Exploration, Negotiation, Party Game, Science Fiction
mechanics: Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Hidden Victory Points, Roles with Asymmetric Information, Roll / Spin and Move, Semi-Cooperative Game, Team-Based Game

name: Dinn: Chapter Pack 1
description:
Chapter Pack 1 features ten unique cards designed to augment decks and introduce players to the story of the mysterious disappearance of Natalie Neil.

Chapter Pack 1 Content:

10 deck-building cards, each with a unique puzzle.
10 digital card images that allow you to start solving card puzzles immediately upon purchase.

Each card in this chapter pack features a unique puzzle that will take players on a digital treasure hunt that moves the story forward and unlocks bonus cards for Chapter Pack 2. Additionally, each card is a powerful addition to your deck. Every player who purchases this chapter pack will receive the same ten cards – but these cards will never be printed again after the conclusion of Season 1.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Dinn: Chapter Pack 2
description:
Dinn Chapter Packs allow you to dive deeper into the mysteries of Dinn’s first season, as well as customize your decks with powerful new expansion cards.

Chapter Pack 2 continues the investigation into the mysterious disappearance of Natalie Neil with 10 new puzzle cards that will introduce players to new events, characters, and strange notifications in Rock Springs, Wyoming.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Unspecified

name: MetalleFest
description:
In MetalleFest players form their band by drafting musician cards, then draw and select song cards to compose a song. The groove of the song draws fan cards to your stage. The music skills used to play the song impress fans gathered at your stage. Impressed fans will buy your merch! The first band to sell all their merch wins.

—description form the publisher
mechanics: Open Drafting

name: Battle for the Hill
description:
Get Ready... get steady... and try not to get wreckt! In Battle for the Hill, players collect points in a fast-paced futuristic race of sports stars with amazing abilities. Use action cards to slow down other players or join together and K.O. the many obstacles standing in your way. Stuck? Players can reprogram “cobot” referees, who are standing by on the sidelines waiting to help them out.

What’s a cobot?
A cobot, short for “collaborative robot”, is a robot that helps people and works alongside them.

The game includes four sports-themed card suits: Boxing, Football, Basketball, and Weightlifting. A fifth cobot-themed suit allows players to affect the different sections of The Hill, boosting their performance. On your turn, you can play one (or sometimes more!) cards to move your team up The Hill, slow down your opponents, OR change the cobot programming to give you a strategic advantage. So, bring your A game, and try not to get sacked!
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Sports
mechanics: Command Cards, Multi-Use Cards, Point to Point Movement, Programmed Movement, Race, Take That

name: Human Flavor
description:
Humans have long provided the nourishment that supernatural creatures need to survive and thrive. Celestial angels dine upon human faith, feral shape-changers upon meat, infernal demons upon fear, the undead upon life force and the fey folk upon willpower. No matter their palette, it takes a lot of work to band together, capture hapless humans and hide your kills from public view. Eventually, the humans of Bigbad City will get fed up (pun intended) and band together to fight back.

Human Flavor is an resource management and worker placement game where 2-6 players each manage a clan of mildly asymmetric supernatural beings striving to take control of the city.
​
You start the game with limited actions and take turns placing meeples until all actions are used up. Actions include capturing humans, feeding upon captured humans to gain additional resources, devouring captives for points and gaining/placing dominance stackers in the city for end game victory points.
​
There are also public Agendas drawn each round giving players common goals to pursue for points. The game concludes after 4 or 5 rounds when final dominance stacker points are tallied and the player with the most victory points gains triumphant dominion over the city.

-description from publisher
mechanics: Once-Per-Game Abilities, Worker Placement

name: Clue: Naruto Shippuden
description: In Clue: Naruto Shippuden, a Jonin from a neighboring village has been slain by a mysterious villain, framing the resident ninjas of Hidden Leaf Village. Take on the roles of Naruto and his closest friends to prevent a Shinobi war by determining WHO from the Akatsuki is the murderer, WHAT weapon was used, and WHERE they are hiding!
categories: Bluffing, Comic Book / Strip, Deduction, Murder/Mystery
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Slime Battles!
description:
Strategy game with resource management mechanics for 2-4 players in which players fight to become the new king of the island using their army of slimes.

A long, long time ago, some little creatures began to populate this island. Over time, they formed a society divided into groups according to their specialty and ruled by a king. A long, long time has passed since these days, but if you look carefully through the dense forests, over the high mountains and across the green meadows, you will find slimes who have made this island their home.

Now, the slime king is dead! An era of power struggle has begun. You, the leader of a village of slimes, want to be the new king but you are not the only one. As written in the slime law, you will fight from next spring to next winter to increase your army and strengthen your power. At the end of the year, whoever has the largest army will rule the island. Will you be the new king of slimes? Prove yourself in the fight for the crown!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Sector
description:
Playing Sector will take you directly into the experience of a science fiction dystopian adventure where you fight to the death to be the last one standing in a wilderness arena. A young girl rushes to the center for items only to be shot by a bow and arrow. A dehydrated jock runs around desperately searching for a source of water. A small girl wins by luring her attackers into a river swarming with piranhas. With fog of war mechanics and a plethora of formidable opponents, you’ll never feel safe for long. During the game, you control one of the characters, each with unique skillsets and traits that cover the different playstyles you’re familiar with. Cade, the big jock, thrives in combat and loves to hunt down weaker opponents with strength-based weapons. Regina, on the other hand, is agile and likes to take out competitors from a distance. Ivy, the frail girl, prefers to let the environment do her dirty work and merely out-survive the competition.

Sector is a competitive game for up to eight players. With a wide variety of characters, items to collect, and new arenas every time you play, each game is a unique cinematic experience.

The game is played over three phases, the Center Stage, the Game Stage, and the End Stage.

In the Center Stage, player pawns are arranged in a circle on a central game board where they can move inward to collect items and engage in combat with others or move outward onto individual maps behind cardboard screens to explore the arena and temporarily get out of harm's way.

The Game Stage begins once all players have left the central game board and are on their individual player maps. Each round of the Game Stage consists of players moving locations, performing location checks to see if another player is in the same spot on the map, fighting another player in combat if in the same location, performing actions to acquire resources from the environment and resolving event cards.

The End Stage begins once all players have moved back onto the central game board after a deadly fog has pushed them inward from their individual maps. The central game board's play area is reduced every round to force players into combat until only one remains.

The combat system combines the chosen characters' unique traits and skills with the weapons they possess and varying ranges to determine if dice rolls result in successful attacks.
categories: Adventure, Exploration, Fighting, Novel-based, Real-time, Science Fiction
mechanics: Action Points, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Finale Ending, Grid Movement, Hidden Movement, Resource to Move, Variable Player Powers

name: Supremacy ECG
description:
Supremacy Expandable Card Game is a game based in science fiction universe where battle is fought by alien races for control of the galaxy. Player's mission is to defend their own base (HQ) while destroying the opponent's base, as is known from RTS computer games.

Each player has two decks, the main deck contains 40 cards, the support deck contains a maximum of 40 cards, and the HQ card. Players construct decks having infantry, drones, mechs, spaceships, battle stations, and creatures from outer space regions.

At the beginning, each player takes 7 cards from the top of the main deck, and then they are placed face down near HQ card represent life of that HQ. Next, takes 4 cards into player's hand. Each turn, players take total of 2 cards into their hand to choose from two decks (except for the first turn).

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Collectible Components, Fighting, Science Fiction
mechanics: Deck Construction, Hand Management, Interrupts, Player Elimination, Take That

name: By the Seashore
description:
In By the Seashore, you are a beachcomber searching the shoreline for beautiful things like sea glass, shark teeth, and sand dollars to add to your collection.

Play starts with six face-up cards in the middle of the table. On your turn, you can either trade up by discarding a card and taking one card of higher value or trade down by discarding a card and taking two cards of equal or lower value. Once you collect either a three-of-a-kind or a three-in-a-row, you can score that set; add one card to your tableau, pass one card, and dedicate the last for scoring. (You'll only score for symbols that you have dedicated in this way.) Different symbols shown on the cards have different scoring mechanisms, so cleverly arrange the cards in your tableau to maximize your points.

Play continues until everyone has at least five cards in their tableau, then you score. Whoever has the most points win!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Toasty Toasts
description:
Objective*


Toast to the top with Toasty Toasts! Combine delicious Topping cards, use sneaky Actions, and create the tastiest Toasts spread to score the most points!


Setup*


Separate the Base Toast pile, Draw pile, and Time to Eat card.
Shuffle the Draw pile.
Deal each player two Base Toast cards and three cards from the Draw pile.
For two to three players, shuffle the Time to Eat card into the bottom 1/3 of the Draw pile. For four players, shuttle it into the bottom 1/4 of the Draw pile.
Place the Base Toast (faceup) and Draw piles within reach of all players.
Determine the starting player by selecting the player who last ate toast.


Gameplay Overview*


Toasty Toasts is played over several turns, where each player may take a number of actions before passing the turn to the next player on their left (clockwise). Turns continue until the “Time to Eat!” card is drawn, at which point the game ends, and players proceed to the scoring phase.

Player Turns*


Each player turn can be split into three quick phases (Draw, Play, Hand Check).


Draw Phase*


The active player draws two cards from the Draw pile. If the active player has no cards in hand at the beginning of their turn, they instead draw three cards.


Play Phase*


During the active player’s play phase, they may make up to two plays. A player may choose to pass at any time on their turn, as a result a player may make 0, 1, or 2 plays on their turn. Most plays only require a single play. These include:
Playing a single topping or action card
Playing two cards as part of a matching or combination pair
Trading any two cards for a new Base Toast.
Additionally, Players may play Plain Toast cards in two different capacities—as a Base Toast, or as a Sandwich.


Playing an Topping Card*


For a single play, the active player may play a topping card face up on one of their Base Toast or Plain Toast cards. Toppings may not be placed on a Toast that already holds a topping if the topping does not:
a. Match the played topping
b. Combo with the played topping
A single Toast may hold any number of matching toppings, or toppings that combo with each other. Combo toppings do not require a direct 1:1 ratio of each topping to be placed on a Toast.


Playing an Action Card*


For a single play, the active player may play an Action card. When playing an Action card, resolve the text printed on the card, then place the card into the discard pile.
Playing Matching Topping Pairs
For a single play, the active player may play two matching toppings on a single toast.
As with single placement restrictions, the active player may not place a matching topping pair onto a toast which already holds one or more toppings that the played toppings do not match or form a combination with.


Playing a Combination Pair*


For a single play, the active player may play two toppings on a single toast provided the toppings form a combination pair. Combination toppings share card color and are designated on each topping card. Combination pairs include:
- Peanut Butter & Jelly
- Bacon & Egg
- Tomato & Avocado
- Choco Spread & Banana

As with single placement restrictions, the active player may not place a combination pair onto a toast which already holds a topping that is not part of the combination pair.

Trading for a Base Toast*


For a single play, the active player may trade a combination of any two Toast, Topping, or Action cards in their hand for a Base Toast from the Base Toast pile. Base Toast cards are placed immediately in front of the active player next to their other Toasts.
-Note- This play may only be performed once per turn.
Playing a Plain Toast Card
Plain Toasts are unique in that they may be played in two different capacities: As a Base Toast or as part of a Sandwich.


As a Base Toast*


As a single action, the active player may place a Plain Toast card face up in front of them next to their other Toasts. Plain Toast cards played in this way are treated as if they were Base Toast cards.


As a Sandwich*


For two actions, the active player may place a Plain Toast card on top of any of their other Toasts. Doing so changes the Toast into a Sandwich. Plain Toasts are the only cards that may be used to create sandwiches.


Sandwiches – Important!*


Once a Toast becomes a Sandwich, additional toppings may not be added to it. However, it is also immune to the effects of all Action cards.


Hand Check*


Once the active player has completed two actions—or passed—they check their hand to ensure they have seven or fewer cards. Should their hand hold an excess of seven cards, the active player must place cards from their hand into the discard pile until their hand holds seven cards.
Play then passes to the player on the active player’s left.


Game End*


Once the “Time to Eat!” card is drawn, play ends immediately.
Each player counts their score using the following point structure:
- Base Toasts (exclude sandwiches) – 1 point
- Single Toppings – 2 points
- Sandwiches – 3 points
- Combos – 5 points
Note that all toppings that are part of a sandwich score their points normally—whether they are single toppings or part of a combo, sandwich points are considered a bonus for converting a Toast into a Sandwich using a Plain Toast card.

description from designer
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Print & Play
mechanics: Hand Management, Take That

name: Space Jam: A New Legacy – Serververse Showdown
description:
Introducing Serververse Showdown for Space Jam: A New Legacy, a card game that brings the story of the blockbuster family film to life in a strategic battle on the court! Serververse Showdown features fan-favorite characters from Looney Tunes and world-famous basketball players! Recruit your ultimate dream team and play to win, or risk being stuck in the Serververse with Al-G Rhythm forever!

As you play, cards will be drawn from the Game Deck and placed on either your court or your bench. Abilities will activate, including game-changing Hacked! cards that can rewrite certain rules mid-game.

Players take one of three actions on each of their turns:

Shoot! - Choose a character on the court to shoot, gaining cards from the Game Deck facedown as points

Substitute! - Rearrange cards between your court and your bench, setting up bigger plays

Glitch! - Eject one of your cards from the bench, letting you trigger their abilities a second time

It's a low complexity, high fun pick up and play card game. The first to 21 points (or the highest scorer once the deck runs out) wins!
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Sports
mechanics: Drawing

name: The Enchanted Burrow
description:
Under the big trees of a mystical forest there is a mine with precious magical jewels solidified between the rocks. The little animals of the forest extract them and take them to their burrows to survive the scarcity of food in difficult seasons, as they have discovered that these gems increase the size of the fruits, others increase their sweetness and others regulate their temperature, which keeps them fresh for longer. But the gems are very besieged by the forest fauna and it is not easy to get the best ones.

In The Enchanted Burrow, players roll the dice and write down the results on a sheet with the intention of optimizing their score. Players have to complete sets of gems, improve burrows, save fruits and rush to win bonuses before opponents in various puzzles with different challenges in each game. Which burrow will have the most magic points and the best food before winter arrives?

—description from the publisher
categories: Dice, Fantasy, Number, Print & Play, Puzzle
mechanics: Bingo, Dice Rolling, End Game Bonuses, Pattern Building, Race, Set Collection, Square Grid, Variable Set-up

name: Adventure Party: The Savage Lands A FREE RPG DAY Exclusive
description: Adventure Party: The Savage Lands A FREE RPG DAY Exclusive is a "quickstart", or demo, version of the game Adventure Party, distributed at Free RPG Day 2023 to promote the upcoming Kickstarter campaign. Adventure Party delivers a robust role-playing experience that can be enjoyed within 2 minutes of explanation. In this cooperative guessing game, 3-6 players take the roles of adventurers in a classic fantasy role-playing world, facing monsters and attempting heroic deeds.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Storytelling

name: Unavowed
description:
Unavowed is a pocket-sized two-player card game about palace conspiracies played with a deck of just fifteen cards. Players begin by drafting a hand composed of members of the royal court, then play a series of rounds.

In each round, players place one card face down in a secret meeting, and count up in rank to determine the winner with the higher value. The lower-rank card is revealed and loses the meeting, while the winning card stays hidden. Certain cards have the chance to reveal a specific opponent if it was played in the meeting.

When one player wins three meetings, the round is over, but the defeated player has one last chance to secure victory by assassination. If they can guess which of the opponent's cards played during the round - face up or face down - is the highest rank, they win instead!

The loser of the round draws a new card into their hand, both players pick up their cards, then play for the best of three rounds.
categories: Bluffing, Card Game, Deduction, Fantasy, Memory, Science Fiction
mechanics: Closed Drafting, Deduction, Memory

name: 1-48TACTIC: Achtung Panzer!
description:
This supplement covers all the rules required for introducing heavy weapons and vehicles in the 1-48TACTIC game.
Covers Hard and Soft targets, HE, AP and HEAT shells, Heavy MG, rifle grenades, bazooka and other man-portable AT weapons, mines, incendiary and explosives, upgrade cards and much more! You will also find included stat cards and profiles for many of the vehicles and weapons most commonly used during the “Battle of the Bulge”.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Bizarre Bazaar
description:
Welcome to the Bizarre Bazaar, where you turn ordinary into extraordinary!

Bizarre Bazaar offers a humorous and memorable way to teach players new vocabulary while immersing them in a fusion of reality and myth.

Each round, the Buyer draws a Role card and becomes a mundane human or a fantastic creature. All other players use Quality (adjective or gerund) and Item (noun) cards to invent Quality Items. These combinations are placed in bags that are shuffled and distributed to new, unsuspecting players. To the best of their abilities, players then attempt to sell the bizarre contents of their bags, and the Buyer chooses which one of these Quality Items wins the round. The players who created and pitched the chosen Quality Item each receive one of the winning cards as a reward. The Buyer switches roles with the player to their left and play continues until a predetermined number of rounds has been completed. Prepare for mutually assured amusement!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Player Judge, Simultaneous Action Selection

name: Kitunda
description:
In Kitunda, a game for two to four players, in which only the chess pawns are available for placement on an 8x8 field of play. The eight pawns of each player reside in a “trench or dugout” alongside the outer edges of the game board.

A plague has crippled the “royals” (rooks, knights, bishops, and king) leaving the queens of four different nations to attend to them. The Kitunda, Swahili for chess pawns, are given a crystal (die), which they can use to access the powers of the royals.

Each roll of a die allows any pawn to enter the field of play using the capability of a royal piece. For example, a 1 on a die allows any chess pawn to move like a rook. While a 6 allows any pawn to move like a bishop, and so on.

The objective is to capture all opposing pawns until only one victorious player remains.

-description from designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling

name: Give Me 3
description: Divide your play group into two teams and compete to give 3 answers to creative prompts. For example, the prompt might be "Give me 3 things to never say during a job interview?" Each team alternates giving 3 answers in 10 seconds; whichever team fails first, loses the round. First to win 10 rounds wins the game!
categories: Card Game, Humor, Party Game, Real-time
mechanics: Unspecified

name: On the Spot: Family Edition
description:
On The Spot is the hilarious party game to hot seat your friends AND FAMILY. I mean you are absolutely grilling each player with no remorse for a full 2 minutes.

You get to ask things you would never know. You will finish this game closer to every single player.

Exactly like On The Spot Original, but rated PG instead of R.

The game is simple.

The player with the closest birthday get the red 'You Are On The Spot' first.

Everyone takes 5 cards from the stack.

Each round:

Start the 2 minute timer.

Begin grilling the player 'On The Spot'.

Moving clockwise, players ask 1 question at a time.

Discard the used card in front of the player 'On The Spot'.

Pick up a new card, so you always have 5.

Once time is up, the 'You Are On The Spot' card moves clockwise.
Rinse and repeat.

Optional play to win: Save all the cards you answer. At the end, count your cards. Most questions answered wins!

NOTE I: You are allowed 1 skip no-questions-asked each round. Group decides consequences of skipping more than 1.

NOTE II: Group is allowed to ask for 3 "story times" each round so player 'On The Spot' can further explain their answer. Pause the timer by laying it on its side during story times.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Fan Expansion, Humor
mechanics: Questions and Answers

name: Write or Die: The Romantic Period
description:
In Write or Die: The Romantic Period, players simultaneously draft cards to strategically build upon a budding writing career, fulfill personal bonus objectives, and remain in good health. Should a player die, they continue to play from the beyond but focus on cards available to the deceased. After each round, players recount the latest life update using the drafted hand for inspiration.

With cards influenced by the lives of the great writers of the time—Jane Austen, William Wordsworth, Mary Shelley, Edgar Allen Poe—you forge your own path to write your name in the stars. With 108 unique cards, no two stories are ever the same. The player with the most successful career dead or alive by the end of three rounds wins the game.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Closed Drafting, End Game Bonuses, Simultaneous Action Selection, Storytelling

name: The Taming of the Slugiraffe
description:
Taming the Slugiraffe is a solo roleplaying game where players take on the role of an insignificant background fantasy creature as it journeys into THE PIT to find the fabled SLUGIRAFFE. Can you survive the PIT and gather what you need to TAME THE SLUGIRAFFE?

What's it like?

It's a bit like Dark Souls if you were playing as a Pikachu trying to catch a Snorlax. The monsters are nasty, the world is dark, but you're just hoping to find a big slug-giraffe thing to make the life of your people much easier.

What's the set up?

You play as a GIBLET, a small background fantasy creature – the kind of thing that gets kicked off a cliff (without being hurt) for comic relief in films and TV. You and your people like a happy life, but there is a story a mystical creature that once would ferry and care for your tribes. You wish to return your people to this bountiful golden age – but to do this you must find, and tame, a SLUGIRAFFE. The only place they exist is within THE PIT. You, brave GIBLET, must descend to find the creature, and return a hero.

The System

The game uses a random exploration system and simple dice combat and event resolution using 2D6 (originally based on the excellent TUNNEL GOONS system by Nate Treme). Depending on the monsters you defeat or friends you make along the way you'll roll a different sized dice on the D20 loot table. Naturally, the most beneficial items are those in the top range of dice rolls.

Players draw their progress through the pit. Each location has it's own interaction or event which might be useful for gaining the resources to find and tame the SLUGIRAFFE. They will need to work with the pit dwellers to improve their chances of survival by trading items, performing rituals, and eventually finding a way to track the mythical creature.

Exploration

Exploration is a case of creating paths and exploring new biomes and settlements using the provided map. Players roll for exploring biomes, and if they're lucky they'll find a settlement. Once a connection has been made between two locations the path can be travelled freely. If you want to find somewhere new however, you'll have roll for exploration again, and deal with whatever encounters lurk there.

Combat

Combat is deadly and ruthless – and your choices about what you carry with you will make all the difference to your survival. Simply beat the number requested on 2D6, plus any useful items, and victory is yours. Failure means losing an item, or an item slot. If you run out of item slots, you've been squished. On the plus side, if you fail your quest, they'll just send another one of you. You are, after all, only a GIBLET.

Taming

One you have gathered your gear and found the location of the SLUGIRAFFE, it's simply a case of chasing it down and taming it. Your weapons are no good here, as the ancient beast is indestructable. The game is a balance between arming yourself for your survival, and being equipped to capture that ancient creature towards the end of the adventure.

The Zine

We'll be printing a 16 page zine with all the rules needed to play the game solo. The zine will be in colour throughout. You'll have to bring your own dice, writing implement and sense of foolish adventure.

The zine will also come with character sheets and token sheets printed within for easy photocopying, Digital versions of these will be available to all backers.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Map Addition, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Bees with Hammers
description:
During a regular workday, bees tirelessly look forward to attending and please their queen in order to gain her sympathy and proximity. To accomplish this, bees go out into the fields and explore them in search of the best flowers, to make the sweetest honey, according to their monarch's tastes.

In Bees with Hammers, players will become worker bees and compete against each other to fulfill the preferences of their queen, regarding a specific group of flowers. To do so, they must obtain the most points possible by placing their hives as close to the queen as possible and strategically considering the flowers used.

The player to obtain the most points at the end of the game will be the one who gains the trust of their monarch.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Drawing

name: Thundercats Juego de Aventuras
description: A game based on the 1980's children's cartoon. This edition has a hex-shaped board with numbers connecting the spaces.
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Cold Case: A Move and Write Escape Room Experience
description: In Cold Case: A Move and Write Escape Room Experience, a print-and-play board game for 2-4 people, the players attempt to solve the puzzles in an escape room! During the game, they collect the clues scattered around the room and use them to solve the puzzles before time runs out. At the end of the game, whoever contributed the most to solving the room wins!
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Weeds
description:
Weeds is played either one-on-one or in two-on-two teams. From a deck of 4 cards, players take turns choosing a card with a Tetris-like figure and drawing it in the shared garden. The last player or team to be able to draw a figure wins.

At the start of the game, 6 ability cards that cheat the placement rules are selected. During the game you can choose 3 of these abilities for your team. If you choose too early, the ability may not be used optimally. If you choose too late, your opponent may already have taken it.

Throughout the game, players collect water cans that allow them to refresh the card marked. But use them wisely, because they can also give your opponent new opportunities.

All players compete for space on a shared game board, which provides a high degree of player interaction. The 2v2 version encourages discussion around the table about who will sacrifice themselves for the team and block the opponent. Alliances are already formed - now it's time to get personal.

Sounds simple? It is. But if you don't coordinate your attacks with your partner and choose your abilities correctly, you'll quickly become locked in. And then it's up to your partner to be the "last plant standing".

Nominated for Best Presented Board Game and Best Innovation in Board Games at Fastaval 2023
mechanics: Grid Coverage, Square Grid, Team-Based Game

name: CATAN: Dawn of Humankind – Promo #1
description:
This promo for CATAN: Dawn of Humankind contains the Shaman's Prophecy card and the Dice Cave dice "tower."

The Shaman's Prophecy card is added to the starting hand of the player to the right of the start player. It can be used in the action phase to move an explorer 1-2 intersections. Once used, it is passed to the player on the right. It counts towards the number of cards held so can be stolen and can be discarded when a player must do so when a 7 is rolled. If that happens it is given to the player to the discarding player's right.

The Dice Cave, when assembled can be used to roll dice into, like a dice tower.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Hexagon Grid

name: Prisoner's Trilemma Game Theory in Action
description:
The Prisoner’s Dilemma is the most famous conundrum in Game Theory. Two criminals are caught by the police for a minor crime. They are suspected of a major crime which, if convicted, would put them behind bars for a long time indeed. The police separate the two partners in crime and offer them a bargain. If they betray the other prisoner, they will be released. If both stay silent the police will only be able convict them of their minor crime. If they both take the offer and betray each other they will both serve a long sentence. In Prisoner’s Trilemma: Game Theory in Action, players are presented with a variety of moral dilemmas where they have three possible choices to make. Players can choose to cooperate, betray or compromise to make the best of a difficult situation.

OBJECTIVE – The objective of Prisoner’s Trilemma is to work through moral quandaries each with three possible choices presented to the players scoring points based on the outcomes.
GAME PLAY – In each of five rounds, players are presented with a moral trilemma. Players play cards from their hand representing the degree to which they cooperate, betray or compromise in the situation. Payoff cards are revealed in each round which indicates points earned from the decisions the players make.
GAME END AND WINNING – Prisoner’s Trilemma ends after five rounds, when the players considered five trilemmas.
THEME – Game Theory Exploration

—description from the designer
categories: Abstract Strategy, Deduction, Game System, Negotiation
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deduction, Induction, Negotiation, Prisoner's Dilemma

name: PRIMAL
description:
A survival/strategy board game that takes place during the last Ice Age. Players navigate the board and participate in the actions at their leisure. But like life, the game can be unpredictable and force you into action and even take everything you have accumulated away from you. Work with the other players or go it alone as you fight for survival in a world full of prehistoric beasts such as woolly mammoths and sabre-toothed cats.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Action/Event, Critical Hits and Failures, Dice Rolling, Impulse Movement, Player Elimination, Semi-Cooperative Game

name: Jogando com Lovecraft
description:
Playing with Lovecraft is a Lovecraftian Card Game to children 6+ years old.

Objective
Explore the main deck to capture Elder Ones, Deep Ones, Ghouls and find Gates to make points.

Gameplay
The game is played in turns. Every turn, players explore a main deck opening a card (gate, elder one or monster) and each player choose a card with a number (force 1-9).


Gates: Make each player discard the choose card.
Elder Ones: The UNIQUE high card capture a card.
Monsters (Deep Ones and Ghouls): The UNIQUE low card capture a card.


After 9 turns the game is end and a player with more points wins.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Deduction

name: Sasquatch BBQ
description:
Compete with fellow Sasquatches in this push-your-luck card game to prepare the most delicious barbecue using questionable ingredients. Foul play is never off-limits, but stay away from nosey cryptozoologists that try to disrupt your feast.

Each turn, start by going on a Hunt to gather Ingredients and Recipes by flipping cards from a central draw pile into an open draft. Push your luck by flipping more cards to have more options to choose from, but make sure you don't run into a Cryptozoologist because they will surely ruin your Hunt.

After Hunting for Ingredients, head back to your BBQ Pit where you commit Ingredients to your Recipe cards in order to cook the dishes and score points.

The first Sasquatch to cook an Appetizer, a Main Course, and a Dessert triggers the final round. After the final round, Sasquatches tally up their points to find out who is the BBQ Pitmaster.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Open Drafting, Push Your Luck

name: Munchkin: Dodatek Obfitości
description: Expansion, released only in Polish, contains the contents of 8 boosters: Fairy Dust, Munchkinomicon, Monster Enhancers, Game Changers, Dragons, Dragon's Trike, Undead, Princesses.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Fighting, Humor
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Take That

name: Paneveggio
description:
Paneveggio will immerse you in 1700 close to the Paneveggio Forest where generations of renowned luthiers such as Amati, Stradivarius or Guardani took the precious wood to build the famous violins we still hear about today.
Players will embody young luthiers who are launching their own workshop after leaving their mentor.
They will try to earn as much Violin points (VP) as possible and offer their most beautiful work of art to prestigious musicians of that time by alternating work sessions and rest.
The game is based on a musical score mechanics, the notes are then representing planned actions.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action Queue, End Game Bonuses, Hand Management, Multi-Use Cards

name: Fleets of Renown
description:
Fleets of Renown is a free Print-and-Play Game for 2 to 8 players designed to bring dynamic and fun games based on real historical naval figures from both fame and infamy. Choose your Fleet, Captain and Crew before commencing battle on the High Seas to see which player’s Fleet has the most Renown!

The game is split into two phases;

Phase 1 sees each player choosing their custom Fleet and Crew. This phase can be done before the game night and can be changed between games. Each player has 60 Renown Points to spend on their Fleet and 24 Renown Points to spend on their Captain and Crew. After the Fleet and Crew have been chosen, you can place your Ships and Safe Port ready for Phase 2.

Phase 2 sees each player engage in battle by moving their Ships across the map into broadside positions to be able to fire their Cannons at the opposing Ships. Using tactics and strategy, sink each opponent’s Ships to be victorious!
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Summon & Sacrifice
description:
You’re a wizard, using sorcery to summon creatures more powerful than those of your opponents. You'll use magic gems to buy creature cards that will earn you points at the end of the game. Some will gain bonus points from other creatures of the same element type, so it's wise to focus on collecting one type of creature (earth, water, or air).

But to create life, you must take life - you’ll need to sacrifice some creatures in order to earn magic gems. This is done by simply turning your creature cards upside-down at the beginning of your turn. But be careful -dead creatures will subtract points from your final score, and they can only be revived witha specific wand or spell.

Once a player has 7 creatures (living & dead),all other players take one more turn. In the end, points are tallied and the wizard with the highest score wins!

—description from the designer
mechanics: End Game Bonuses, Set Collection, Take That

name: #LikeMe Escape Game
description:
The SAS rugby team the Tigers play against their arch-rival: the Pitbulls! It is the last match of the season, the final that will determine the winner. But the Pitbulls are playing dirty. To make sure they will win, they have Vince and his friends locked in the school. Choose your favourite #LikeMe character to play. Help get Vince to the match in time for the Tigers to win the final! But beware, the Pitbulls have left traps and their mascot is lurking to slow you down. A race against time! Will you manage to escape in time?

This is a cooperative party game. So you work together to win. Thanks to the different combinations of game cards and the game board which is different every game, this Escape Game is infinitely replayable.
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Puzzle
mechanics: Team-Based Game
