name: Poison Garden
description:
Poison Garden is a solo experience where the player is a caretaker tending to a garden filled with deadly and poisonous plants. As the brave caretaker, you must weed and care for the Poison Garden to prepare it for visitors, but beware; the garden has an infamous reputation.

Poison Garden is for one player and plays for 30 minutes or less. Players will start off with a deadly and poisonous garden represent as tiles that needs serious tending before the gates can be opened to the public. Each turn, the player will tend one plot of the garden, which triggers a chain reaction of sub-actions with adjacent plots. Some of these actions are:
- Weed: removes a plant from the garden for further care
- Transplant: moves a plant to a different area of the garden
- Water: immediately tend an adjacent plot
And more…

Sometimes your hard work will become undone as the chaos of weeds comes back to your garden. Players will have to be diligent and thoughtful to execute their actions in a timely fashion so as not to fully exhaust their time tokens. If a player can tend to all the plots visible in the garden, they win. If not, then they succumb to the poison garden and the iron gates will remain locked.

There are additional modules included in the game to ramp up the difficulty by introducing new poisonous plants that introduce new sub-actions and challenges.

Poison Garden is a title in the new Talon Strikes small-box series.

-description from developer
mechanics: Slide/Push, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Kolory na kolory
description: A quick party game in which you have to get rid of your cards as quickly as possible by matching the color description to the spot on the card on top of the pile in the middle of the table.
mechanics: Hand Management, Matching, Pattern Recognition, Speed Matching

name: Dungeon Cube
description:
A competitive fantasy adventures game, played only with a single cube.

Dungeon Cube is a game for 1-4 players, campaign driven, that let you live an entire story of adventures for you and your friends.
Each player chooses a hero, represented by one face of the cube, then the heroes must accomplish the same mission, represented by a sequence of goals to be fulfilled by the heroes. To fulfill a goal, a player must rotate layers of the cube to obtain a specific configuration on his face.
The first hero that fulfill the last goal, is the winner.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Airport Service
description:
You are the manager of the airport terminal services department. You have to arrange maintenance of the aircraft for the departure.
The goal of the game is to send as many passenger flights as possible.
Each player rolls a dice. The number on the cube is the number of workers that can be brought in to service the aircraft. To send a flight, it is necessary to attract a sufficient number of workers indicated on the flight requirements card.
Player can take a card of a random event. The card can result in both positive and negative events that can speed up the departure or, on the contrary, lead to a delay.
The player with the most departed passengers wins.
Also, players can trade with each other to find the fastest way to depart flights.
categories: Aviation / Flight, Card Game, Civilization, Dice, Transportation, Travel
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Worker Placement with Dice Workers, Worker Placement, Different Worker Types

name: Bird Turds
description:
Bird Turds is game for nerds who love words. It tests a players vocabulary, spelling and ability to rhyme.

Each player chooses a character bird and gets 10 bird cards. Players also receive 3 turd cards. Play begins with the selection of the first word ending. For example if the first ending is "Ace," each player has to come up with a word that ends in "Ace" such as Place, Face, Mace...etc. If a player fails to come up with a word, they get a Turd and they lose their turn. The last person without a Turd at the end of the round gets to collect a Bird from the other players.

The goal of Bird Turds is simply to not crap out. The last person without Three Turds or the most Birds at the end of 10 rounds wins the game.

—description from the designer
categories: Card Game, Educational, Party Game, Word Game
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Wall Streak
description:
Wall Streak is a board game where players take on the roles of investors, competing against one another to become the king/queen of Wall Street. Players accomplish this by having earned the most victory points at game's end. Victory can be earned one of three ways, buying company's (worth 5vp's for each owned at game's end), accumulating money (worth 1vp per every 5M at game's end), and completing investor goals (worth 3vp to 15vp). Players must find the right balance between the 3 in order to be crowned king/queen of Wall Street!

On player's turns they roll a single six sided die and move the corresponding number of spaces and then perform the action on the space. Players may pay to move forward one or two additional spaces for costs of 3M or 5M respectively. While navigating the board of Wall Streak players move following the direction/path that they are on until they reach an intersection. Once at an intersection players may change their path or continue following the path they were. The only restrictions being players are not allowed to double back and reverse course, and players must always travel clockwise in the company and money loops.

There are several different types of spaces which players can land on throughout the game. When a player lands on a M, T or gold bar space they draw a card from the respective deck and perform its action, or keep it if it is stock or movement adjusting card (found in the T (Transaction) deck) or an additional investor goal (found in the M (Merger) deck). Spaces with a money amount provide players with that amount of money when they land on them. On dice spaces players will roll either a single or double D6 dice and receive or lose money according to the color dice space that they landed on. Finally there are 50 company spaces which players can land on. When landed on players may buy the company for it's current price, initiate an auction for the company, or pay rent to it's current owner.

Players must must find the right balance and timing between accumulating money and buying companies. The game end is triggered once a certain number of companies are owned by all players. This number varies based on the number of players in the game.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Action/Event, Auction: Once Around, Dice Rolling, Die Icon Resolution, Hidden Victory Points, Modular Board, Ownership, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding

name: Tribal Second Edition
description:
THE SKIRMISH COMBAT GAME THAT PROVIDES PLAYERS WITH A GAME SET IN A PRE-GUNPOWDER TRIBAL/CLAN SETTING. THE RULES OFFER SOME NEW AND EXCITING APPROACHES TO WARGAMING.

Honour is used to drive the narrative of the game. Players are rewarded in honour for the things that they do in the battle. Honour determines who wins Tribal – it can be won and lost during combat, the deeds of combatants can win or lose honour, players can spend honour to do ‘dirty tricks’ to win combats.

The game is also played with a normal deck of cards. Cards determine movement, unit activation and – most importantly – combat. Players can actually be involved in the combat through playing/holding particular cards. Attacking, defending, waiting for an opening, bluffing the opponent – these are all strategies the player can use in a round of Tribal combat.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Measurement Movement, Open Drafting, Simulation

name: Syncanite Foundation
description:
Syncanite Foundation - The Ultimate Grand Strategy & Conspiracy Board Game"A Game by Timon Thöne, designed by M. Rockatansky, soon to be published by the Syncanite GmbH on Kickstarter"

Syncanite Foundation is a deep economic strategy & area control game with variable victory conditions and no player elimination for 2 - 6 conspirators. Force the crisis of your choice to exploit its momentum and win. Want some example? Trigger a war and annihilate your rivals! Or trigger a revolution and get crowned as supreme chancellor - the choice is yours!



Intro:Syncanite - materialized power. For the masses, it is the only source of energy. For the elites, the key to immortality. As an independent trade league, the Syncanite Foundation regulates the mining and distribution of the syncan mineral, ensuring political, economic and military stability. But behind the noble guise lurks a secret society of machiavellian oligarchs. At the levers of power, it is easy for them to push the continent into mayhem. How far will YOU go?



How to Play:Easy to learn: Syncanite Foundation is a complex game that is not complicated to play!
Fight your power struggle in four phases per cycle:



I. Conflict phase: Claim regions & resources"Only those who dominate can shape the future."
~ Soric Flasyra, Guardian of the rhilian Imperium

Every member of the Syncanite Foundation has a private army. Use it to occupy regions of the continent to claim the resources there. But be careful: other players can outbid your military contingent. As long as this cold war prevails, the troops cannot fight, only displace each other. In addition to sheer mass, the clever use of operations and doctrine are decisive for this phase.



II. Offering phase: Use profits for corruption"With the right contacts, momentum becomes a method."
~ Wator Abrius, Chairman of the Tycan Conglomerate

The market prices for your resources are in your favor? Sell or buy stock for capital and use your profits in a bidding contest against the other players to win over the continent’s dignitaries to your side. Their powerful effects will drastically change the course of the game. In the later game, this phase holds many more offers and opportunities for the players.



III. Parliament phase: Manipulate and murder"When good words are not enough, clearer messages are needed."
~ Maverid Czylark, Speaker of the Avadian Conclave

Influence the course of the continent by intervening in parliamentary votes. How many votes you have is entirely up to you and your abilities: Prevent laws that stand in your way and pass those that benefit you. Damage your competitors with a variety of means – from denunciation to insidious assassination.



IV. Foundation Phase: Pull the levers of power"When the Nations collide, we profit."
~ Unknown, Founder of the Syncanite Foundation

Use the unique power of your Role to push the continent into a direction you want: Invest in Infrastructure, censor the media, manage democracy, steer the Markets or control the military of a faction of your choice. Eventually, prepare for the next cycle: A new conflict phase awaits – and maybe even a crisis.



How to win - the unique Crisis MechanicsThis world is a powder keg. Every operation, every law, and every market driven to extremes can trigger crises. A single spark can ignite the Continent! Immediate events create unstoppable chaos and add crisis-specific mechanics to the game phases, opening the way to multiple victory options! There are five crises in total with unique paths to victory:



Revolution - The Diplomatic VictoryUse your parliamentary privileges to your advantage. Drive the integrity of parliament into crisis and provoke draconian measures. With the “Revolution” crisis, you can eliminate your political opponents and be elected ruler of the continent. Once appointed, you’ll never give up your power again, will you?



Monopoly - The Economic VictoryLiberalize the parliament, privatize the institutions and make gigantic profits. Whether by legal and ethical means or not is entirely up to you. With the “monopoly” crisis, you are laying the foundations for a plutocratic system of oligarchs bidding in obscene wealth for the last remnants of the once all-powerful state. How much are you able to pay?



War - The Military VictoryUse force against your opponents. Ignore the conventions of war and place yourself above the laws of parliament and nobility. With the crisis of war, you can enforce the law of the strongest and destroy your enemies. Millions will lose their lives, yet lay the foundation of a new era. Will you triumph?



Triage - The Hero VictoryReduce access to resources and drive up their prices immeasurably. Provoke hunger and misery. Push the population to the limit of their ability to suffer. With the “Triage” crisis, you and your fellow players will incur considerable costs to save the people. Who of you will become the people´s saviour and direct the anger of the masses against those in power?



Tyranny - The Story VictoryGive in to your greed for the Syncanite and make a pact with the Order: Help its leader to the Emperor’s throne and serve under him to your own advantage! With the “Tyranny” crisis, you face a final boss scenario that revolvse around one great question: Do you accept the Emperor and win by his side, or do you all together coup at the right moment to reestablish the Foundation?

Which fire will you ignite?



Learn More:Syncanite Foundation - Soon on Kickstarter! Follow now:
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/timon-thone/the-world-o...;term=syncanite%20Foundation

Find out more on our Website:
https://arkaniteproductions.de/en/syncanite-foundation-the-b...

—description from the designer
categories: Bluffing, Civilization, Deduction, Dice, Economic, Fantasy, Negotiation, Novel-based, Political, Wargame
mechanics: Action/Event, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Auction/Bidding, Betting and Bluffing, Deduction, Dice Rolling, End Game Bonuses, Events, Income, Investment, Loans, Market, Multi-Use Cards, Negotiation, Push Your Luck, Trading, Voting

name: Frankenstein Madness
description:
A unique print-and-play horror board game for 1-8 players, based on the Frankenstein mythos.

This game is for 4-8 players assuming the roles of characters inspired by one of the world’s greatest horror stories spanning books and movies.

With this base set, you’ll get two different playing experiences as you dive deep into the darkness of an evil-filled world:
The base game for 4-8 players, and a solo-play highly-narrative campaign.

The game plays in a maximum of 6 rounds, each one dividen in 3 phases:

Gather, In which you select one of the 6 options to gain resources, with an unique system that allows you to receive resources from adjacent players (you give them resources too).
Conspire, You will hire a service in one of the 8 available locations (2 possible actions per location), which will be resolved in the next phase (survive).


Interlude: You can reveal your secret character to activate your unique character power and get close to your objective.

Survive, The hired actions resolve in location order, hurting some players, protecting others or giving you that advantage you need to achieve victory.


Reaching the personal goal will cause the end of the game. Some characters may do it during phase 3, others at the end of that phase. The winner will be the person with the most Victory points (reaching the goal will give a gross amount of those sweet points).

—description from the publisher
categories: Horror, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Print & Play
mechanics: Hidden Roles, Roles with Asymmetric Information, Worker Placement

name: Shadows of Brimstone: A Trick Up Your Sleeve Promo Card
description:
A secret promo card handed out at Dicefest 2022, only to those that attended a joke panel. Aaron from Flying Frogs claimed to have the ultimate secret to painting, and offered a panel on his finding. He jokingly stalled the entire time, then told guests he would tell them one at a time in a private room what the secret was. Once at the back room, he would tell the guest to keep the joke going and pretend there was a crazy secret, and this card was given as a thanks.

Gear Card: Discard to choose one die just rolled and turn it to be any face of that die instead of what it rolled. (Discarding of this item may not be prevented in any way).
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Shadows of Brimstone: 2 Elemental Dragons Promo Card
description:
An exclusive promo card offered during the Forbidden Fortress Kickstarter. A second Sho Riu must have been added to your pledge in order to get this card.

Epic Threat: Draw an enemy trait card for each elemental dragon. lesser Dragons… Elemental dragons have -40 health each.
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Shadows of Brimstone: A Cunning Disguise
description:
A promo card given to those at Dicefest 2022 who entered the costume contest:

Gear card: Discard to cancel an attack targeting you (even after dice have been rolled to hit), or to remove all unwanted attention markers from every hero.
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Shadows of Brimstone: Rotten to the Core
description:
AN exclusive Darkness promo card given to certain attendees of Dicefest 2022. In order to receive this card, you must have checked out Shadows of Brimstone from the game library, where you were then given a secret mission for the game, and those that participated received this card.

Darkness: ALl undead enemies gain Rotten 5+ - Immune to critical hits and rolls the heal every wound it has at the start of the turn, on a D6 roll of 5+ each (Max heal 5 per turn). Remains in play.
mechanics: Unspecified

name: BLASTBOTS
description:
BLASTBOTS is a competitive race-against-the-clock game with a focus on resource management and strategic card play.

The Story So Far: CHAOS ON KHAOS-5!

For the last 5,000 years, the BLASTBOTS have been locked in an endless battle royale for control over their planet, KHAOS-5! You are the robochief of one of the tribes, and you just detected a gigantic meteor hurtling towards your home. You have two objectives — and only ten turns to accomplish them.

Goal #1: Evacuate as many of your passenger rockets as robot-ily possible before the meteor impacts KHAOS-5!

Goal #2: Sabotage other BLASTBOTS’ escape efforts by bringing their rockets down!

Resource Management
It’s all about strategy. And resources. And management. And resource management. Deploy resource tokens to operate different sections of KHAOS-5’s manufacturing infrastructure. Each section of the board represents different card draws, and you can reallocate your tokens at an opportune moment to surprise your opponents and disrupt their strategies.

Card-driven
There are rocket, battle, and discovery cards, and players can draw from the three different decks based on their resource token placement on the resource grid.

The types of cards:
Rocket cards super-charge your escape efforts, letting your rockets escape the doomed planet into the safety of space.

Battle cards offer different ways to sabotage other robotribes’ escape efforts every step of the way. From destroying rockets in an opponent’s factory, launchpad, or even in the atmosphere, your battle cards can inflict the worst kind of damage. . .MAJOR damage.
Discovery cards modify rocket and battle cards present rare opportunities to gain an upper hand in this chaotic struggle.

Remember: You’re racing time; and time is pretty quick.
Meteors slow no robot. You start the game with ten turns to evacuate your BLASTBOTS and sabotage your enemies. When the first player’s meteor totem crosses the threshold to IMPACT, the game ends. Big boom — and maybe doom.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Multi-Use Cards, Random Production

name: Taproot
description:
Taproot is a light abstract puzzle strategy game designed for two players that takes 2 minutes to learn and 10 minutes to play.

To set up the game, one player arranges the rock tokens and starting plant in the play area while the other player places the water tokens in the game box, gives it a shake to randomize the tokens, and then spills them out onto the play area.

Starting with the player who most recently watered a plant, players take turns connecting root pieces to the starting plant, aiming to collect as many water tokens of their specific color as possible. Players must strategically avoid rocks, while also being mindful not to inadvertently help the other player with their root placements. The game comes to an end when either player has collected all of their water tokens or no more roots can be placed.

Whether you seek a leisurely, relaxing experience to savor with a cup of tea and casual conversation, or desire an intense, strategic face-off where every root placement counts, Taproot delivers a unique and enjoyable gaming experience each time you sit down to play!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Connections, Race, Tile Placement, Variable Set-up

name: Odds Of Chaos
description:
Odds Of Chaos is a card where each player is trying to be the first to get rid of all the cards in their hand. This is done by matching the active card's suite color, number or phrase.

This game has a range of challenge and wild cards that can drastically impact how many cards a player is holding and the length of the game. The wild cards are weighted to be more beneficial during the beginning and middle of the game. However, because the cards in a player's hand can change quickly, strategy is limited but nothing is all luck.

The combination of using shape and color for suites was intentional to make the game more inclusive for players with impaired color vision.

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Hand Management, Matching, Push Your Luck, Take That

name: Knightmare: Usque Ad Mortem
description:
A competitive strategy game of sword, sorcery & mutations for 2 to 6 players. Each player controls a Knight, only 1 will survive and win.

The players will move on the map and collect items and abilities that will help them improve their knight and defeat the other players. Not only items such as weapons will be available but also traps, body mutations and "mystical powers" will improve the character to give them an advantage against their opponents.

The turns will take place in an always different fashion so that the order of the moves will be very important in determining who can attack (and kill) first. The players will wage war against each other on a no quarter battle, collecting loot for every kill.

The last man standing is the winner.
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Turn Order: Random, Variable Player Powers

name: Missing Lynx
description:
The deck consists of 7 animal cards, 7 food cards, and 7 location cards. Each card displays 5 clues about its subject. The picture on each card is repeated on one of 7 "endemic set" tiles. Each such tile displays a picture of each type and can be claimed by the first player to collect all three cards of the set during the game. One card of each type is secretly placed in an envelope, as in Clue. The rest of the cards are dealt.

A die determines which hemisphere a player may visit on his turn. A second die determines whether a player (i) asks another player to read aloud a clue about a specified card type in that other player's hand, (ii) asks another player to give him a specific card, or (iii) names one card of each type and asks another player to give him one of those cards. A location in a request must be the location that the player is visiting.

The game ends when a player correctly guesses the contents of the envelope. Points are scored for ending the game, for collecting the cards that constitute endemic sets, and for optionally reading aloud some clues displayed on cards that one receives during the game. Most points wins.
mechanics: Deduction, Set Collection

name: NEO SPARTA
description:
Revolutionize your tabletop gaming experience with NEO SPARTA - the board game that blends classic mechanics with cutting edge A.I. technology.

The challenge is: Can one artist develop a AAA board game with the help of A.I. and launch it successfully on kickstarter?

NEO SPARTA is a medium complexity premium strategy board game set in a futuristic dystopian world.

It is designed for 3 to 5 players, revolves around combat, deck building, area control mechanics, and supports Augmented Reality.

Players control one of five asymmetric factions and their corresponding leaders:
• The Cyber Elites led by Neonidas
• The Mega Corporations led by Gorgo
• The City-States led by Lysander
• The A.I. Faction led by Nabis
• The Black Hand Collective led by Cynisca

Players acquire resources such as Pelanors (currency), Energy, and Influence by controlling areas on the game map.
These resources are essential for constructing buildings, recruiting and maneuvering units, utilizing card effects, and upgrading research.

The game can be won…
• … by reaching 80 Victory Points, or
• … by destroying two opponents' capitals, or
• … by being the last player remaining on the board.

The game is lost…
• … if your capital is not constructed before reaching 40 Victory Points, or
• … if your capital is destroyed, or
• … if your Pelanor debt exceeds minus 10.

Each regular round consists of five phases, commencing after an initial event.
• Drafting Phase: players assemble their decks by selecting cards.
• Admin Phase: players collect resources, purchase cards, and build structures.
• Units Phase: players build and move units, as well as play additional cards.
• Combat Phase: players resolve battles, form alliances, and capture structures.
• Victory Phase: air units return to their airports, players reveal quest cards, tally Victory Points for area control, retire cards, and repurchase cards.

Additionally, there are two Summit Phases during the game where new laws are introduced.

-description from designer
categories: Card Game, Economic, Fantasy, Industry / Manufacturing, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Mythology, Negotiation, Science Fiction, Wargame
mechanics: Action Drafting, Alliances, Area Movement, Auction: Fixed Placement, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Cooperative Game, Deck Construction, Dice Rolling, Events, Finale Ending, Income, Loans, Movement Points, Moving Multiple Units, Open Drafting, Victory Points as a Resource, Voting, Worker Placement

name: Hostile Hoarders: Enhancements 'N' Events
description:
Expansion pack containing:

5 Unique translucent Pets cards;
9 Unique Events cards;
9 additional Weapon cards;
7 Enhancements cards (Kickstarter Stretch goals)
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Anna Maria Island-Opoly
description:
A Monopoly-like game featuring place and things around Anna Maria Island, Florida USA.

Buy your favorite Anna Maria Island properties, increase your rent by collecting city blocks and trading them in for Keys to the City. Sounds easy? Well add in some traffic jams, property tax, and the IRS and it gets a little more difficult and a lot more fun.

6 unique movers: High Five, Big Smile, Heart, The Dog, Pretzel, and Gym Shoe.
mechanics: Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: Crystal Cup Rally
description: Players take turns rolling two dice and racing their vehicles around a 3-D track. The speed die dictates how many spaces a vehicle may move; the action die permits players to move obstacles or change lanes. Certain spaces on the track generate crystals that can be used to overcome obstacles or take short cuts or move faster. The first player to complete two laps wins.
mechanics: Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Catharsis: Divine Wrath
description:
A divine aura has engulfed the world, tainting the once wonderous beauties of its fragile being.

Divine Wrath is solo & cooperative dice rolling adventure board game for 1 to 5 players. You and other heroes will choose a hero and encounter a boss deck. Each boss deck features their own narrative and choices to make as you roll your dice with simultaneous action gameplay to navigate through traps, events, monsters, locations & more. Each game is a different experience as each hero has a deck of powers they draw from, creating unique synergies every playthrough. The game lasts 45 minutes to 1.5 hours, and by the end, win or lose, you will definitely be excited for your next challenge!

—description from the designer
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Chaining, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, Re-rolling and Locking, Simultaneous Action Selection, Solo / Solitaire Game, Storytelling

name: The Witch Pot
description:
In The Witch Pot players are kids trying to cast out the evil witch that has cursed their forest and village. They gather crystals, pumpkins, fireflies and mushrooms to brew potions while trying to avoid curses. Precision is essential in finding the perfect combination of potions that banish the witch and make you the village hero. Fast paced action with a quick learning curve makes The Witch Pot accesible and replayable while offering enough depth for skill development.

The game develops over a series of turns in which players throw rings trying to capture specific or random poles in order to collect ingredient cards or color tokens. Using these resources they are able to brew potions at the end of each turn. The first player to brew 3 potions is the village hero.

The competition element of the game is found in the fact that only the topmost ring around each pole is considered as the winning ring. Therefore, players have to make constant tactical choices.

Players can also try to capture the black pole in the middle of the game board. In doing so, they are able to steal other players color tokens and use them to their own advantage.

Ready, set, throw...
mechanics: Flicking

name: Magic Number
description:
Magic Number is a Rummy style card game with a twist!
Played in 13 rounds, each round has an increasing number of cards with a different Magic Number as a wild card.
The aim is to collect the right combinations to be the first to come out and then enjoy watching opponents squirm to minimise their losses. The player with the lowest score wins.
What makes this game so much fun for all ages is that every round is a new opportunity to turn the game around. It’s anyone’s game until the very last round. Oh yes, and don’t mind the laughter when a player accidentally discards the Magic Number!

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Highest-Lowest Scoring

name: Gemwielders: Rocket Shield
description:
A brand new Gembearer (starting deck) for Gemwielders Deckbuilding Game. It comes with two full art versions of the core set Gembearers Hammer and Pistol.

A century ago, Discwielders patrolled the skies, securing the outer provinces of the empire. When the second emperor passed, many gave up their Rocket Shields to not get caught in the aftermath. Some of these discs, however, survived the decades, hidden away, waiting for a suited Gemwielder to be taken to the skies once again.

Not only does the Rocket Shield’s passive ability allow you to play power costed gem cards more reliably early, it also provides you with a steady stream of power throughout the entire game. The price for this headstart is a power hungry starting deck. Efficient power generation and power expenditure therefore become key features of the discwielding playstyle.
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Deck Construction, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Open Drafting, Variable Phase Order

name: Moonlight Ascendance: A game of arcane strife.
description:
Moonlight Ascendance – A game of arcane strife is a competitive strategy game wherein you face off with up to four other players, each representing a faction fighting for power over the city in which the game takes place!

Moonlight Ascendance is played in rounds, in which the players take turns to spend their actions, treasures and hard-earned money to forward their cause. A player may win in three different ways, which vary depending on the faction they play as. While most have similar core abilities, their varying powers and goals make for differing and exciting playstyles.

During the game players may collect cards, inspired by mythology and folklore, that appear across the map. These might provide new ways for the players to spend their actions, or they might provide new abilities or boons.

The game can be played in multiple ways depending on the amount of players, and the cards and events make for a new experience every time you play. The simple core functions make the game easy to learn, but hard to master.

—description from the publisher
categories: Card Game, Economic, Fantasy, Mythology, Negotiation, Territory Building
mechanics: Action Points, Alliances, Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Events, Moving Multiple Units, Multi-Use Cards, Negotiation, Turn Order: Progressive, Variable Player Powers

name: Atlantis Omni
description:
In a lost City, four factions face each other with a common goal, to claim it. Their unique weapons are their Omnis and the elements of nature fire, water, earth, and void that must be moved strategically to survive and win. Two energy levels for the powerful to activate them and turn the game upside down. Nothing is unlimited, time is running out, energy is running low, every decision counts and the victory is uncertain even after the end...

Atlantis Omni is a unique, handmade energy board game for 2-4 players, that puts you in the role of the leader of one faction, that is trying to prevail to control the City of Atlantis.There are 2 energy levels in the city and 30 Energy cards that define the strategy of the game. Each faction has 4 Omnis, 1 Black Hole as base, and 5 Energy Wheels.The Omnis are flying to Energy Spots inside the City, to confront opposite Omnis or to obtain gravity blocks and upgrate energy levels.The Black Holes control the energy of each faction.Each faction use 1-6 energy per round and uses strategy and bluff to place and activate Energy Wheels on energy Sources.The game ends at the moment that the Counter Gear, which is placed in the center of Atlantis shows 0 (9 rounds). The player who has the greater number of points from the Energy Wheels on the sources on the high energy level wins the game.

The game has glow in the dark features.

-description from designer
mechanics: Area-Impulse, Rock-Paper-Scissors

name: Sammu-ramat: The Gates of Kalhu
description:
It is the year 801 BC in the Neo-Assyrian Empire, Ancient Mesopotamia. Queen Sammuramat’s capital Kalhu is being attacked by the Enemy, and her bannermen are rallying to form a Queen’s Guard to defend the city.

This card game simulates a field battle outside the Gates of Kalhu. You will need two decks: One for the Enemy and one for Queen’s Guard of 2-4 players. ♠ represent Military, ♦ represent Supplies, ♣ represent Diviners (Priests) and ♥ represent Medicine.

The game is played by taking tricks, where the first-played card decides what suit to follow. Winning a ♠ trick means that the opponent side will take Military Power losses. The team that gets the opponent side down to Zero Military wins the game.

-description from designer
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Communication Limits, Trick-taking

name: Hunter x Hunter: En Route Vers Greed Island
description:
Embody one of your Hunter heroes! In this cooperative game, players embody Hunters that dive into the Greed Island game. They'll need to find all 100 Greed Island Collection cards to win. The Hunters will have to face many opponents and solve many missions to find them before Bomber!

The Genthru team is approaching the end of the game, they are only missing a few cards to collect! Gon, Kirua, Biscke, and their allies will have to take on perilous challenges and survive hard battles to stop their progression and finish the game for the very first time in history.

On your turn, each hunter can choose an action from the following:


Resolve a mission to be rewarded with health or money.
Fight and opponent for a chance to push Bomber back or gain a Greed Island Collection card.
Shop bonus cards to get benefits.
Rest to gain money and discard a mission or opponent.


The object of the game is to reveal the 8 Greed Island Collection cards, which correspond to a total of 100 Spell cards, before the Bomber group has reached the end of the Bomber group Progress track or before 3 Hunters are KO'd.
mechanics: Cooperative Game

name: Leblin
description:
Introduction:Leblin (from German: Lebenslinie, meaning "lifeline") is a drawless game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board of triangles. The recommended size is 9 points per side, but it can be played on a 11–sized board for longer games or a 7–sized board for shorter games. There is also a location outside the board called prison. Each player has access to a sufficient supply of stones of their own color.



Definitions:– A lifeline is a path of uninterrupted empty points located in a straight line from a stone to the edge of the board, and it is said to be cut when enemy stones are placed on it. However, when a stone is placed on the lifeline of a friendly stone, the length of its lifeline is reduced to that stone, that is, a new shorter lifeline is created.
– A group is a set of connected stones of the same color. A stone is also a group.
– A living group is a group that contains at least one uncut lifeline, otherwise it is dead and is moved to prison.
– A territory is one or more empty points connected to each other. You own a territory if all the stones connected to it are your color.



Turns:Black plays first and then turns alternate. On your turn, do exactly one of these actions:

– Place a stone of your color on an empty point, then move all dead enemy groups to prison. After this action, the stone you placed must be part of a group with at least one uncut lifeline, and the position of the board must be different from the positions of the board at the end of all your previous turns.
– Remove an enemy stone from the prison.



End of the game:– The player who made the last action wins the game, so passing the turn is not allowed.
– A player has the option to "propose end" of the game and the other player must accept it or not. In case of acceptance, the points will be counted by adding the friendly territory and enemy prisoners, in addition to granting half an extra point to the player who made the last move.

For the game to be fair, before it begins, the first player places several black stones in prison and then the second player chooses the sides. This balancing method is called komi foot. For handicap games, the weaker player takes black and opens by placing on the board a number of black stones proportional to the skill difference between the players.



Notes:The prison mechanism was introduced by David Wolfe and Elwyn Berlekamp in their book Mathematical Go: Chilling Gets the Last Point.

—description from designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Line of Sight

name: Les
description:
Introduction:Les (from Middle English: -les, meaning "without, empty, -less") is a board game for two players: Black and White. It is played at the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board of triangles. The recommended size is 9 points per side, but it can be played on a 11–sized board for longer games or a 7–sized board for shorter games. Each player has access to a sufficient supply of stones of his own color.



Definitions:– A hole is one or more empty points connected to each other. You own a hole if all the stones connected to it are your color and when you build them you are said to be digging them.
– The size of a hole is the number of empty points it contains.



Turns:Black plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, you perform these actions in the following order:

1. Place a stone of your color on an empty point adjacent to friendly and enemy stones simultaneously.
2. Place a stone of your color on an empty point not adjacent to any stone.

When neither player can take the second action because the board is filling up, both players take only the first action.



End of the game:The game ends when a player runs out of moves, the player winning under the following conditions in order of importance:

1. The player with the most holes made up of stones of their assigned color wins.
2. In case of a tie, the player with the biggest hole wins, the next biggest holes being used for the tiebreaker.
3. In case of a tie in the size of the holes, the player whose biggest hole contains the most stones connected to him wins, the next biggest holes with the most stones connected to him are used for the tiebreaker.

If neither player managed to form a hole, it is a tie (it is very unlikely that any player will form at least one).

To keep the game fair, before play begins, the first player sets four starting stones, one black adjacent to a white, and one black one point away from a white. The second player chooses the sides.

–description from designer
mechanics: Chaining, Hexagon Grid, Pattern Building

name: Fravan
description:
Introduction:Fravan (from Gothic: Fraujinassus, meaning "dominion") is a drawless game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board of triangles. It can be played on a 7–sized board for long games or a 5–sized board for short games. Each player has access to a single set of identical stones of two colors, one color on the front and another color on the back.



Definitions:– A flank is a configuration where two friendly stones in a straight line (along one of the six cardinal directions) are at the same distance from a stone, with the same number of empty points (which can be zero) and no other stones in between.
– To flip is to replace a stone with a stone of the opposite color.
– A territory is one or more empty points flanked by friendly stones that are not flanked by enemy stones. You own a territory if the stones flanking it are your color.



Turns:Black plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, you can pass your turn or perform these actions in the following order:

1. Place a stone of your color on an empty point.
2. Flip all enemy stones flanked by friendly stones.
3. Flip all friendly stones flanked by enemy stones.

If when you perform the previous actions there are more flanked stones, perform actions 2 and 3 in that order until at the end of your turn there are no flanked stones left. Stones can be flipped only once by the most recent flank during the entire game if they are flanked by friendly and enemy stones simultaneously.



End of the game:The game ends when both players pass their turn consecutively. At the end of the game, points are counted by adding up the friendly territory and the friendly stones on the board.

The player with the highest score in the final position wins.

For the game to be fair, before the game begins, the first player places a black stone on an empty point and the second player chooses whether to play with that stone or to continue with the white ones. This balancing method is called the pie rule.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, Hexagon Grid

name: A Brilliant Fight: The Battle of Queenston Heights, October 13, 1812
description:
“We shall save our own land—wipe away part of the score of our past disgrace, get excellent barracks and winter quarters, and at least be prepared for an early campaign another year.”—General Van Rensselaer’s summation of the benefits of gaining a secure foothold in the Niagara Peninsula before the onset of winter, September 1812.

A key element in the American campaign to take control Canada was securing the Niagara Peninsula in 1812. This endeavor was increasingly important to the US war effort following the surrender of an entire American army at Detroit during the summer of 1812. However, a crossing of the Niagara River near Lake Ontario was guarded by Fort George, while those near Buffalo near Lake Erie were dominated by the Queenston Heights. The Americans gambled that a quick early morning assault on Queenston Heights could gain them a bridgehead that could very well lead to the capture of Ontario. Can you do as well, or better, than your historical counterparts? Learn and enjoy!

Each copy of A Brilliant Fight is composed of the following:

• One 11 by 17 inch map with Turn Record Track.
• 100 double-sided counters.
• This set of rules.

Players will also need a standard deck of playing cards and a six-sided die to play the game.

Players use the cards to determine which player gets to activate and with how many units/formations, as wall as when to a random event can occur or the end of game turn. The six-sided die is used to resolve combats (fire or assault), as well as various game events (rally checks, random event determination).

-description from designer
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid

name: Lanquia
description:
Introduction:Lanquia (from Spanish: Flanking, which means "flanking") is a drawless game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board. The recommended board size is 9 points per side, but it can be played on an 11-sized board for longer matches or a 7-sized board for shorter matches. Each player has access to a sufficient supply of their own colored stones.



Definitions:– A flank is a configuration in which two friendly stones in a straight line (along one of the six cardinal directions) are at any distance from an enemy stone and without other friendly stones in between.
– A chain is a set of stones of the same color connected in a straight line. A single stone is also a chain.
– A live chain is a chain that is not flanked by enemy stones, otherwise it is dead and is removed from the board.
– A territory is a set of empty points that see more friendly stones than enemy stones in line. An empty point that sees them is also a territory. You are the owner of a territory if the stones that see them are your color.



Turns:Black plays first and then they alternate. On your turn, you can either pass your turn or perform these actions in the following order:

1. Place a stone of your color on an empty point that does not see more enemy stones than friendly stones in a straight line through empty points.
2. Remove all dead stones.



End of the Game:The game ends when the board is full or both players consecutively pass their turn. At the end of the game, points will be counted by adding up the friendly territory and friendly stones on the board.

To make the game fair, before the game starts, the first player places a black stone on an empty point and the second player chooses a side. This balancing method is called the pie rule.

–description from designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Enclosure, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight

name: Night Witches
description:
Night Witches is a solitaire or two-player cooperative player game in which the Night Witches–female pilots of the Soviet 588th Night Bomber Regiment–work together to fly harassment missions on the Eastern Front during WWII. Their planes are rickety and minimally equipped, but with their engines whirring quietly and with the dark of night to cloak them, the Night Witches are flying towards promotion to 46th Guards Night Bomber Aviation Regiment–and towards making aviation history!

Night Witches is a light wargame that consists of a ten-mission campaign, during which the pilots try to amass enough victory points to be promoted to form a Guards unit, a great honor in the Soviet military. Each mission lasts roughly 30 minutes, and each can be played on its own, separately from the campaign. On each mission, two planes will venture into unknown territory to complete a specific goal and to earn victory points. As they fly, players will observe the terrain around them by drawing tokens from a bag. Some tokens will merely represent the night, but the players will also need to avoid spotlights, navigate through clouds, respond to attacks from AAA, and more.

Each mission is made up of multiple sorties, with brief recovery times between. During sorties, players will evade enemy fire–and bomb targets–by pulling from a bag containing success, failure, and stress tokens. During recovery, they will have to manage their time, fuel supply, and stress levels. As pilots gain experience and complete missions, they will also be able to acquire upgrade cards. (Those victory points are good for something!) Will the Night Witches be able to dodge AAA, do maximum damage to the Nazis, and fly off into the sunrise?

-description from publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deck, Bag, and Pool Building, Hexagon Grid, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Scieldweall
description:
An abstract strategy game base on unique moves. Use your pieces to escape and free your king. Or get captured by the enemy.

Place all your pieces on your side of the board. The enemy does the same. Then you move every piece one at a time. This is a turn base strategy game. Every piece moves differently. The one common factor is every piece captures other enemy pieces. Most of the time you perform a triangle attack to capture the enemy on a hex board. you want to either capture the enemy king or have your king escape to the other side.

This is an abstract strategy game that you could relate to chess.

Every turn you move one piece and then pass the turn to the enemy.

You win by capturing the enemy king or escaping your king to the other side.

–description from designer
mechanics: Hexagon Grid, Moving Multiple Units, Real-Time

name: Nestorgames GP: Gate and Teleport Board
description: A more complicated board with a teleport space, a gate and a few extra pieces to implement it.
mechanics: Push Your Luck

name: Nadraz
description:
Nadraz (from Proto-Germanic: Nadraz, meaning "snake") is an abstract board game for two players who play on an initially empty hexagonal board.

Objective:
The objective of the game is to build the longest snake possible, that is, one that contains the largest number of stones.

Components:
– A hexagonal board with 9 intersections per side.
– One set of black stones and one set of white stones.

Definitions:
– A snake is a non-forked chain of two or more stones connected to each other.
– A head or tail is a stone adjacent to only one friendly stone and is located at the ends of a snake, it is not allowed to leave it adjacent to two friendly stones unless it is no longer located at the ends (in which case it would cease to be the head or the tail).

Turns:
Black plays first, then alternate. On your turn, do one of the following placements:

– Advance by placing any number of stones of your color on empty intersections located in a straight line, from the front of the head or tail of one of your snakes.
– Turn by placing any number of stones of your color on empty intersections located in a straight line, from the side of the head or tail of one of your snakes.
– Bend by placing any number of stones of your color on empty intersections located in a straight line, from the back of the head or tail of one of your snakes.

Each stone you place must be adjacent to one or two friendly stones, one of those stones must be the head or tail of one of your snakes to make it grow. However, you can place a stone that touches any number of friendly stones only if one of them is the head or tail of another snake(s), in order to join them to form a larger one.

Cutting snakes:
When we grow a snake, we can cut enemy snakes by passing through them. When cutting an enemy snake, we go to one of its stones in a straight line to replace it with one of our color, to do so there must be an empty intersection on the other side of the replaced stone in which we will place a stone to carry out the cut otherwise it cannot be done. Also, it is not allowed to cut off the head or tail of a snake.

Isolated stones:
It's possible that after a player cuts through his opponent's snakes there are isolated stones left, i.e. no adjacent friendly stones. As an isolated stone isn't considered a snake, it's forbidden to join isolated stones, as they must remain isolated throughout the game.

End of the game:
When a player cannot make placements, they must pass their turn. In case no one can do it, the game ends and the player with the snake that contains the most stones wins, in case of a tie the player with the next snake wins and so on.

To make the game fair, before the game begins, the first player places two starting snakes of two stones, one black and one white, on empty intersections on the board and the second player chooses the sides. This balancing method is called the four-stone pie rule.
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Chaining, Hexagon Grid

name: Worden
description:
In Worden, players utilize words to find clues and deduce what letters are hiding in their opponent’s hand. The first player to correctly guess all three letters in their opponent’s hand wins the game!

The game requires an alphabet deck comprised of 26 letter cards.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Print & Play, Word Game
mechanics: Deduction

name: Valaturna
description:
Introduction:Valaturna (from the Proto-Germanic: Walaturna, meaning "ruling tower") is a no-draw game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board. It can be played on a 7-sized board for long games or on a 5-sized board for short games. Each player has access to a sufficient supply of stackable pieces of their own color.



Definitions:– A stack is a set of pieces located at the same point, one on top of the other. A single piece is also a stack.
– The color of a stack is the color of its top piece, which indicates its owner.
– The height of a stack is the number of pieces it contains.
– A chain is a set of stones of the same color connected in a straight line.
– A flank is a configuration where two friendly stones in a straight line (along one of the six cardinal directions) are at the same distance from one or more enemy chains, with the same number of empty points N in between and N empty points on both sides (where N can be zero), and no friendly stones in between.
– To flip is replacing a stone with a stone of the opposite color.



Turns:Black moves first, then turns alternate. On your turn, you can either pass your turn or take the following actions in the following order:

1. Place a stack of your color with height 1 on an empty point that can see a friendly stack in a straight line through empty points.
2. Place a piece of your color on any flanked enemy stacks during your placement to increase their height and take control of them.



End of the game:The game continues until a player manages to create the tallest stack that cannot be captured. This means forming a stack that cannot be flanked by enemy stacks. The game ends at this point because the player who achieves this will generally not cooperate with their opponent to form stacks that reach or exceed that height, as it is not in their best interest.

To ensure fairness, before the game starts, the first player places a black stack and a white stack on an empty point, and the second player chooses a side. This balancing method is called the two-stack pie rule.

—description from designer
mechanics: Enclosure, Hexagon Grid

name: Spiritual Dominion
description:
Who is the master of this land, the psychic who calls himself an angel? Selfish citizens? Or a schemer wearing a monstrous mask? Everyone said that God promised to become the master of this world after seven days. God never appeared, but from the first day, everyone's inner thoughts will be presented to everyone in the next morning.

Victory conditions for the three factions
Leviathan 1: Draw a card from the deck every round and distribute it to anyone other than yourself. Each player can have multiple cards. There were three declarations of artifacts on the field at the same time, and Leviathan won. Leviathan was not allowed to reveal or hint to others what the card he gave to others was.
Angel 1-2: The task of an angel is to preach. Each round marks a player in the spiritual field. When the mark reaches 3 (Leviathan needs seven marks), this character is regarded as a believer. The believer on the spot plus the angel Wins when the number is greater than half the number.
Humans 2-5: Conditions for victory. After seven days, neither Leviathan nor Angel wins.
Cooperation and deceit will of course be required to win, but remember that you are all God's children so in some cases your alignment will change.
At the beginning of the game, each player draws an identity card (Leviathan, human, angel), Leviathan shows his identity, and then draws a card from the pile to represent the beginning of a new day, everyone takes turns to speak, and finally Leviathan decides Who is this card for (the three rounds of getting the card can be activated), and then enter the night, people other than the angels close their eyes, the angels start to preach, and they can put a mark on the spirit collar. At dawn after 10 seconds, Leviathan draws the next card and repeats this cycle seven times.
There are three artifacts in the deck that can be used all the time, three events that happen once and a blank Bible book, a total of seven cards and seven rounds, representing what happened within seven days.
Artifact "Lantern"
You can check the identity of others. You can change the imprint arrangement in the spiritual realm
Artifact "laurel crown"
You can remove a marker from a player
Artifact "Sword"
You can kill a player, and whoever kills the Leviathan becomes the new Leviathan.

Event "The Dragon on the Spire"
Leviathan and Instigator get an extra chance to question
Event "Sermon not from the gods"
Directly discard the cards for the next round (the number of rounds minus one)
Event: "Dark March"
People who have been preached join the angel camp and no longer follow the civilians to victory.
Event 'Blank Bible'
Nothing happened.
Claim: Leviathan can't say what he is dealt, and the person who gets the card can claim that he is any one of the seven claims, and the effect can be activated as long as no one questions it. The person who doubts can open the station when the skill is activated. If it is true, he will be silenced for one round. If it is false, he will get this card from the opponent. No one doubts and can change his claim in the next round. Each person can only question once.
mechanics: Betting and Bluffing, Hidden Roles, Negotiation, Prisoner's Dilemma, Semi-Cooperative Game, Variable Player Powers

name: Legend of Kartlos
description:
The Legend of Kartlos is a board game based on Georgian mythology and is designed for 1-4 players. Each player takes on the role of the god, with three demigods at their side to help them conquer the mythical kingdom of ancient Georgia and become its ultimate ruler.

Each of the character has unique strengths and abilities, making the game different and exciting every time you play. You can choose to play as Aiet - the King of Colchis and the father of the legendary Medea, Rokap - the master of the witches, Amiran - the great hero of Georgia, or Atinat - the powerful Goddess of the sun.

—description from the publisher
categories: Adventure, Ancient, Educational, Fantasy, Medieval, Mythology
mechanics: Area Movement, Hidden Victory Points, Role Playing

name: Braunche
description:
Introduction:Braunche (from Middle English: Braunche, meaning "branch") is a drawless game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board with triangles. The recommended size is 9 points per side, but it can be played on a 11–sized board for longer games or a 7–sized board for shorter games. Each player has access to a sufficient supply of stones of their own color.



Definitions:– A group is a set of connected stones of the same color. A single stone is also a group.
– A branch is a subgroup of connected stones within a group that occupy the empty points of the edge. A single stone on the edge is also a branch.
– The value of a group is the number of branches it contains according to the triangular score, which is calculated by adding the consecutive natural numbers from 1 to the number of branches in the group.



Turns:Black plays first and then turns alternate. On your turn, perform one of the following actions:

– Place a stone of your color on an empty point.
– Pass your turn.



End of the Game:The game ends when both players pass their turn consecutively. At the end of the game, points are counted by adding the value of all friendly groups, plus an extra half point to the player who passed their turn first.

To make the game fair, before the game starts, the first player chooses an integer as the komi value and then the second player chooses the sides. This balancing method is called komi pie.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Chaining, Connections, Hexagon Grid

name: Tour De Goa
description:
A card game to create and spread awareness about various places in Goa, India. Games designed by Veer Kashyap.

Concept

The concept of the game is based on virtual tour of our Goa
The game is developed based on basic information available in open source for recreational purposes
The objective is to introduce children and all Board Game lovers to Goa and various tourist attractions of Goa including dishes and restaurants.
Each Player will be distributed with 10 cards / 08 cards (randomly) from the pack of cards. Every player views his/her cards and tries to match the card in the Discard Pile.
Each player will place down one card (Tourist Card / Challenges Card) at a time in the Discard Pile.
Next player to match the card (Season Colour /Tourist attraction/Number) or undertake the challenge as per Challenge Card.
Each player will locate the place on the Map to visualize the location. (Optional)
All players should play their turn and try to completely drop all cards in turn held with them. The player who has NO card remaining at the end will call ‘GO GOA’ and will be declared as Tourist of the Day. Continue to play any number of rounds with your friends and family members.


Benefits

Introduces to geography of Goa
Introduces to various important places, tourist attractions, dishes and restaurants of Goa.
Virtually know our Goa and basic details about tourist places, dishes and Restaurants


Board Game Content

Pack of Cards with Tourist Cards (each card grouped under four different seasons) and Challenge cards
Tourist Cards (108 cards) with Four different Colors (Summer (orange), Rainy (blue), Winter (grey) and Spring (green)) – Beaches(B), Churches(C), Temples(T), Mosques(M), Restaurants(R), Dishes(D), Forts(F), Museums (Mu), Heritage Houses(H), Eco Tourism(E).
Challenge Cards (45 Cards) - Change Season, VIP Pass, No Entry, U Turn, Drop 2 Cards, Pick 2 Cards
mechanics: Unspecified

name: PROTECT: Africa
description:
The card game created by a 9 year old with a mission! 50% of all profits donated to conservation efforts in Africa.

In this fast-paced card game, you are part of an elite anti-poaching unit that must protect vulnerable wildlife from extinction! Use your turn to save, swap or camouflage different species against the poachers.

On your turn, you may draw a card from the draw pile or discard pile.

If drawn from the discard pile, you must keep the card you chose.

If drawn from the draw pile, you may keep, discard, or play the special action - but beware! If you draw a poacher, the card must be played!

Be the first to save all 13 animals to win!

Handmade in Nigeria through partnership with Nibcard Games.

—description from the publisher
categories: Animals, Card Game, Children's Game, Environmental
mechanics: Move Through Deck

name: Shut Up, Cat!
description:
A push-your-luck game about getting a full night's sleep, despite that darn cat. Based on true events.

In this game, 2-4 players take turns rolling dice and then using the results to choose a span of numbered tiles to reveal. Each tile will either be a 'Z' or a 'Meow!' Score points for each Z, but if you hit any Meows you get nothing. Then, secretly put the tiles back, so only you know what tile is where! First player to forty Z's wins the game.

-description from designer
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Push Your Luck

name: Battle by Order
description:
Immerse yourself in the world of Battle by Order, a strategic and intense two-player card game where champions of different classes engage in thrilling duels. Choose from one of four unique champions: the high-damage Fury Fighter, the cunning Poisoner who lays traps and drains opponents, the Gear Master who excels at building powerful combos, or the Shadow Wraith, a specter that deals burst damage and controls opponents.

In each round, players strategically select three cards from their hand of five and place them face down in anticipation of the upcoming clash. The tension builds as both players simultaneously flip their cards, revealing their chosen actions. The game features four types of cards: Action, Passive, Counter, and Trap, each offering a different strategic approach to the battle.

The game unfolds in a series of these fast-paced rounds, where players must outwit and outmaneuver their opponents, all while managing their hand and planning their next moves. The game ends when a player successfully reduces their opponent's HP from 20 to zero, claiming victory.

Battle by Order is a simultaneous action card game that balances strategy and intensity. The game's mechanics, combined with the unique abilities of the champions, ensure a dynamic and engaging gameplay experience. Whether you're a seasoned card game veteran or a newcomer to the genre, Battle by Order promises a thrilling ride that will keep you coming back for more.

-description from designer
mechanics: Action Queue, Card Play Conflict Resolution

name: Sundraval
description:
Introduction:Sundraval (from Gothic: Sundrawald, meaning "separated territory") is a drawless game for two players: White and Black. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board. The recommended size is 9 points per side, but it can be played on a 11–sized board for longer games or a 7–sized board for shorter games. Each player has access to a sufficient supply of stones of their own color.



Definitions:– A group is a set of connected stones of the same color. A single stone is also a group.
– A territory is a set of uninterrupted empty points bounded by stones of a single color that fill all adjacent locations.
– A path is a set of N uninterrupted empty points (where N can be zero).
– A strangled group is a group that, at the end of the game, meets the following 3 conditions:

1. There is a path from there to larger enemy groups or with territory.
2. It has no territory, nor a path from there to non-strangled friendly groups.
3. There is no path from there to smaller enemy groups that are strangled.



Turns:Black plays first and then alternates. On your turn, perform one of the following actions:

– Place a stone of your color on an empty point that has a path to enemy groups.
– Pass your turn.



End of the Game:The game ends when both players consecutively pass their turn.

Immediately before scoring, remove all strangled enemy groups from the board. Then, each of a player's groups with N adjacent territories earns (N^2 + N) / 2 points, i.e., according to the triangular number. In addition, the player with the group that contains the largest territory receives a half point extra (or the next largest).

The player with the total value of groups with territories in their possession wins.

To make the game fair, before it begins, the first player places two initial stones, one black and one white, at any empty point on the board, and the second player chooses the sides. This balancing method is called the two-stone pie rule.



Notes:Special thanks to Drew Edwards and Dale Walton who valuable contributions to improve key aspects; Drew Edwards optimized a key rule, while Dale Walton refined the wording.

–description from designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Chaining, Hexagon Grid, Pattern Building

name: Age of Maths
description: Embark on a journey into the captivating world of mathematics through an engaging card game that celebrates brilliant mathematicians and fascinating mathematical concepts. Battle one or two other players in knocking out mathematicians one by one. The last one left is the winner. Knock out mathematicians by drawing digit cards and using mathematical operations that calculate to your opponent's target number. Use Chaos Cards to gain an advantage. This is a game of strategy and numbers.
mechanics: Unspecified

name: Gawi
description:
Introduction:Gawi (from Gothic: Gawi, meaning "land, region") is a drawless game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board. The recommended size is 9 points per side, but it can be played on a 11–sized board for longer games or a 7–sized board for shorter games. Each player has access to a sufficient supply of stones of their own color.



Definitions:– A group is a set of connected stones of the same color. A single stone is also a group.
– A liberty is an empty point adjacent to a group and is said to be obstructed if an enemy stone occupies it or is adjacent to it.
– A smothered group is a group with all its liberties obstructed.
– A territory is one or more connected empty points. You own a territory if all the stones connected to it are of your color.



Turns:Black plays first, then turns alternate. On your turn, perform one of the following actions:

– Place a stone of your color on an empty point where it is not smothered, then remove from the board all smothered enemy groups.
– Pass your turn.



End of the Game:The game ends when both players pass their turn consecutively. At the end of the game, points are counted by adding up friendly territory and captured enemy stones, plus awarding an extra half point to the player who passed their turn first.

To make the game fair, before the game begins, the first player chooses an integer as a komi value and then the second player chooses the sides. This balancing method is called pie komi.

–description from designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Hexagon Grid

name: Taugo
description:
Introduction:Taugo (from Proto-Germanic: Taugô, meaning "string, rope") is a board game for two players: Black and White. It is played on the intersections (points) of an initially empty square board without the lines on the edges. The recommended board size is 16 points per side. Each player has access to a single set of 256 identical stones of two colors, one color on the front and another color on the back.



Definitions:– A string is a set of same-colored stones connected orthogonally to each other. A single stone is also a string.
– A knot is a 2x2 area of same-colored stones. Formation of knots on strings is prohibited.
– To flip is replacing a stone with a stone of the opposite color.
– A cut point is an empty point adjacent orthogonally to a single stone in a set of stones arranged in a straight line within an enemy string, so that a friendly stone can only access that set by crossing it in a straight line.
– To cut is flipping enemy stones by passing through them in a straight line while accessing their cutting points. You can only cut enemy stones adjacent orthogonally to at least two same-colored stones.
– The value of a string is the number of stones it contains on the perimeter line according to the triangular score, which is calculated by summing the consecutive natural numbers from 1 to the number of stones it contains on the perimeter line.



Turns:Black plays first, then players alternate. On your turn, perform one of the following actions:

– Place a stone of your color on an empty point not adjacent orthogonally to friendly stones.
– Place one or more stones of your color, each on empty points in a straight line adjacent orthogonally to a friendly stone, also being able to do so on enemy stones in the same direction to cut them if some of your newly placed stones occupy all their cut points.
– Pass your turn.

You cannot place a stone on the board edge unless the empty point on the edge becomes a cut point.



End of the game:The game ends when both players pass their turn consecutively. At the end of the game, points are tallied by summing the value of all friendly groups, plus a half-point bonus to the player with the fewer number of strings. Additionally, additional points are awarded for each stone that was able to reach the edge of the board according to the triangular score, but without considering the strings they belong to.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Chaining, Connections, Pattern Building, Square Grid

name: Ruffians
description:
In Ruffians, you are an up and coming pirate captain, striving to become rich and famous. Over the course of the game you will recruit a ruthless crew of fuzzy critters, raid cities, collect treasure, and increase your bounty. After all, the best way to measure fame as a pirate captain is to watch your bounty rise!

The goal of Ruffians is to be the pirate captain with the highest bounty at the end of the game. Your bounty increases as you gain notoriety through raids. You will need to recruit a crew to take on raids and collect treasures.

—description from the publisher
categories: Animals, Card Game, Dice, Fantasy, Nautical, Pirates
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Events, Hand Management, Investment, Market, Random Production, Take That, Turn Order: Stat-Based

name: Crumo
description:
Introduction:Crumo (from Proto-Germanic: Krūmô, meaning "fragment") is a drawless game for two players: Black and White. It is played at the intersections (points) of an initially empty hexagonal board with triangles. It can be played on a 7–sized board for long games or a 5–sized board for short games. Each player has access to a sufficient supply of stackable pieces of their own color.



Definitions:– A stack is a set of pieces located at the same point, one on top of the other. A single piece is also a stack.
– The height of a stack is the number of pieces it contains.
– A guarded point is a point located at a distance equal to the height of a stack, and that stack is said to be guarding it. The stacks also guard the points they occupy.
– A controlled point is a point occupied by a friendly stack or an empty point that can only be occupied by friendly stacks.
– A stack receives an amount of attack equal to the amount of enemy stacks that control the point it occupies, and receives an amount of defense equal to the amount of friendly stacks that control the point it occupies. One or more stacks are dead if they receive more attack than defense and are removed from the board.



Turns:Black plays first and then turns alternate. On your turn, perform one of the following actions:

– Place a stack on an empty point that is at a distance equal to the height of the stack, either in an orthogonal or diagonal direction, towards an empty point or towards a friendly stack, unless it is also towards an enemy stack. At the end of your turn, the newly placed stack cannot be left dead.
– Move a complete stack or a portion of it orthogonally or diagonally a distance equal to the number of pieces taken from that stack. You cannot move a complete stack if your opponent also did so in a turn immediately prior, unless you are capturing. Then remove all dead stacks. At the end of your turn, unlike the newly placed stack, the newly moved stack can be left dead.
– Pass your turn.



End of the game:If a player cannot take any action, he must pass his turn. If both players pass consecutively, the game ends and points are counted by adding the points controlled by friendly stacks and the number of enemy pieces captured, in addition to awarding an extra half point to the player who passed first.

The player with the highest score in the final position wins.

To make the game fair, before starting, the first player places an initial black stack and the second player chooses the sides. This balancing method is called the pie rule.

—description from the designer
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Stacking and Balancing

name: みつばちブンブン (Bee Buzzing)
description:
In みつばちブンブン ("Bee Buzzing"), players cooperatively create and manage a tableau of cards representing a beehive. Their goal is to fill 7 honeycomb cells with honey before the card deck runs out, whilst protecting the queen from hornets and cleaning any trash from the hive.

—user summary

This is an apiary that is very popular for its homemade honey. You are beekeepers working here. It's not easy to make honey because hornets come and garbage accumulates and the nest is ruined. Let's work together to make honey!

—description from the publisher (translated)

ここは自家製のハチミツが大人気の養蜂場。皆さんはここで働く養蜂家です。スズメバチがやってきたりゴミがたまって巣が荒れたりとハチミツ作りは簡単ではありません。みんなで力を合わせてハチミツを作りましょう！

—description from the publisher
mechanics: Cooperative Game

name: Ultimediation
description:
Ultimediation is a cooperative strategy game. Your mission is to restore peace on an Earth plunged into a world war.

This is probably the first board game in the World with such mission!

You are a mixed team of the best human mediators supported by extraterrestrials who are part of a very advanced civilization. You come to Earth in avatars to save humanity and life on Earth. You work together to choose the best strategies to evacuate people, remove attacks and successfully mediate between sides. Will you save the World before Earth is destroyed, human beings are lost forever, or the time for mediation runs out? Up to you to play out!

GAME PLAY

REMOVING ATTACKS
During each game turn, there are attack tiles that land on different places on Earth.
Part of your mission is to undo the destruction that results from the attacks of war. You are endowed with a power that allows you to move in time in the near past, and to modify the present. In the game this is called "removing an attack".

EVACUATION OF HUMANITY
Part of your mission is to save as many people as possible.
When an attack card lands on a square with humans, they escape or they are lost.
To save people the Ultimediation team is teleporting them to the base in Africa and to the space ship.

MEDIATIONS
To succeed in the mission, peace must be restored through mediation. For this purpose, the mediators move to the bases of the warring governments which are in their submarines. They need to get good answers from them.

END OF GAME CONDITIONS
The game ends when one of the following occurs:
- Mediations have been completed with both governments.
In this case, the players have won the game.
- A horizontal line on the board is completely covered by attack tiles.
In this case, the players have lost the game.
- The "game turns" and "lost humanity" cubes come together. That represents losing too many humans and having mediation time run out.
In this case, the players have lost the game.

-description from designer
mechanics: Action Drafting, Area Movement, Card Play Conflict Resolution, Cooperative Game, Dice Rolling, End Game Bonuses, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Lose a Turn, Memory, Moving Multiple Units, Multi-Use Cards, Questions and Answers, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Team-Based Game, Turn Order: Claim Action, Variable Player Powers

name: Diabolical Dave's Rumble Throwdown
description:
